7.5/10  I played Divinity: Original Sin 2 with a group of friends as a Persuasive Lizard, focusing on Summoning and Geomancy. Though the boulders and oil that can be thrown with Geomancy are effective, I initially focused on it to serve as a healer for our Undead tank. Undead are healed by poison, so your party's usual healer can't help them out. However, Geomancy also gave me access to Fortify which I could use to restore physical armor, and Artillery Plant, which was my favorite thing in the game. Artillery plant is a summon that exists in the Geomancy tree, whose level is determined by your Summoning skill. In the game, your most powerful skills cost "source" to cast (sort of a special type of mana). By the end of the game, you will be able to possess three source points at a given time. Source is rare to come by during most of the game, and even towards the end it's not necessarily unlimited. Artillery plant costs a single source point to cast, but then it can cast an extremely powerful spell called "Acid Spores" every two turns, among other strong abilities. If your character were to cast "Acid Spores," instead of the summon, it would cost you two source points every time!  The type of discussion you see above is what makes Divinity: Original Sin 2 so exciting. How can you support the other characters in your party in combat, and what is the optimal way to use your source or action points? If a member of your party has the "Loremaster" ability, you can examine enemies to learn their abilities, talents, and resistances. If an enemy reduces and redirects damage dealt, you may want to attack his friends first. If he has the opportunist talent, you do not want to walk away from melee range as it grants him an attack. If he has a fire resistance of 150%, fire will heal him. You want to constantly take stock of enemy composition and the skills of your party.  If Divinity: Original Sin consisted of a more linear story with more combat encounters, and lasted about 2/3 of its current length, it would be a 10/10 game for me. However, as it stands, I have a few gripes.   Although I'm sure that many players appreciate the ability to complete quests in multiple ways, I just found it frustrating. Some of the solutions are obtuse, and require a lot of poring through documents. Some of the late game puzzles, like pulling levers in a certain order or playing the enormous "pipe dream" game, were just tedious. There are many many quests, and in a multiplayer party it just felt like I was always receiving experience from somewhere because someone in my party was progressing on one of the many many quests in my quest log. While I'm sure some might say that I should've played with a different group of people, there are so many quests with so many solutions that often we made quest progress by aimlessly walking around.   Another issue I had with the title is just how quickly my character advanced. Each character has a maximum of 40 in an attribute, a maximum of 10 in each skill or combat ability, and a maximum of 5 in each civil ability. Each character in our party maxed out at least one of these categories well before the end of the game. In addition, the highest tier of skills in the game become available at level 16, also well before the endgame. Though perhaps others are drawn primarily for the story, this severely hampered my enjoyment of the game. After learning all skills I was interested in, maxing my summoning and my persuasion, I just didn't have as much to look forward to.  I enjoyed most of my time with Divinity: Original Sin 2. The argument could be made that this type of game just isn't for me, but I enjoyed the combat so much that is was worth some of the other irritations.

I just finished my first playthrough last night. Let's get this out of the way: this game is something special. It improves on almost every gripe I had with the original (mainly just story and pacing) and just knocks it out of the park. This is a new gold standard for what a modern RPG should be.    What's Good The companions are memorable, well-written, and have realistic motivations that make negotiating their place in your party really engaging as you strive for the end-goal of the game. (I mean, it makes sense, you can play them as the main character if you wish!)  Combat rewards creativity, exploration, and experimentation without ever feeling like it's unfair towards the player--some fights are tough as nails, but they're just puzzles that you've been given an entire toolbox to solve. It's incredible just how many viable strategies you can employ to build a party and the myriad tactical decisions you can make in combat with those interactions.  Some of the quests and puzzles are pretty inspired--I'm a DM for tabletop group and I can appreciate how hard it is to make a puzzle that's challenging and feels organic to its context while delivering on fun. So hard to do, and 90% of the quests and puzzles in D:OS2 deliver. The quests often have multiple paths to resolution, which can be incredibly satisfying.    (Minor) Gripes I only encountered a few bugs over the course of my game and none of them were show-stopping. (A few dialogue options that didn't make sense because of my choices; quicksave reload breaking a script in combat and requiring rollback; a few quests not updating / reflecting change after I made major progress in them.) The lion's share of these happened in the last two major areas of the game--which I totally understand given the sheer scope of the game.   Long story short: there hasn't been an RPG this rich in a long time. It's worth every penny of the price tag.

Larian turned gold to lead, but this game is probably worth it, provided that you know what you do.  First off, choose wisely your play level. I chose tactician as a veteran of RPG. I was well served. Indeed, tactician it is! But it doesn't say that you should also scratch every single little advantage that you can (steal as much as possible, stack on potions etc.) in order to be well prepared for the last fight. It also doesn't say that you shouldn't expect your characters to be heroic! Indeed, in many situations at that level you will have to resort to cheesy tactics such as some characters fleeing the combat to recover skill timers, heal, then come back while the combat has been frozen because you left one character or invocation hold it... Or by reloading consistently because you were not prepared for a nasty surprise in a combat and had nothing left to deal with it; so you reload, come back with smart prepositionning and the combat will go smoothly. I remember a fight against some outrageous horror -helped by numerous cronies, all of them more powerful than my characters despite being one level above-, which I easily lost head to head, then won after reloading, placing my characters far enough, engaging with invocations and keeping my characters far enough -actually out of combat- that I could always cast a new invocation when one died. I finally won that fight without a scratch. Smart ? sure. Pleasurable ? Hardly.  So unless you like going very slowly, always moving like there is a fight at the next step (or reloading often), managing inventories to be sure each character has the absolute best equipment, has the necessary consumables,  and so on (i.e. total micromanagement), skip the tactician level. At normal level, the game is going to be challenging enough for most players. Especially the last combat, which I never finished -I have done quite well in the first part, but am hopelessly outnumbered in the second part. I probably know what is wrong, but I won't be going back batching the potions that I am missing, respecing my characters to more useful stats, traits and spells, changing runes for more useful ones etc. you get the picture for tactician level.- So, I won't know the end of the story line I chose, and I won't change my storyline just so the last combat is easier. That's a bit sad.  And NO: YOU CANNO'T CHANGE THE DIFFICULTY LEVEL DOWN! That's a real shame!  Also, there is no excuse for larian in turning an excellent character development/combat system into the mediocre thing that it has become. In that respect, Original Sin 1 was way better. The current system has clearly been designed in order to foil the player and outrageously favor the opponents. You cannot inflict secondary effects (blinding, stunned etc.) as long as the target has magical or physical armor (a new protection that comes above your hit points.) This means that the first rounds of combat are always going to be damage dealing: you won't have any crowd control coming until you've done some attrition first. Worse: the system favors teams which choose a damage type and stick to it. I made the mistake of wanting a balanced party: the result is that I am too weak for the last fight. Actually in some fights, I had characters standing aside, watching the combat go because they did not deal the right kind of damage...  After all this has been said, I still recommend this game because the story looks good, the world is well developped and generally speakig as RPG go, it stands on the top if you don't fall into the trap where I fell.  EDIT: I finally found the courage to do what I said I wouldn't do, and of course finish the game. As expected, I had to respec my characters, and decided to go for lone wolf. The advantage in lone wolf lies not in the power of the characters (they indeed are stronger, but you have overall less firepower), but in the fact that you don't have to bother about the survival or such and such character, as well as reducing the drain on your consumables (you use two instead of four for a similar effect.) The fight was easy [SPOILERS (light) AHEAD] mostly for use of the special tea sold by Mrs Kremm, combined with at least +50% full elemental protection potions and five star dinner -i.e. all elemental damage did heal me, which both let me remove most healing spells as well as use my own offensive spells for healing-, the pawn and duck duck goose (for good movement, not mentioning spells.) Other talents which I thought would help did not (guerilla) [END SPOILERS] ; I changed my main character from pure mage to hybrid melee (fighter) / mage, helped by an archer/assassin ; as explained above, this was a choice to favor physical damage over magical damage, choice made necessary by the difficulty of that fight. I of course had to spend considerable time to prepare the characters and the consumables, buy or craft the required potions and books as well as redistribute equipment. The trouble is that in that fight I did not recognize the character(s) I played consistently from the beginning (no respec before the end), which is annying (to say the least) for a RPG! The other trouble is of course that I could not have to feeling that the hero was well above the other contenders to deserve my victory. Indeed, the stats of all other human opponents were consistently above those of the hero. Understand who can!

I don't usually play Turn Based games; when it comes to RPGs, I'm more of an free actions kind of guy (Gothic, Dragon Age, Witcher etc). However, a colleague told me about Original Sin and I've purchased D:OS EE and had a blast with it. Unfortunately, I arrived late to the party and didn't get a chance to help Larian with their kickstarter for D:OS2, but I did pre-order it (which I almost never do). And I'm glad I did.  The goodThere are some good changes to the first game: - you can choose your companion's class when you recruit them - you can respec your character and your companions at almost any time! - if you respec, you don't lose your learned spells/skills - you now have a skill bar with many slots at the bottom of the screen - summoning, hands-down one of the best class in the game; summons can really turn the tides of battles, especially since they can be infused with different elements - full voice acting (I know EE also has that, but the original D:OS didn't)  The so-soThere are also some changes, let's call them neutral; some I've learned to like, while others not so much: - physical and magic armor: you first have to tear through your opponent's armor before you can apply any CC to them; this bothered me a lot at first, when I didn't have the means to get rid of their armors easily, but, as you gain more skills and spells, it becomes less of a problem; there are still some weird things about this system, like you fight an attack dog and it has physical armor for no reason (I mean, I understand when a human enemy has physical armor because he has a breastplate, but a naked dog?) - you have to spend skill points on Memory, which increases your skill slots; I didn't like this at first, because I'd want to spend my points on other attributes; however, it isn't as bad, as you receive free Memory slots when leveling up at certain levels - Source Points; I still don't like this mechanic as some of the best abilities are now locked behind the need of source; these good abilities already had the disadvantage of using more than 1 Memory Slot, but you also need Source to cast them; of course, you can steal source from enemies or corpses, but enemies can also steal you source - a bit of spoiler ahead: the companions that are not in your party at the end of the first area will die, so you cannot see their storyline for the remainder of that playthrough; in my opinion, this is horrible game design, but I guess it helps with replayability - your party members can leave you permanently late in the game, depending on dialog choices, even though you had a good relationship with them (high attitude) until then; I was shocked when this happened, because I don't understand what the point of companion attitude is - new game modes: PvP and Game Master; I haven't tried these yet, so I don't know if they're good, but they're there - it also comes with a free Map Editor  The badThe game also has some bad parts, of course: - I didn't play it when it launched because I was sure there were going to be bugs. I've waited for a week or two and a few patches and played it without major technical issues (though I did have a 100% crash in an area that had a lot of lava around, but lowering the graphical settings resolved that). - on the gameplay side, as many have pointed out, the last part (Arx) isn't as good as the rest of the game, but it's not really that bad. There are some weird fights with respawning enemies in a certain embassy, but those can be avoided by sneaking. P.S.: When writing this review, I'm just before the last fight, so I'm not sure what that's like.  The uglyRed Prince and the lizard kin. They're ugly AF.  VerdictThis is a must buy for any gamer who likes party-based RPGs.

This is an absolute gem. It is absolutely incredible. The graphics, the story, the gameplay, the comedy, you name it. I typically find top down cRPGs rather boring but this is definitely one of the top 10 games I have ever played. Time will tell where it lands but it is incredibly good.  There are plenty of full reviews out there so read those if you want a general review. Here is what I specifically like about it: Larian loves its players and it shows.  They really do. In DOS2, you can customize this game to make it the game you want to play. For example, I am not a hardcore CRPG guy. I like a more casual experience and I also want to play this with my partner, preferably without having to cash out for a second copy. While that might be difficult for most games in the genre, DOS2 lets us set the difficult to Explorer (which feels perfectly balanced for us) and play coop in split screen. It also allowed us to redo our builds after the first act so that any mistakes made could be adjusted without having to start over again. It also autosaves plenty, so we could easily recover from any mistake.  I could easily see how I could play DOS2 by myself and love that too. Or to play it with 3 friends who really love hardcore games. In fact, this is the closest any videogame has ever come to being a tabletop pen and paper roleplaying game IMHO.  Can't wait for DOS3.

What a brilliant game.  I am not a great fan of turn-based RPGs (or at least wasn't till now) but D:OS2 really changed that. The combat system is simply epic, both in terms of visuals and dynamics. It is so much fun to fight with strategies and due to the well-balanced difficulties, most of the fights are very exciting.  Exploring is also incredibly fun. The game has maps of decent sizes but more importantly, each act is generously full of well-scripted contents. You never know what you will find but you always know you will find something that makes your exploration valuable!  The story is quite compelling. Side stories, however, are often even more compelling. Additionally, all characters you meet have a personality that speaks to you on a human level. The attention to details for creating such a lively world should really be appreciated. Even animals have individually established personalities that make meeting them much more fun. Similarly, the dialogues are of the same quality. Very good voice acting and very well written lines.  The open-world aspect is, again, very good. The number of options you have through the gameplay is vast and unlike most other open-world games, your choices actually matter. Abundance of options applies not only to your choices of progressing through the storyline but to each part of the game. Almost everything expects some decision from you.    Graphics are very stylish and they look really good. Just by looking at the screenshots you can tell that this is a game with a fantastic world that will immerse you 100%.   The price is completely worth is without a doubt. You can easily expect 100-110 hours of gameplay from D:OS2.  In my opinion, if you like the genre of RPG at all, don't even hesitate to buy this game. This is a RPG masterpiece.

Early Access Review:   Original Sin 2 is what exactly what every RPG gamer has been looking for - there's a potency to its' immersion that every EA title should aim to hit. This is the caliber of gaming you (EA devs) should truly attempt to employ!!!! It's an absolute masterpiece of Early Access gaming. A true game of D&D mixed with chess.......Larian said they posted this game on steam with a laugh, and I know why!! Ok I'll stop with the hype and explain.   (Graphics, optimization, controls, gameplay, sound.)   Graphics/Animations: 10/10  Right from the jump you notice how polished the world and characters look. From beautiful landscapes to fluid animations, I love it!!!! Nothing left to say here! Excellent job!   Optimization: 10/10  No loading screens.. LIKE EVER during your gaming experience! Excellent work!   Controls: 9/10  No complaints other than the restriction of your camera angles. Part of the experience is viewing a gorgeous and artistic world... You can never look at the sky....and view your character from better angles.. sad. Although, you can rebind your keys, you can rotate and zoom in - You feel like you're in control. Great job!   Gameplay: 9.5/10  This is where the bulk of the game lies. From story to combat - the immersion starts with the world appearance and story narrative, then ends with a blast with its' combat delivery. The combat is spaced out making you feel like you're not always in a chat box, and you'll be satisfied in casting, buffing or even simple melee attacks.  You can be whatever you want to be. Unless you want to be an orc...you can't be an orc - BUT what you can do from what they have to offer makes you feel like you're totally in control of your character's person.   Yes, customization is quite limited. I like my rpgs to let me customize my character to the "T" ... and this does limit you in that aspect to a certain extent...better than most games but coming from MMOs you may be disappointed. Given a more customizable character and maybe even adding a few other races .. you'll never play the same character again. Character creation is key in this type of genre - still ... Excellent work!   Music/Sound: 9.5/10  The sound and music is fantastic! ... I'd still love to hear a larger variety of music during gameplay...This will probably end up being a 10 simply because they will add voice acting and more music throughout the future acts. Excellent job!   Overall: 10/10  The story, the adventure, the combat, the scenery, the ..... oh you get it already!!!! What a phenomonal game. RPG lovers, MMO lovers...hack'n'slash lovers... VIDEO GAME LOVERS! You'll love this. I wouldn't post my first review on steam if I didn't believe this to be a game for everyone on steam. Do enjoy! Thanks Larian!

One of the best games I have ever played.  Several bugs and lack of features make it fall just short of that #1 however.  My main concerns are in multiplayer. You have to play as the hosts party characters and not your own. That means playing an archer with a level 2 bow, all stats in wits and other useless talents. There is also an endless amount of bugs with multiplayer. For example, if I am host and start a multiplayer and someone joins me as say The Red Prince and I save, restart whatever, that character then becomes bugged. Instead of reverting back to The Red Prince after that player leaves, he bears that persons name and is unable to be reset, or even dismissed. You normally can talk to npc's in your party and say you want to go your seperate ways and recruit another party member, nope. bugged.  Another example is I use one of my npc's for dialect options since they have persuasion stats and my main is undead. Someone joined the game and took control of MY character and when I leveled up he butchered his stats and skills and those remained on my character after I kicked him and / or restarted the game.  These things make multiplayer extremely frustrating and have forced me to start brand new games probably about 6 times now. I haven't even been able to get through act 1. I am very wary to play in multiplayer due to all these reasons and despite preferring multiplayer in it's theory am forced to play single player to avoid game breaking bugs like those i mentioned. I wish I could provide some feedback or get some kind of bug fix on this bug I don't see an option for that. Thankfully the developer is very involved in the game and will probably fix this at some point. I am now hoping that a user created mod will fix many of these issues in the future (thank god this game has mods)  Despite all my frustrations this game is absolutely incredible in every other aspect. Everything is voiced, every npc which is amazing. Graphics are good (not great) especially for this type of game. Quests are actually fun and not all fetch they actually have lore. There is an absolute freedom: you can kill every npc and still proceed with the game. The gameplay is some of the best ever. This genre has been ruined in the past decade with games like the Final Fantasy series dropping the traditional turn-based combat for an active combat. Yeah, thats nice in some circumstances but it is extremely boring hacking and slashing repetitively just like every other game. The combat in D:OS2 is calculated, and detailed. Everything is listed and heavily focused on strategy and statuses. The game encourages using environments such as high ground and environmentals like barrels and puddles in order to gain favor in battle.   The best part of the game is the fact it's challenging. The default difficulty will probably be too hard for average gamers and those not familiar with the genre or the first game. There are two higher difficulties on top of that which are extremely challenging (I normally play on the highest difficulty in every other game) The next best thing would be that the developers aren't EA, Ubisoft, Activision, etc and force paywalls on an incomplete game and don't support the game after launch. This dev actually cares and I have personally downloaded atleast one patch per day and they have already stated that they are going to implement being able to use your own character in multiplayer which is something I look forward to. Can't wait to see what's next for this game.

THE STORY: This is by far the most densely rich lore I’ve played through from any game I’ve played, where almost everyone and everything is connected in one way or another. Creating a living and breathing world, where one’s actions and decisions will affect their adventures through Rivellon. The part where this game shines the most, is how it gives the player choices on how they want to advance the story in any way the player chooses to play. Choose to be good, evil, just or whatever mood you choose, this game adapts to it and guides you to the end that your choices led to. While I’ve only completed Fane’s Story (in the moment of writing this), the endings it gives you will satisfy however you played. While you can choose how your adventure ends, the game lets you know how those actions will affect Rivellon in the future. The reason why I love this story is how grim and real this story plays out, no one is truly good or evil, it’s all a grey area, but it’s your choice on how you want to navigate in it.  THE COMBAT: There was never a dull moment every time I went into battle, or stumble on to one. While combat is turn-based, pre-battle is when things become interesting. Some approaches I found to be more fun is laying out traps and pre-emptive attacks on unknowing enemies. I can go into combat with my enemies clinging on 5% health and wipe them out with one attack. This is true liberty that this game gives to players, it gives you the tools and it’s up to you on how to use them. And this is just combat, skills can give a creative twist to combat. You can chain attacks to deliver devastating blows to your enemies or toy around with them by unleashing various Statues Effects and skills that can either immobilize them or transform them into chickens. All this creates a simple yet complex toy box you can play with. Finding out what seems fun and effective will make you want to seek out the next battle and unleash your battle plan.  THE MUSIC: I do not, in any way, have any complaints or criticisms about the music. The only thing I can say is that it is Divine. The music makes Rivellon and in turn makes you believe that it is a real place and these characters who live in it are part of a giant play. The 4 instruments that you can pick (while you build your character) creates the mood in how you want to play and you can change it any time you want.  This is the best RPG for this generation. While there are quite a few bugs the developer needs to fix, this doesn’t affect how much I love this game.

A wonderful game with a great (if flawed) combat system, fun characters, an interesting world with deep lore and most importantly it has a full co-op story experience. You'll want to replay this game with new character ideas or to test your knowledge of the game in tactican or honour mode. But if I thought DOS1 was brilliant and needed changes, then I must admit I feel the same way about DOS2. My main issue being that the combat system filters you to certain ways of playing which DOS1 did too but DOS2 does in different ways. Party of 4? Stick to either physical or magical damage focus for all, as mixing stats makes both weak or one side essentially useless (but doable on explorer mode). Party of 1 or 2? Hit that Lone Wolf talent on character creation and you'll have the most fun the game can give. To an extent you can mix damage skills quite well and not have a bad character.   With that said, you'll have many hours of fun making characters that work and even those that don't (which you can thankfully fix after act 1).

Divinity: Original Sin 2 reawakened sensations I haven't felt in many years. This is definetly one of the better games I have played in a long time. If I am being fairly honest, I did find the combinations of genres a tad bit peculiar, I do however enjoy the core genres a lot seperatly (RPG, Turn-Based Strategy, Story Rich, Character Customization), so I decided to give it a shot anyways. I was a bit reluctant to pay +45$ for it, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥am I glad I did. I do have a few Issues with the game, but they are heavily outweighed by the positive aspects (+ for positives, - for negatives).   + Fantastic setting  Now I have no prior experiences with the early/earlier title(s), but the game did a splendid job of introducing me to all the different kinds of political strife, discrimination predujice, as well as the fanatical religious zealots. I quickly became aware of the kind of world my character was living in, so I could more easily integrate the character I wanted to play.   + Beautiful landscapes  The maps are by no means short of details, with the next accessible area being even more astonishing than the first. I can't even fathom how many hours went into designing these places.   + Intriguing story	 I will make this one brief & completely spoiler free. The story is absoloutely captivating in almost every aspect.   + Loveable cast of characters  All of your potential followers (with the exception of Mercenaries), all have their own unique storylines, and backgrounds, with your game experience changing depending on who you choose to bring with you along for the ride. Personally I was especially intrigued by characters such as Lohse & Sebille, but should you decide to try out the game for yourself, you might yourself intrigued by other characters.   + Side activities, rewards & exploration   The game does a great job of keeping you busy, there is never a lack of stuff to do. Honestly 50% of the time you will probably have +10 unfinished quests in your journal. The game also does an even better job of making sure you are properly rewarded, and that also accounts for exploration. Matter or fact the game almost encourages you to explore & do side quests, because the game gets exceedingly hard if you don't make sure to gain a few levels.   + Regretting class choice? No problem homie.  Did you initially choose a stealthy assassin, but you'd actually rather play as a blazing pyromancer? Not a problem the game has got your back. After the 1st Act you are able to change reallocate your stat points, afterwards just get some new suitable equipment and you are good to go.  Now I could go on and on, about what I love about this game, but I also want to get into some of the few issues I have with the game.   - Normal difficulty is too hard at first (for newcommers).  Now I am by no means a hardcore gamer, like I previously was (I am more of a casual these days), but I personally found the earliest stages of the game too tedious to play through on the normal difficulty, and I ended up getting a bit stuck at one point, so I had to lower the difficulty until I could establish a solid foothold. However once I did get a foothold, I went back to the normal difficulty, to find it to be perfectly suitable, but an interresting challenge.   Tag values.  (For the unintiated "tags" are basically character descriptions. E.g. you choose wether your character was an established educated noble, or a battleready savage) Now no playthrough should ever be the same, which is why I can accept some missions only being accessible with certain followers. What I cannot accept is some character tags granting access to certain quests, while others are pretty useless apart from a few entertaining dialouges. For instance, during Act 2, you will be barred from certain quests if you don't have the scholar tag, whereas (from my own experience at least), the Barbarian tag only allows for some savage remarks. It does slightly ruin the RPG element of the game. And I honestly don't want to be forced to pick the scholar tag to get the most enjoyable experience with the game. I don't know about you, but I don't want my bearded-battlescarred-battleaxe wielding-viking warrior to be a bloody bookworm.   What to do next?   This is likely my biggest issue with the game.. I have 1 sentence to describe this in better words..  Thank ♥♥♥♥ for online guides!..	 I would really be at a terrible loss without them. The game does a mediocre (at best) job of telling you where to go next. For instance I often found myself struggling to get through opponents 2 levels higher than me (mostly in act 2), because the game did not inform me of the best area to go to in order to level up. I initially did learn to save often so if I found myself in an unwinable battle I could always retreat, explore elsewhere (hopefully the right places), get some levels and return later. Although it was very frustrating at first. Another point I want to make is that the player journal feels incredibly clumsy to look at, so I did often find myself unsure of the next approach to take on certain quests in order to proceed, so I had to look up guides so I could figure out what to do, (the game can feel like a bit of a puzzle once in a while).   = Multiplayer experience	 Can't really comment since none of my homies, play this game (And I have no real interrest in playing it with strangers), but I have only heard great things about it.   Rating	 Despite the issues I have with the game, none of them are actually gamebreaking, and are pretty much easily fixable, and their are - as I said earlier - heavily outweighed by the positive aspects of the game. All in all it is definetly worth your hard-earned money. I will rate this game a staggering = 9/10  (Also I do apoligise for any grammatical errors).

With so many ways to play and succeed, DOS2 rekindles that old feeling of D&D the way many have wanted for a long time. If you're used to a game that holds your hand, you might find yourself confused or lost, as there's minimal help in the game. But if you want adventure, strategy and tactical gameplay, you may have found your time-killer. Well worth the money.  THE GOOD - The story is well-fleshed out and full of characters you'll see (or not see, if they die) again at some point. - Combat is tactical, complex, and sometimes downright difficult, even on the easiest setting. Sometimes it felt like sitting at a table of miniatures and contemplating the next move like a game of chess.  The AI is quite good, and the enemy may stay just out of range and teleport your characters into lava. - Characters are almost completely customizable at a certain point, so if you don't like something, feel free to swap it out when you want. - Audio is rather engaging. - The game easily remembers things you've done and never turns out the same way twice. - Carry weight feels limitless, so you won't have to worry about over-encumbrance bothering your honest gameplay. - Vendors have good gear almost all the time, refreshing frequently, though almost anyone can be traded with.  THE BAD - Inability to go back to previous zones for exploration or completion of side quests with no relation to the main story. This can lead to forgetting a map you just got used to, and having to learn a whole new one. - For some players, explorer mode may in fact be too difficult at some points, and you may feel boxed in, unable to explore or retreat. - Occasionally, controls regarding moving characters or unchaining them momentarily feels hamfisted. Taking extra steps to just make one character go somewhere is awkward. - There's almost never a time when you're not standing on a corrupt surface in combat, which requires extra effort to clean, extra effort you likely can't put in on time to change it. This means a large portion of your combat time will be spent dealing with endless DOTs and also an inability to heal your characters. - Pet Pal is an almost essential talent to have for one character, wasting some more valuable talent space for the ability to talk to rats.  THE UGLY - Crafting feels like an incomplete feature. Recipes are learned via experimentation or finding it in a book somewhere, but there are many times when you simply would have no clue how to craft things, and don't need to because vendors have what you need. Would you have thought you could make lockpicks by combining a hammer and nails? Never did discover how to make trap disarming kits.  SUMMARY Definitely a great game. Buy it and enjoy it, over and over again.

TL;DR Buy this game! Best RPG game I've ever played and in my top 3 games of all time without a doubt. There are hundreds of hours of gameplay here. The gameplay is quality unlike games like Skyrim which pretty much relies on mods to be fun for extended play sessions, which this game also offers. Dialog and story is also some of the best you'll find in recent games with  every piece of dialog being voiced which is just a great thing for an Indie game to do.  Seriously 9.9/10 game.  This is honestly the best RPG I have ever played and one of the best games I've played in general. This is one of the few single-player games that I just can't stop playing.   Before I played this game me and my friends played a lot of D&D, but we couldn't find enough time to play as much as we'd like since we were in our final year of school. So for ages I looked for a game that could emulate that same expirence. Being able to do what I want, having funny moments as well as epic. When one of my friends showed me this I was hooked.   The mechanics are almost the exact same as old school table top games, so iif you're into that turn based combat you'll love this, but even someone like me that normally hates those kind of combat mechanics in games I just loved these just because of how polished they were. The combat suprisingly has a lot of depth to it. There's so many different spells and equipment and many of them interact with eachother in their own ways.  The story and dialog is also one of the best I've ever seen in a game. Most of the dialog has so much character and is of such high quality, only of the voices feel as they were acted poorly, but 10000x better than you'll see in any Bethesda game. The fact that all of the dialog in the game is voice acted is also just an amaznig thing. It makes it feel as you're living in a real world and it also helps with the consistancy where some lines would be voiced and some wouldn't. This wouldn't mean anything iff the story wasn't good, which thankfully it isn't. The story is so good. It pulls you emotionally in so many different directions and you have to make so many decisions that make or break relationships and have an effect on what happens for the rest of the game.  Character creation is also pretty good, different races and classes having different traits and abilities as per usual. This part is the only part that I find to be pretty hard on new characters since some races and classes are harder to play than others, which can make it difficult and punishing. This can become a non-issue early in the game since you have the choice to pretty much change everything about you if you're not happy about it.  The one thing that I wish could be different about the game is its modding cababilities. Sadly as of now there aren't any mods anywhere near as big as mods that you find in Bethesda games, but thankfully this isn't a Bethesda game so you don't need mods to make it interesting lmao. This game does have the ability to act as your own Dungeon Master and make a whole game for you, your friends and your fellow steam gamers. and you also have the ability to download other peoples campains which just extends the hundreds of hours in the base game.  This game is almost a perfect example of what a game should be. For the gamer by not constantly trying to ram microtransactions down every hole in your body, have hundreds of high quality content from launch. Constant interaction with the community, THESE GUYS MAKE VLOGS MAN!!! and last but not least they don't do what every triple-a developer is doing now and making all their content and just releasing it as expansions. These guys are just about to release a FREE expansion that adds hundreds of more hours of gameplay which I would be more than happy to pay for since it is actually worth it and it's made to add value to the game instead of be a stupid cash grab.     SO IN SUMMARY. Buy this game, its amazing how an indie studio made on of the best games of recent times from a kickstarter with a reasonably small studio compared to multi-billion dollar companies that make subpar games at best. These people really care about what they create and it shows in their final product. I recommend this game to everyone and I feel like a better person everytime I do so.

AHHHHHHHHH where to start. This game Has NON of the thankfully also you can get a quest from animals these Devs were on like weed or something when making this game because some of the quests are AMAZING there was one where I had to kill a chicken. Conclusion - This game is a must buy for D&D players strategy players and also starters it is well optimized and loading is like zipping fast but in some areas, they do throw a lot at you so be wary of that, and if the game is on sale it's even MORE worth it. Pros:One of the best co-op experiences I've ever played. Assuming you're playing with a patient, like-minded group. Amazing story. Well crafted characters. Decisions feel like they actually have weight. The story and characters have just the right amount of silly. It is both serious and fun at the same time. Revamped combat. I love the new physical/magic armor system. Status effects aren't as overpowered as they were in the first game (They're still insanely good.) AI. It's brutally efficient. Most of the time. Beautiful graphics engine, with all the expected graphical options. I believe all the dialog has a voice over, and the acting is excellent. The animals with human voices are especially hilarious. (Using the Pet Pal talent.) Reasonably priced at $45. No Loot Boxes/Season Passes/Micro-Transactions. If they put out and old-school style expansion pack I'd buy it in a heartbeat. Origin characters are a great addition over the first game. It adds a ton of replayability. GM Mode is amazing. You could run a full D&D campaign over the internet with your friends using this tool. Dev team is still very active in fixing bugs. An instant classic, right up there with Baldur's Gate. Steam Workshop supports adds a ton of content to the game. Neutral:Running the game two player with the Lone Wolf talent is super unbalanced. I'm kind of enjoying it though. Above level 5 or 6 Lone Wolf makes tactician mode feel like normal mode. That being said the very beginning of the game on tactician is really rough with only two people. The game is still kind of linear, but nowhere near as bad as the first game. Cons:If you're playing this game as a four person group, progressing through the storyline can sometimes feel like herding cats. Scholar tag seems overly important. Make sure you have at least one character in your party with it. There are several quests that require you to have it in order to finish. Armor scaling gets out of hand past the early teen levels. Picked up items being automatically added to your hotbars. Polymorph skills that add additional skills automatically added to hotbars. Can't fix this without using a mod, and I don't want to disable my achievements.  Computer Specs: Intel i7 5930k (O.C. 4 GHz), EVGA GTX 1080ti FE (O.C. 2,000~ MHz), LG 34UM95 (3440x1440, 60hz), 500GB Samsung 850 Pro SSD.

Never played the first, but I've been loving everything about this so far. I've always enjoyed the style of game that feels pseudo pen-and-paper D&D (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Neverwinter Nights, etc.). But with those, and even D&D itself, I have a similar gripe with special moves and spells, which tend to work on a very limited, "x uses per day" system. Divinity 2 has a similar feel to those kinds of games, but most abilities and spells have a turn cooldown.  Also, where the default in those other games mentioned was real-time with options to pause on triggers, or to manually pause and unpause, combat in this is solely turn-based. Battles tend to feel a lot more strategic as a result. Also a bit chaotic, as elemental effects get thrown across the field all the time. The important thing to note is that all of your characters are likely to get set on fire or be poisoned in most battles. It's inevitable.  I haven't played multiplayer, but it's been great playing single player because of the character stories. A full party of 4, and I'm really wanting to know more about all the pre-made characters. While you can make a fully custom character, I recommend playing the first time with one of the characters that has a backstory. It's really adding to the lore to have a character with a much more fleshed out backstory than I'm used to seeing in these kinds of games, and it's been adding another layer of fun to not just roleplay, but try to roleplay my character (in dialog, you'll get prompts for why a certain option is choosable, and you'll sometimes have your character's name next to an option to show it's choosable because of their backstory, which I don't think you'd get if you made a fully custom character).  If you've enjoyed other cRPGs then all I can say is two thumbs up -- would recommend.

It's a long game, but a good game. II just finished my first playthrough at 110 hours. I didn't complete EVERY quest but I did come to some sort of resolution for most of them. Divinity Original Sin 2 is a rich and beautiful world to explore with an explosive and exciting turn based combat system. The game has a very intersting story that is 99% voiced which goes a long way in immersing you into this world. I never knew that I needed games like this to be voiced and to have a narrator. Take note Pillars of Eternity 2. It gives you this sense of going on a real Dungeons and Dragons style adventure. It conjures up feelings of Baulder's Gate 2 while being very modern and engaging. This is the divinitive CRPG experience in gaming today. I firmly believe it will be a classic like the CRPGs of old.   The game isn't without it's flaws though. Firstly the last two acts slog a bit. There are still tons of interesting things that happen and a few jaw-dropping moments, but some parts I struggled to boot my PC up and play the game. This comes right into the second flaw, the game is a little too long. You definitely get your money's worth. This game would give you good value per dollar even if it cost $100, and it only cost $45 US. It's a freaking steal. However, when it takes 100+ hours to beat a game while seeing most of it's content sometimes you just burn out a bit. Finally there are some flaws with the actual gameplay a few times. Some of the puzzles are unecessarily difficult, sometimes it feels like the enemy gets 10 turns for every 1 turn you get, and it has performance issues in a few spots.   However, overall this game is the best game of 2017. It's an absolute steal at $45 and the game tells you a story you won't soon forget. Easy reccomendation to anyone even slightly interested in CRPGs.

First I want to talk about the character creation, I found it a bit annoying to navigate and felt it would have been much better if everything was on one screen instead of multiple screens, Fallout 2 did this well, you can increase your main attributes and pick and choose skills/traits, all on one screen. The creation itself is pretty standard, pick your preset "class" although you can choose which abilities you want to start with, your preset will determine the pool of abilities you get, if you choose a rogue you get rogue abilities, if you choose a summoner, you get summoner abilities. The talents in this game are absolutely terrible, there are 1-2 amazing ones, 3-4 decent ones and the rest are pretty crappy and not worth picking up. Stuff like hothead, which gives you 10% accuracy and 10% critical chance, this is pretty insignificant but you know whatever its decent I guess but oh wait it is only at full health, and if you don't know, this game's combat is pretty much all about having poison and fire and all kinds of stuff happening on the battlefield, your characters will almost definitely be on fire or poisoned, it is pretty much impossible to avoid it from happening, and while your healer(s) will probably be able to keep you topped up, it just seems not worth the effort for such a small buff.  I now want to start talking about how fun the combat is, I started as a rogue and it was pretty boring to start with but as I progressed and my party progressed I was able to cast tons of different abilities and spells to change the battlefield to something that is advantageous to me. For example, I started as an undead, and being a rogue I just blinked on-top of the enemy and dropped poison at my feet, this allowed me to gain a small amount of healing and also damage the enemy, but that is just a very small advantage. You can mix elements to totally screw with your enemies, you can drop some rain down (this makes them wet) and then just use an aoe chill spell and this will freeze everybody and they will be helpless for a turn, allowing you to bash their heads in. And later on you gain the ability to change these elements even more, but that is somewhat spoilerific so I will refrain from going into details on that. Not only is it really fun strategizing how you are going to fight in battles, but every spell looks amazing and the game in general looks spectacular.  The quests in this game are excellent, there are no generic "kill 20 goblins and bring me their toenails" quests which makes you look forward to the next quest you will run into, everything is voiced, which you wouldn't really expect from a game that has so many different outcomes in dialogue in and out of quests. The voice acting is very good I would say, besides the NPC dialogue you will regularly hear the narrator talk, and he has a very good voice, they did a good job of making you feel like you were in the moment experiencing everything, the great descriptive writing allows you to close your eyes and picture whatever the narrator is talking about. Something I quite like is how your character creation changes NPC dialgoue, most NPC's will reward you in some way for simply being their race, some characters are seemingly racist and despise elves or dwarves (these characters are usually not involved in quests so you don't miss out on anything). There are also some NPC's that reward you in some way for having certain Character Tags, a soldier will relate to another soldier which increases relation with them, this gives a discount when trading with them which helps a bit. The game really feels as though you would have had a completely different outcome in a quest for simply having changed 1 or 2 things in character creation. It makes you eager to finish the game and restart as a totally different character and hear all of the dialogue you totally missed the first time around.  That mostly concludes my thoughts on the game, just gonna put some arbitrary numbers here.  -Gameplay 4/5 The combat is extremely fun and challenging too albeit a tad annoying when you take on too many enemies and wonder why you are incapable of winning.  -Story/Quests 4/5 All of the quests I have done I enjoyed and I look forward to seeing how the story of my character progresses once I leave the Island.  -Graphics 4/5 Not absolutely mindblowing but definitely looks good.  Overall I would say the game is very good, one of the best RPG's I have played in my life and I haven't even beaten it yet. I look forward to the rest of the game, I put 30 hours into just the first zone of the game, so I hope the rest of the game has the same amount of content and I will easily see 200 hours worth of content in this game depending on how thoroughly you play through each quest and explore everything.

Amazing and very promising game. As it prequel, Divinity Original Sin 1, it is an awesome, interesting and funny game.   I really liked that they had different options for player who prefers the story over the combat or vice versa. I personally prefer the rol part over the combat, so this was a welcomed surprise for me. The combat system, turn based, is in my opinion a smart choice they made. A refreshing touch after all the more 'action' based RPGS, like Skyrim. You can really plan a strategy and take your time to give orders to your characters. Or you can ignore combat and focus on the story. I loved the graphics the locations are beautiful, and I really enjoyed that they were not the typical ‘European medieval forest’ type but rather deserts or tropical islands. I loved that this time we were able to play as different species (I played as the Red Prince) and specially that you could chose a premade character or a new one (with any option for species/sex/race etc). I really liked that the ‘non chosen characters’ end up being your companions. It is something that I always wanted from the first Dragon Age. Every character had a very specific personality and very interesting backstories, the same as a very funny banter.  I would only complain about the lack of lore connecting this game with the others in the Divinity Series. I found it a little bit confusing, specially regarding the first Divine divinity. I would only complain about many parts of the game still being bug (like many quests and some characters like Fane). This was disappointing but I hope that will improve with further patches.  In my opinion it is one of the most addictive and fun games that I played lately.

Everything that made the first game amazing, with the fat cut and a ton of new stuff. I loved the story, the detailed graphics, the wonderful voice acting, the music that has only improved from the incredible soudtracks of the other Divinity games, the new gameplay mechanics and skills, and just about everything. The annoying "skill tier" system of the last game has been greatly downplayed by the memory stat, meaning the only limit to what skills you can use are slots to equip them in. The combat has been improved by enemies who teleport themselves and you, inflict status effects, and generally act a lot smarter than the last game. I found the tactic of "start a big fire and teleport anyone who tries to escape back into the fire" that made short work of most enemies in the last game uneffective here, and that made combat more dynamic. Everyone now has physical and magical defense which guard against not only health loss but status effects, so it may become necessary to recover someones magic armor if you know the enemy might charm you. There are dozen of examples like this. There are plenty of standard skills like fire, warrior, necromancy etc but the one that really stood out to me was polymorph. Spread wings and fly around the battlefield or turn enemies into helpless chickens or grow bull horns and charge enemies from great distance. There are so many great skill combos and plenty of tricky enemies to use them on. I honestly believe this game will go down as one of the greatest RPGs of all time along greats like Deus Ex and Baldur's Gate. It offers the same level of freedom in quest design, combat, and story that all the greats do. I have heard a lot of games like Mario Kart referred to as "friendship ruiners" and this game is the exact opposite. Its fun solo sure but if you have a nerdy friend or spouse or whoever, this game will be a great bonding excercise. It supports controllers in a smooth satisfying way for such a complex game. I look forward to another chapter of this fantastic series and an eventual console port so I can buy and enjoy this masterpiece all over again

I highly recommend this game! I have almost 100 hours into this game and they've been a GOOD 100 hours. The most surprising part of this game is that the story is good. You have to make serious decisions that can have lasting ramifications on the game. The story is great, but the game play is also great. Mind you, it's pretty hard. Just when you feel like you're doing really well, the enemies ramp up and get harder. So this is a pretty challenging game, but it's also very satisfying.  I really enjoy the different builds and the ability to reset your character. That means that if you get bored with a play style or run into a really difficult section, you can respec. As soon as I beat it, I will likely play through it again as a lone wolf.   There were a few bugs that I ran into, but reloading and doing something else first would fix it. For example, if interacting with a certain object causes the game to crash, travel to another area, do some trading, then come back. Or use a different character.   I have only two major complaints. The first is inventory management. Moving things around is tedious. I like having the Wares system, which is where you can move an item into this category called "Wares", then sell all your wares at once to a vendor. Saves time with the vendor, but not placing them into wares. I also had my strength hero be the pack mule. So I'd have to move the item to the Red Prince, then right click and move to wares. Tedious, but manageable.   The second complaint is the persuasion system. It seemed like I failed literally every persuasion attempt for the first half of the game. I gave up on making it work. See, I would see an Intelligence-based persuasion attempt and would say, "Ok, I'll use my dude who has maxed intelligence." FAIL. What the heck?! Turns out that not only do you need high intelligence, you need high persuasion, which is a stat you can level up. Later, when I had more points to spare, I maxed out persuasion on two characters, one finesse based, one int based. That way, I always have someone who can win that persuasion. It was minor and I was able to live with failing literally every persuasion attempt.   Anyway, I give this game a 9/10. The only reason I don't give it a 10/10 is because my summoner can't have more than one summon out at a time! I want to summon my spirit wolf, summon my incarnate, and summon a bone widow from my summoner main! But alas, you can only have one summon out at a time.   BUY THIS GAME

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a masterpiece cRPG. It's got an awesome balance between fun, roleplaying, exploration, tactical combat and nice stories. Its got an enormous amount of choices to make in both playstyle and solving puzzles. Those puzzles, as well as combat can sometimes be unforgivingly hard though, so prepare to quicksave often.

This game can only be decscribed as a labor of love, and Larian Studios should be praised for what they have accomplished. In many ways this game is the gold standard for what a sequel should look like. The combat is exceptional, it lets you approach a combat situation from multiple angles, environmental interaction is wide and vary, and percise usage of skills is critical to controlling the battlefield. The story is entertaining, and every side mission you happend upon is either hilarious or contributes to the lore of the world  with great voice acting for every major/minor NPC (even the animals are voiced and some will even give you questlines). Finally the environment of the game itself is gorgeous, ad the amount of detail that the developers have put into this game only gives it a more immersive feel as you explore the game. It is a must have, and is a golden example of what we should expect from game developers from any genre/franchise.

Divinity Original Sin 2 was the first game of the Divine games that I had tried / pickup and really enjoyed myself when getting through the game and making progress with my original party. From my personal experience, DOS 2 offers unique ways to solve different quests while also being punishing if you screw it up and not letting you get a retry button (unless you reload a save). From the character selection to the origin characters, divinity has a very vast variety of options to choose for your characters skills, do you want to be a tanky mage? or how about being an rogue who can polymorph enemies into chickens. When you get into the game after making a custom character or choosing one of the six origin characters, you are able to pick up to three other origin characters to recruit into your party and journey along together till you reach your end goal. What sets this game differently from an RPG like skyrim or fallout is that you actually get to do side quest for your companions and are able to learn more about him or her through dialog, not having bland reused dialog changing with the envoirment and how they see you as an ally or an enemy depending on if you're being rude to them. On top of all of that another part that I enjoy is that all most all dialog (except some that have been added recently to put players in the right direction and some that are just bugged) are 100% voice acted, from the Red Prince to a dog in Fort Joy each entity has its own character and appeal to them. One thing that makes divinity shine from most RPGs is that you can physically kill any NPC you want, from entire towns to some of Fort Joys residence (But killing origin characters will cause problems with the main story line so avoid doing so) allowing you to kill a trading that you might have a grudge over if you want some of their loot from their store. Finally the loot system is extravagant allowing you to have different loot while looting dungeons in different play throughs based on Lucky Charm and loot tables that were generated in the game, while also not completely dropping the NPC's inventory if killed making it more useful to pickpocket them for their better wears before killing. Overall I love DOS 2 as a game, it personally has to be one of my favorite games released this year, should you pay $45? Yes this game is worth every cent the COOP is amazing and the story and side quest will have your save be longer than 40 hours or more depending on if you go into the nitty gritty.

The game starts a little rough/boring when you're on the ship (I did not like it at all), but after that short area the game slowly opens up and before you know it you have been absorbed into it. The attention to detail (all animals are voiced but you only talk to them if you spend a point on the required ability), the flexibility that your abilities come with opens up many options for battles and exploration that is mostly limited by your imagination, and the little hand holding when it comes to exploration (you must talk and explore around instead of waiting for ! marks and waypoints) allows for a greater immersion. I got this game not expecting much outside of a regular RPG, but what I got was an old school DnD-esque game with a lot of depth and ♥♥♥♥ me if that's not something that we haven't seen in ages. If you liked games like Baldurs Gate and the more recent Pillars of Eternity then this game will grab a hold of you and never let you go.

Kickstarter backer, played about an hour or three of early access.  A couple hours into this game and I findi it to be an improvement in pretty much every regard. Most specifically, in the writing and the tone. Original Sin's writing was well-executed, but the game felt like a slapstick cartoon far too often for my tastes. A comedy game that I didn't find that funny wasn't what I was really looking for, and so I wound up losing interest in the first.  But this. Ye gods, this. Much improved.  Sure, talking to animals is still funny, but the game spends a hell of a lot less time laughing at people, and a lot more time being compelling. I'm invested in these characters, this world. I actually care what happens in Rivellon. The pregen/companion characters are lovely, the dialog keyword system is a blast, the (surprise) voice acting is *really good*, and the combat and gameplay seems to have evolved in some interesting ways.   I'll update this if relevant as I continue to play, but as of now? I'm estatic with this game.  Planning to try some co-op; I'll let you know how that goes if I do.

I'm just going to copy-paste my review of 1 here and amend the parts that have changed, overall this is basically the exact same game as the first with a different story.    This game varies wildly between really great and confusingly terrible.  Good:  -The combat is amazing and the ways you interact with the world are interesting and sometimes novel. -There are some pretty fun / interesting / unique puzzles. -The voice acting is pretty good. (except anything involving goblins, they obnoxiously hiss all their s's) There are few enough of them now that it isn't a problem.  Bad  -Inventory management is a nightmare. I'm pretty sure it was made to be as obtuse as possible, which is a problem when you're contantly getting buried under garbage you need to sift through. This has been improved, but it's still tedious.  -The puzzles that aren't good (most of them) are really awful. They are either ridiculously tedious or obtuse, or both. The devs apparently thought that searching rooms pixel by pixel to find tiny camouflaged buttons is fun gameplay. It is not fun gameplay. It happens all the goddamn time.  This is absolutely still the case, some of the puzzles are goddamn idiotic and will absolutely destroy your immersion and enjoyment. Pixel hunts are much less common at least.   -The difficulty curve is strange.  The first main zone (levels 3 through ~9) is far harder than the rest of the game, and is capped off by a boss that is frankly complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.   Difficulty curve is still real frontloaded, but the bigger problem is accidentally wandering into encounters that are 2 to 3 levels higher than the one you're supposed to go to because they were closer, and the game wasn't clear about the order you're expected to do things in.   - Every once in a while the game will just instantly kill you in a way you couldn't reasonably have expected. This isn't a huge problem since quicksaves are fast and easy but it's still frustrating.   This doesn't happen anymore as far as I can tell.   -So much running. So much of your time in this game will just be spent running through places you've already been.    The game has great combat but everything that isn't the combat tends to be tedious garbage or trying to figure out what the ♥♥♥♥ the game wants you to do because it never bothered to tell you.  Pretty mediocre on average but it does enough different and there are enough fun and unique moments that it's worth trying out. (It's long as hell though so set aside some time. One playthrough took me 55 hours.)

The game itself is great and a true continuation and development of all that was loved and praised about the first Original Sin; however, and it's a big however, the engine is buggy as hell.  There's an odd core usage issue which means that multi core cpus are not utilized and the game dumps everything onto a single core - notice the strange frame skip stutter when panning?  That's a core usage issue and nothing else.  It seems the devs either don't care to fix the issue or can't fix the issue, which means one has to set the processor affinity to a single core and then back to all cores in task manager every single time one plays the game.  Not cool.  So if they sort that out, it's a highly recommended game; if not, it's still recommended but be prepared to tune your system every playthrough.  Oh yes, also there are issues with overclocked CPUs and GPUs.  Come on Larian, get your technical issues as sorted out as you've gotten the combat in this game.

Let me start off by saying that I don't normally write reviews for games unless they are exceptional. This game lies in one of the few exceptions where I have to. At first, it seemed difficult for me as I never played the first Divinity and tried to learn my way around the game. Not that long after, I got familiar with the story and the lore. From someone who doesn't enjoy care about the plot of most RPG's or MMORPG's, this game somehow brought the story forward for me to be interested in. I personally built an attatchment to my character and my companions as we continued on this adventure through Divinity. It was an amazing experience and that was when I knew what a gem this game was.  Some of the elements that I found compelling about this game was:   The voice acting - The many actors who portrayed the characters in this game did not disappoint. At times, I was just shocked at the amount of emotion and passion placed into each line of dialogue. My personal favorite was the voice actor for Lohse, whom I felt went above and beyond what some would just skim past. Also a big round of applause to those actors who put themselves out there to voice each animal or dungeon rat that was available throughout the game.   The combat - The understanding of many tactical aspects of each combat situation made it harrowing for me, in a fun sort of way. It was fun to experiment different strategies to clear a particular room of enemies or be faced with decisions that could affect whether or not my party makes it out of combat alive. The high-ground/low-ground system made it particularly mindful to pay attention to your surroundings while the natural elemental occurences (such as oil, poison, fire, etc,) keep you on your toes.   The storytelling - As stated in the above paragraph, the story is phenomenal. I found myself always wondering what would happen next and how my actions would affect the world down the line. It was truly one of the times where I found myself relating to my character, as if I were them rather than me controlling them. I truly loved the way the world was set up and how mostly everything had some role to play either in the narrative of the story or just to contribute to the feel of the world.   The world - Speaking of the feel of the world, everything was how it should be to establish a world that felt dynamic and alive. NPC's truly made their experiences feel real with some having problems that seemed normal and how they were portrayed. I sometimes imagined the theoretical lives of these NPC's and treated them as if they were real people with their own past experiences. When a game can make you engrossed into their world, you know it is good.   Music - The music was excellent at many areas and shifts according to the environment that you were placed in. Dungeons or naturally spooky areas had a feeling of dread but the suspensful and harrowing music helped contribute to the feel of this.  The music that played during the ending fight actually had me tearing up as even though it was something that I heard so many times, knowing that this was final area made it truly special and evoked a lot of memories and emotions of the overall adventure   Overall, I had just finished my first campaign and am planning on finishing more as to learn more about the companions that I did not choose at first and to see all the possible routes that I can go through before I eventually clear up the game. The game's amazing and a big thanks for Larian Studios for putting out such a masterpiece. I can't wait for the Definitive Edition to come out but until then, there are many mods and more to keep you continuously entertained. 10/10

I don't ever do reviews normally because I always think, why the heck would anyone be interested in what you've got to say?! lol! But this is how strongly I feel about this game!   A bit about me ('cos hey this is what you came to read right?! Nah, I just thought if you're like me you might enjoy this game too) I'm a 37 yr old female gamer and I love games ranging from GTA:V, Mass Effect, Battlefield, CoD, The Elder Scrolls Online, Skyrim, Dishonoured, God of War, The Witcher 3, Final Fantasy to Stardew Valley, Command and Conquer, Tropico etc, as well as all the retro Nintendo classics on NES, SNES, N64 and Gamecube etc.  So I've got a pretty eclectic mix of games I like, and I'm definitely not a gaming pro, more a casual gamer who just happens to get absolutely addicted to great games!  I stumbled on this one day browsing my queue and I'm beyond happy I did.  I actually think the storyline's ten times better than Skyrim (and boy do I loooooove Skyrim!).  The graphics are stunning and the music is so on point it's unreal. I've sank over 130 hrs into DOS:2 and if I didn't work full-time for a living I'd have probably sank in triple that amount, this is how engaging I've found it so far!   From having played games like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and Neverwinter Nights back in the day, DOS:2 immediately caught my eye as I fancied a nostalgia trip.... but damn it was SO much more than that! The narration is brilliantly engaging, witty and fantastically acted, and the love that Larian have put into building their characters backstories is blindingly obvious and unparalleled.  There's so much depth in there and it's so well padded out that I honestly can't fault it in the slightest.  Larian just became one of my favourite studios and I wish I'd known about DOS:2 when they were securing funding over on Kickstarter, because hell yeah I would have backed them!  The only thing I struggled with to begin with was the difficulty, in that modern games tend to spoon feed us tidbits and tips on what we should be doing in a game, they're full of map-markers and quest highlights on the map etc. specifically guiding us to the people and places we need to see, the tasks we need to do.  DOS:2 on the other hand demands that you think on your feet and outside the box! Sure it has a journal function with your quests loosely written in (actually in a journal format though), but it's absolutely down to you to work out how to accomplish that quest and there's zero hand holding.  But to be honest with you, it's actually something I've come to love about this game, for once it's a game that actually really requires to start using your brain, otherwise you're going to miss key elements of a fantastic story.  Enough waffling from me, just do yourself a favour and if you love RPGs of any kind, buy this! - I'm over 130 hrs in and I'm on Act 4 already looking forward to my next play through!

Divinity Original Sin 2 is an isometric computer RPG in the tradition of old-school pen & paper RPGs (such as Dungeons & Dragons) brought to the digital age.  In DOS2, you'll take on the role of one of six characters (or create one of your own) to explore, interact with friends and foes through interesting dialogue options, and engage in tactical turn-based combat encounters.  Whether you build your own character or play through the story of one of the six Origin characters, you'll be able to fully customize your character by choosing skills, assigning attributes, and picking talents that all synergize to make interesting and unique builds that change your options for interacting with the environment, with NPCs, and in combat.  As you play, you'll recruit the aid of up to three other characters (chosen either from the remaining available Origin characters or hired from a mercenary captain), but be warned; while choosing to travel with fellow Origin characters will open up new and interesting storylines to explore, your goals will sometimes be at odds. Like your main character, you'll also be able to customize your companions, creating a party that can stand up to the challenges that await you.   Alternatively, play with up to three additional players, and explore Rivellon together in jolly cooperation.  Although DOS2 is not procedurally-generated, and encounters are placed and not random, the choices you make and actions you take have long-term consequences that can dramatically alter your play experience, but in a way that feels surprisingly natural - even intended!  DOS2 is complex, and what seems intimidating to start quickly becomes a deep and engaging experience that both challenges you mechanically and drives you on to experience more and more of the story it has to offer.
