One of the best RPGs I have ever played, Divinity: Original Sin 2 truly is a work of art. From character creation to waking up in the prologue, the player will experience a familiar and welcoming feeling similar to creating a character for a tabletop RPG. This is pen-and-paper put into video game form in the truest sense.   Character creation is simple, and handled rather well. Though there is a slight lack in customization where one must choose face x through y and skin color x through y. Although the amount of races to choose is actually impressive. Alternatively, rather than playing a custom character, the player can experience the story from the perspective of one of the six, well-written, story characters. The races are vast and different in their own right with Human, Lizard, Dwarf, Elf, and Undead to choose from. They each face their own difficulties but all have unique boons or bonuses. Each class is just a combination of skills, a preset of gear and skills to start the player off with as customization and 'build-your-own' is heavily emphasized soon after the prologue. The player even has a choice to select a pseudo-background for their customized character of anything between a noble, mystic or barbarian with plenty more to be earned through the Roleplay elements.  Combat is very in-depth and ties in well with character customization. Skill trees and the skills, themselves, interract with the world differently in, sometimes, unexpected ways. The way combat feels is amazing, satisfying as it is turn-based combat done well. Abilities and spells, positioning, and the wide range of items make it one of the best features in this game, though one that is difficult to master. Spells can set the ground ablaze, clouds of poison can be created, and a combination of thing A and thing B can create explosions, electrified hallways, and giant spiders made of bone. Feedback, something important for combat, feels good. Powerful spells feel powerful and two-handed weapons feel weighty and hit hard. An overall enjoyable experience.  For those less combat-savvy, there is always the option to talk yourself out of a situation. The Rp elements are some of the finest done that I have seen in recent years. Skyrim has nothing on this. Each conversation and attempt at persuasion can change the experience of playing through the game. Accidentally anger a skeleton? Talk her to death- Yes, that was a thing that happened. Got caught stealing? Convince them otherwise! Need help solving a theft? Talk to a rat! The conversations and interractions with NPCs around the world are some of the best I've ever seen. From sad tales of a family lost to the hilarity of a cow attempting to tell your future. Or, simply murder them all if you can. There is freedom here that is just waiting to be explored.  On top of all of this, however, is the fact that this game has a co-operative feature of up to four players. Each player can choose to create a customized character or take the role of one of the story characters. While it is set up for an enjoyable single-player game, the ability to enjoy the full game with friends or family is also very welcome. The party is able to split up completely and roam the world if desired. There are also ways to troll your friends by Dying poison red, and giving it to them as a gift. Or, of course, you can all become Heroes.  The storytelling in this game is deep and rich as is player choice and freedom. The combat system is well thought out and satisfying. Even the character creation, simple as it is, gives the player more freedom than in most games to change almost everything stat-wise. It is easy to see that this game is made with love, and the developers have shown it clearly enough through this game that I regret not being able to support it on kickstarter. I cannot recommend this game enough. It is a gem and a must-have, even if you are not a fan of turn-based strategy games. This is, first and foremost, an RPG. If you have ever played D&D, Pathfinder, or any other table-top game then Divinity: Original Sin 2 is for you.

tl;dr:  Divinity OS2 is one of the best RPG's and one of the best Co-Op games out right now, and quite possibly the best game I have played in years.  A friend of mine got me this game as a Christmas gift, and I have not been able to put it down since. I enjoyed Divinity OS1 before, but this game manages to outdo it in most aspects still.   The story is amazing. It truly makes you feel like every small decision you make matters, and changes both the course of the game, the way your characters personality forms and how they interact with party members and the world in general(and obviously how they react to you as well).   Most if not all dialogue is fully voiced by great voice actors(including the narrator), the sound track is atmospheric and immerses you straight into the fantasy world, and the graphics and world design are gorgeous.   When I played the OS1 for the first time the slow-paced combat kind of turned me off at first (I thought it was quite hard to survive, and kind of confusing), but once I got more into it I grew to like it, and with Divinity OS2 all my doubts about the turn based combat have vanished. It is a lot of fun to plan out your next moves with your friend. The game wants you to be creative and tactical in combat, so you better not try to run head first into every fight, or else you will probably end up dying many times.Rather you will often use the environment to your advantage( which reacts to pretty much anything you do ) applying status effects, luring enemies away to overwhelm them in numbers and combining elements with your party members to cause havoc.   The companions have rich stories, are fully voiced and quite interesting (I had a hard time picking a follower because they're all quite cool).   That's pretty much all there is to say: if you like (Old-School) RPG's and don't mind the slower paced more tactical combat system, this is probably the best game out there right now.

Narrative: DOS 2 has a true fantasy story. It is one steeped in mystery and pushes the boundaries of creativity.  Each character has a unique subplot completely entangled with the main story. The side quests tie in with the games central themes and main narrative very well. Accordingly, they dont seem out of place or tacked on but are very believeable in the world crafted by larian studios. Music: The music works. It sets the tone quite nicely for the various parts of the world. It goes from epic to playful to somber to tragic in parallel with the envirement or scenario. Gameplay: The gameplay is very strategic with nuanced application. You must defeat intelligent and powerful Antagonists. Your set of abilities can be used envirementaly and you must keep your wits about you for the entirety of the game for both battle and exploration.  Characters: the ensemble cast of main characters each have their own ambitions, dreams, and philosophy. They are not just along for the ride. If you dont want to play as one of them you can create a character whose complexity and depth extends as far as yourself. Most if not all of the NPCs have believable ambitions and reasons for either deterring you or assisting you. there are many factions of npcs and 2/3 of them will seek your destruction depending on your choice so replayability is permitted. I have finished this game once and this is a reflection of that experience.  Since this is truly a great game, I wish everyone to play through and experience its wonders, for that is why I recommend the exploration mode for anyone that is turned off by the difficulty, so they can focus on exploration. I say that because the world and its characters are a spectacle to behold. This is the purest Role Playing Game i have played and I look forward to the future of its developer, Larian Studios.

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is beautiful, turn based rpg game which so delicately crafted it's not like anything I have ever played before. Highly Recommended 5/5  Myself as a fan of D&D, coming from games like Baldur's Gate I & II: Shadows of Amn, Throne of Bhaal and Enhanced Edtion, IsewindDale, Pillars of Eternity, Neverwinter and many other titles this game was exceptionally good and a breath of fresh air, it is both Dynamic and Immersive, the story is deep, thrilling and intriguing, the characters are full of life and awe, even the side quests are interesting, funny, scary and powerful, the artwork and graphics are beautiful, the music is immersive, dramatic and very appropriate. The game also has a powerful way of making you think and leaves you baffled with the simplest of tasks sometimes and it's amazing how well it works as a whole.  The combat & environments are amazing and take the best of all my past D&D experiences to new levels and excels in ways other games fall short, having the ability to try any skill tree, wear any armour, use any weapon and off hand is amazing and other games i suppose just do not see the power of the possibilities it all offers, giving players the option to be and play exactly how they want to, also giving groups far more  utility and a much better role-play experience. The combat and AI combinations are amazing and synergize so well it can lead to very intense immersive battles that require good communication and well planned tactical combinations between groups to succeed.  To make things better they have incorporated the D&D experience through Game Master Mode allowing players to create their own story and encounters and battles with their own take on the D&D game similar to Tabletop Simulator but of course with a much better gameplay experience, taking things further a full workshop allowing the community to develop their own content including classes, weapons, spells, maps and much more, anything they want to create, they can.  All that together makes this game, in my opinion, the best D&D Coop/Multiplayer style Fantasy RPG of the past 10 years, I cannot find a single fault for this game I have enjoyed it immensely and its only gotten better since playing with groups and developing content for it.  BUY IT! TODAY!!

Post-Release Review (Updated):  A great sequel to the first. Tactician mode seems quite a bit easier than the original, but there are enough new updates and  additions from the original to make it unique, but still feel just as smooth.  As with the first, the camera is fairly close, and it would be nice to zoom out further but it is what it is. This is pretty much the only criticism I can make. Characters and npcs are unique and interesting, with good voice acting they really feel like individuals who each have their own personalilty, some could respond well to charm, others might threaten to kill you. Combat is challenging, fluid, and forces you to stay alert, using your head to figure out the best action to take. The visuals are gorgeous for the type of game it is and help to preserve the verisimiltude of the world. Divinity Original Sin 2 is by far the best RPG game that I've played this year.  The story is fantastic and changes based on the choices you make, the combat is interesting, and the game is fairly challenging. While in character creation, you are prompted to pick a pre-made origin character or to create your own. I highly recommend using an origin character as all of their dialog is voiced and they have their own unique twist to the overall story. As for the combat, there are almost always ways to interact with your surroundings during a fight whether it be terrain to climb, barrels of oil to burn, or even puddles of water that can be frozen. The combat also gets much harder as you increase the difficulty and really forces you to use your surroundings to your advantage. The only downside to this is that if you're running a cheesy build ranger and rogue each with the lone wolf trait, you can make quick work of almost any enemy from the early-mid-game and on. My biggest gripe about Divinity Original Sin 2 is that things are added automatically to your hot bar as you pick them up or learn a skill. I personally spent 71 hours on my first play through and did quite a few of the side-quests. If you actually read the items that you pick up and do more of the side quests, you could easily get 100+ hours out of one play through. I highly recommend this game to anyone who's into RPG games, especially those with turn-based combat.

At the cusp of completion.   I think this game has some major drawbacks. One being the difficulty spikes. I am referring always to classic mode for I have not tried any higher. You are doing well, almost a little too easy but nothing rediculous, and then BAM. You are fighting a group that kicks your♥♥♥♥♥so hard your teeth hurt. You reload and adapt and thats fun. But sometimes there is a fight that is just plain unfair.(Not much of a spoiler) There is a boss called Eternal Aetera. This is without a doubt the most rediculously hardest fight in the game so far and I bet the harder than the final. She basicly swamps your team by suprise with a sudden group of phantom wolves. She starts the fight and summons 2 more right on top of you and they attack first. In two or three hits they kill someone or leave them critical. Then she will do several attacks in one turn one of them being a group killer: Hail strike. She has a huge amount of armor and magic armor, and she can keep summoning wolves once killed. I have tried every damn strategy there is. I tried rushing, kiting, charming, status effects. I even tried breaking the dialogue to cheese behind the fight with the pyramids. I must be missing something. I had to lower the difficulty just to beat her. A few fights are this way so I think thats a draw back. I love difficulty and challange but unfairness I cant handle.  Another draw back is the source points. I dont think the magic spells should use up these source points. I think the source skills should because regaining your source is kind of rare. You spend a lot of cash getting these awesome spells you level  and put points in for but you need the damn source to use it.   Another thing I dont like is the limited of AP points. It just feels like it limits the strategy and you do the same battle over and over. Turn 1 you teleport or travel to them. Turn 2 you use your strongest attacks. But with that said it still is very very good and fun. You still get a good dose of strategy too.  One thing I really hate about this game is the cryptic quests. Nothing holds your hand and thats a good thing. But the problem isnt doing the quest, its the completion. The problem I am finding is that so many quests seem to intermingle with eachother that actually turning them in is a god damn mystery. First playthrough on the first chapter: I have done about all the quests I could, but, I didnt know how the hell to turn them in so they left me unrewarded when completing the chapter. I dont know maybe I was just too impatient or not reading carefully. But there are so many cryptic steps to these quests that its overwhelming and annoying.  It's too precise, you must kind of be linear, but there are many ways to go about it. Thats the fun part. But trying to actually turn them in and deciphering which quest is actually what for each pertaining method is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  Oh and there's bugs (current state)  I love the game and highly recomend it. I dont think it's better than the first one. Theres a ton of dialogue with a good portion of it worthless. It's pretty slow. But the game is very long and it's got good graphics, good music, good story, good level up system and good combat system. UI could be better. Cluttery inventory is unavoidable in this game.  If you like the first game you will like this one. The modding community looks really good. But I think the first game is better. Well worth the price.

This game has filled the void in my body that great games like Geneforge have left in their wake. What makes this game so good? (+ is a Positive, - is a Negative)  +The combat is fun.  +The animations are fluid and easy on the eyes. +I can stab my allies and friends and nobody cares. +I can kill my allies and friends and nobody cares. +I can pillage the corpses of my allies and friends and NOBODY CARES. Except my friends. If you didn't want to die, you should have given me the ring! IT GAVE 2 WIT POINTS! YOU DIDN'T NEED IT! +You can customize your character to a decent degree for an alpha that only sports around 30% of the game's content. +You can turn your tank into the game's scariest kamikaze by lining up oil barrels, wearing a cursed ring and soul shackling yourself to the boss for some hilarious burst damage that leaves crippled enemies floundering around in necrofire. -There isn't enough game to keep me satisfied yet. It has about 2-3 hours of content on Explorer. Ignore this mode ENTIRELY. It makes the game too easy and you end up oneshotting most units. Classic is the right difficulty for beginners in my humble opinion. Even with a party of just 2-3 characters, Classic is entirely doable.  (Advice)  Quickly stat Thievery and aquire Cloak and Dagger for your Thief/Assassin. A good thief can steal tomes from vendors that would otherwise cost over 250 gold for free. Cloak and Dagger is simply the most game-changing move Thieves/Assassins can get. This move is beyond invaluable for a mere 1 AP cost. Self Teleport on a short cooldown that clears away nearby ground effects on use, potentially saving allies nearby you when you teleport away, AND allows you to get to unreachable areas, teleport to those pesky backliners and quickly put you in the position to stun and wreak havoc on the enemy backline. Combined with Teleportation, this gives your Thief/Assassin a crazy amount of control over the battlefield.  Mages should aquire Fossil Strike and some form of AoE fire spell as soon as they can. Having a built in oil barrel makes blocking areas off and burning difficult enemies down quickly so much easier. It also gives you an immense amount of control over the battlefiel with a targetable slow field.  First Aid. This cannot be stressed enough how amazing this Huntsman heal is. It removes every debuff in the game but Cursed and Frozen AND heals a set 30% of hp, making it scale without any of your stat points being tosssed into water magic. It also applies rested.  Necromancers. You want one. Especially if they choose Geomancy as a secondary magical build. The amount of debuffs, self healing and battlefield control they bring is crazy. Blood Rain into Contamination makes the entire battlefield into a poison bog. Add some fire and watch the NPCs panic. Pick Zombie and you will be insanely hard to kill outside of a burst.  (Feedback) I would love to be able to change the instruments in-game AND for each member of the party AND enemies. Being able to do this would be awesome. Enemies could be a more somber or erratic instrument, while my controlled characters would be more vibrant to let me know when it was my turn more clearly. Just a thought~

Fantastic strategy RPG that doubles as a platform for online D&D.  Pros: -80 to 100 hour campaign -Massive replay value -Fun and creative turn-based strategy combat -Completely free-form leveling system -After the beginning area you can respec all your characters for free forever -Every line of dialogue is voice-acted, complete with an amazing narrator -Comes bundled with a complete creation kit you can use to make mods, maps, and campaigns -Easy to use co-op, plus a GM mode. -You can kill anyone you want. -No forced morality system. -Quests are very creative and usually have different and interesting outcomes.  Cons: -Tactician mode (hard difficulty) requires you to cheese most fights -Usable items you pick up will automatically be placed on your hotbar, cluttering it unless you manually disable that option -Some quests can be bugged if you accidentally do things before the game expected you to. It's never game breaking, but it can be annoying having unfinished quests cluttering your log. -Ambient voice acting gets very annoying, especially if you are at a vendor sorting out your items to sell and you have to hear the same line from nearby NPC's over and over. -Sometimes it's hard to select specific targets if there's a lot of things near eachother, and the slightest movement of your mouse can accidently change your target just as you cast your ability.   All in all, one of the best RPG's to come out in a long time and I highly recommend it.

At first I was hesitant at getting this. It looks great, and like a lot of fun, but maybe not worth the price. I thought maybe I'd pick up the game on a sale or something.  But I'm very glad I got it.  The story is very rich and there's so many ways to play. I'm excited for my second and third play throughs.   You can steal from anybody, kill anyone, befriend NPCs, talk to your followers if you choose to have them, and each story is different from character creation. Each race is treated differently, you have different dialogue options if you're an Outlaw, or Scholar, or even if you play a smart Wizard, you can persuade people with your smarts, or intimidate people with your strength.   The combat is very fun, and comboing spells and attacks is awesome.  Classes aren't really set in stone either. If you're a Fighter but decide you want to shock people, or grow some wings, you can very much do so.   And the GM mode is amazing.   As a Game Master for D&D games, I've always wanted a game to play it in, to immerse the players, and let them explore with out having to explain every small detail. And this game does it very well. You can create custom items, NPCs (even down to what hat they wear), allies, and customize the pre set maps the game gives you. I would honestly buy a DLC that includes more maps. But there are plently right now, I'm just afraid that through multiple play throughs we'll all think "Oh, this map again."  This game is a masterpiece, but it's not perfect.  The combat is very hard, even on the easiest difficulty it sometimes feels like I need to kill a couple NPCs who don't deserve it so I can level up and continue the story. And sometimes this makes the game feel linear. I don't know if I'm missing something, or I chose bad classes for my party, but either way that's a big down side for me.  That being said, at the time of posting this review I'm 71 hours in, and I havent even completed my first play through, which is a good thing. I'm taking my time, exploring the world, talking to every NPC and living the world.  UPDATE (very minor spoilers):  I finished the game, and I have to say while the ending was good, it was very buggy. I'm surprised that I haven't written a review of this game since I first started playing it. This game from my own perspective offers quite a bit.   Story: Every single quest has multiple ways of being approached and there is no system of good or evil. You could be doing good thing for terrible people or bad things for noble causes. You could just be pure evil for the sake of being a jerk, and you could make every kindhearted decision out there. There is no wrong choice and anytime you block a certain path due to a choice you made, there is always another option to be explored.  For the amount of choices that this game gives you in terms of social and story progression, it's worth a full price buy in that alone.  Gameplay: Honestly, there is no such thing as a game without bugs. For all the bugs that this game has, it has a devoted team of developers to constantly patch and repair whatever the community reports to them. For every feature the community asks of the devs, they take everything into careful consideration. The combat mechanics are simple and complex at the same time. Every attack has it's own property, physical or magic. Physical damage has no sub categories while magic damage splits into, fire, water, earth, poison and wind. What makes the magical damage so complex is how the elements interact with each other and the environment to make the gameplay more immersive.   Unfortunately, if you want to play the game for pure optimization and not immersion, most people go into pure physical damage builds to ignore the majority of elemental immunities that certain enemies might have in the game.  To sum it up, the game is great and worth more than it sells for.

This game does not hold your hand. Remiscent of older AD&D CRPG's. You control a small 4-player party Baldur's Gate-style around a big world map. Each character in your party has unique skills and abilities. Learn them, train them, master them. You can only have four (4) characters in your party so choose wisely.  Expect brutally and sometimes unfair dice-roll turn-based combat. As for questing, again, don't expect any hand-holding, you either figure things out on your own or you look up a walkthrough. Your quest journal is light on hints as well. They DO give hints but they only give you a nudge in the right direction. NPC conversations contain more detailed hints so you have to really pay attention to what they're saying. Oh and important NPC's CAN die and mess up your progress and you will either have to find another way to complete a quest or reload a previous save. Or just live with the death of that NPC and move on. And speaking of saving, this is a game where you either save-scum or you live with the consequences of your choices.  I can recommend this to hardcore CRPG players who are looking for fun and a challenge. I can't recommend it for RPG-lite players who are used to thinbgs like Oblivion or Skyrim.  My overall assesment of this game is: "Brutally challenging and interesting without being difficult for difficluty's sake like Dark Souls"

I just finished my first playthrough last night. Let's get this out of the way: this game is something special. It improves on almost every gripe I had with the original (mainly just story and pacing) and just knocks it out of the park. This is a new gold standard for what a modern RPG should be.    What's Good The companions are memorable, well-written, and have realistic motivations that make negotiating their place in your party really engaging as you strive for the end-goal of the game. (I mean, it makes sense, you can play them as the main character if you wish!)  Combat rewards creativity, exploration, and experimentation without ever feeling like it's unfair towards the player--some fights are tough as nails, but they're just puzzles that you've been given an entire toolbox to solve. It's incredible just how many viable strategies you can employ to build a party and the myriad tactical decisions you can make in combat with those interactions.  Some of the quests and puzzles are pretty inspired--I'm a DM for tabletop group and I can appreciate how hard it is to make a puzzle that's challenging and feels organic to its context while delivering on fun. So hard to do, and 90% of the quests and puzzles in D:OS2 deliver. The quests often have multiple paths to resolution, which can be incredibly satisfying.    (Minor) Gripes I only encountered a few bugs over the course of my game and none of them were show-stopping. (A few dialogue options that didn't make sense because of my choices; quicksave reload breaking a script in combat and requiring rollback; a few quests not updating / reflecting change after I made major progress in them.) The lion's share of these happened in the last two major areas of the game--which I totally understand given the sheer scope of the game.   Long story short: there hasn't been an RPG this rich in a long time. It's worth every penny of the price tag.

review: Being the child of both rpg and turn-based strategy games, Divinity: Original Sins II delivers the best the two genres have to offer.  It can be played alone or with friends comfortably.  It doesn't feel like you [i\have[/i] to play it one way or the other.  In fact, DOSII can be almost defined by its range of options.  From cosmetics to functionality, Larian has done a wonderful job of creating a game that allows the player to experience a unique story every time.

Let me start off by saying that I don't normally write reviews for games unless they are exceptional. This game lies in one of the few exceptions where I have to.  I bought this game when it first released but I didn't have a good computer to actually fully enjoy it. Fast forward to recently when I did buy one and I fully spent the time to play this game. At first, it seemed difficult for me as I never played the first Divinity and tried to learn my way around the game. Not that long after, I got familiar with the story and the lore. From someone who doesn't enjoy care about the plot of most RPG's or MMORPG's, this game somehow brought the story forward for me to be interested in. I personally built an attatchment to my character and my companions as we continued on this adventure through Divinity. It was an amazing experience and that was when I knew what a gem this game was.  Some of the elements that I found compelling about this game was:   The voice acting - The many actors who portrayed the characters in this game did not disappoint. At times, I was just shocked at the amount of emotion and passion placed into each line of dialogue. My personal favorite was the voice actor for Lohse, whom I felt went above and beyond what some would just skim past. Also a big round of applause to those actors who put themselves out there to voice each animal or dungeon rat that was available throughout the game.   The combat - The understanding of many tactical aspects of each combat situation made it harrowing for me, in a fun sort of way. It was fun to experiment different strategies to clear a particular room of enemies or be faced with decisions that could affect whether or not my party makes it out of combat alive. The high-ground/low-ground system made it particularly mindful to pay attention to your surroundings while the natural elemental occurences (such as oil, poison, fire, etc,) keep you on your toes.   The storytelling - As stated in the above paragraph, the story is phenomenal. I found myself always wondering what would happen next and how my actions would affect the world down the line. It was truly one of the times where I found myself relating to my character, as if I were them rather than me controlling them. I truly loved the way the world was set up and how mostly everything had some role to play either in the narrative of the story or just to contribute to the feel of the world.   The world - Speaking of the feel of the world, everything was how it should be to establish a world that felt dynamic and alive. NPC's truly made their experiences feel real with some having problems that seemed normal and how they were portrayed. I sometimes imagined the theoretical lives of these NPC's and treated them as if they were real people with their own past experiences. When a game can make you engrossed into their world, you know it is good.   Music - The music was excellent at many areas and shifts according to the environment that you were placed in. Dungeons or naturally spooky areas had a feeling of dread but the suspensful and harrowing music helped contribute to the feel of this.  The music that played during the ending fight actually had me tearing up as even though it was something that I heard so many times, knowing that this was final area made it truly special and evoked a lot of memories and emotions of the overall adventure   Overall, I had just finished my first campaign and am planning on finishing more as to learn more about the companions that I did not choose at first and to see all the possible routes that I can go through before I eventually clear up the game. The game's amazing and a big thanks for Larian Studios for putting out such a masterpiece. I can't wait for the Definitive Edition to come out but until then, there are many mods and more to keep you continuously entertained. 10/10

A vast improvement compared to the first (DOS:EE) installment of the modern series.  Pros: - In-depth turn based combat system - Beautiful visuals, both in and out of combat - Deep lore in relation to the world that you explore and the characters that inhabit it - Multiple ways to go about accomplishing a central objective - Origin characters with a rich backstory exist along custom player-made characters - Replayability is present for 2 or 3 playthroughs in total as long as you don't get bored of the main story - Infinite respeccing options allowing you to completely change each of your characters on the fly with no penalty     whatsoever - Magnificent soundtrack and audio work  Cons: - Although an improvement compared to DOS:EE, the game at times is still fairly unintuitive (looking at you, Arx) - Some minor bugs pose an equally minor annoyance (some characters keep infinitely looping dialogue, audio bugs) - Very lackluster ending - Unable to go back to previous areas after having moved on to the next act / area - Unable to free roam and tie off any loose ends after completeing the game    Conclusion:DOS:2 is a very fun game that I find was worth the money that I've invested into it. I bought it the moment it came out of early access and have sunk a total of 64 hours into it. You can definitely sink more time into this (around 75 or 80 hours total maybe) if you go around and finish every side quest and origin character questline. As I've already mentioned it's a shame that we can't go back and freeroam all of the areas once we finish the game. This was an issue in DOS:EE as well and it's sad to see that the same problem persists here. Either way I must give credit to Larian for a near flawless second installment. If you're on the fence about buying this game I would advise you to wait for the winter sale and see if it drops in price, and if it doesn't, then buy it anyway. The price will not change from $45.

PROS:  - Excellent artwork - Amazing soundtrack and voice acting - Lots of details - Well written dialogues - Companions are useful and interesting  CONS:  - Last act looks a bit too rushed - Minor bugs, probably fixed by now - Crafting feels unfinished in some recipes but it is pretty extense  FULL REVIEW:  It has amazing artwork and an outstanding amount of details that you just can't overlook.   The dialogue is another thing that is really well written, it contains easter eggs, fun jokes and serious or sensitive  lines that will hit you, that goes hand in hand with the voice acting and sound track.  The story stays consistent and it is well made, no matter your choices you won't see a decrease in quality  (I had several saves).  As a bad point I can say the last act looks and feels a bit rushed. Also I have encountered several tiny bugs, but they didn't really trouble me while playing.  The crafting part to me looks lacking, I had several things that couldn't find on any wiki, reddit or similar how to use them or they were kind of useless.  I was not really fond of the armor design (some looked too huge, or they had outstanding stats and looked like plain clothes), or the fact that you have dyes but cannot change the armour color in any way, but maybe that's planned (?).   So my final review is really positive over all of the cons I found, I think It's still worth playing 100%.

I am unsure where to begin with Divinity 2 at this point. This game has been and still is an amazing journey you can take on alone or with your friends.  I am hardly convinced with most of the games I play but Divinity has me on a collar. I cannot look away or stop playing it. I already am at 50H and haven't even experienced the whole singleplayer campaign.   The fact that you can talk with every single NPC, including animals (if you got the "Pet Pal" Talent early on), that you can explore every corner, find new clues and ways to secret caves or find treasure chests. All those aspects are a big yes for me to recommend Divinity2.   But was that all? Hell no. I haven't even covered 20 percent of what this game is capable of yet! I really enjoy freedom. I want to choose what to do, how to do it and, that should I take the wrong path in a conversation, have to deal with the backfire. Each race reacts differently towards NPC's (as do they. A lot of racism going on in this game) while adding more tags to your character such as "Barbarian""Scholar""Outlaw""Mystic""Soldier""Jester" and "Noble" gives you the options to get more information out of them or successfully persuing them after they saw you stealing. (I have to add this since it caused me great pain. Do NOT click on a trader while they are walking by. I accidentally stole a bottle of wine instead of talking to the trader and hell on earth broke out. Never steal wine guys. NEVER.)   Each races armor looks different depending on what armor you give them. The same helmet looks differently for each race which means just getting out all the armor sets probably took ages and I am glad they put so much detail and work in this game. You can see the development teams heart in it. A great game that is meant to be so much more.  It is sometimes hard to keep the playerbase or even raise those numbers shouldn't there be options to replay the game after "finishing". Divinity did everything right. I am putting the word "finish" like this simply because of the fact that you will be having a hard time completing this game 100% if not impossible. So many options depending on what you chose while creating your character, while talking, whom you talk too and how. So many options to go, so much to explore, so many ways you can complete a single quest will make it hard for you to not get lost in this wonderful world <3  And I haven't even started to talk about the Game Master aspect. So far I have't been able to look at them simply because of the fact that the moment I have freetime I play the campaign.... I might be addicted at this point.  The option to create your own campaign, invite your friends or upload your work on Divnity's Steam Workshop will give you a never ending adventure.  My friendgroup started to use Divinity as DnD platform. Our GM creates the world and through Divinity you don't need to only imagine it, you can actually see and play your personal adventure.  Since the game is turn based you have everything a little RP heart needs to be happy.   In short: If you enjoy exploring, a never ending adventure and have a great time with your friends while playing Divnity's campaign, a downloaded one from the workshop or your own this is the game for you to play.  A long awaited tripple A game that has been worth all the wait. Hands up for an amazing adventure I will be enjoying for a long time!

At the cusp of completion.   I think this game has some major drawbacks. One being the difficulty spikes. I am referring always to classic mode for I have not tried any higher. You are doing well, almost a little too easy but nothing rediculous, and then BAM. You are fighting a group that kicks your♥♥♥♥♥so hard your teeth hurt. You reload and adapt and thats fun. But sometimes there is a fight that is just plain unfair.(Not much of a spoiler) There is a boss called Eternal Aetera. This is without a doubt the most rediculously hardest fight in the game so far and I bet the harder than the final. She basicly swamps your team by suprise with a sudden group of phantom wolves. She starts the fight and summons 2 more right on top of you and they attack first. In two or three hits they kill someone or leave them critical. Then she will do several attacks in one turn one of them being a group killer: Hail strike. She has a huge amount of armor and magic armor, and she can keep summoning wolves once killed. I have tried every damn strategy there is. I tried rushing, kiting, charming, status effects. I even tried breaking the dialogue to cheese behind the fight with the pyramids. I must be missing something. I had to lower the difficulty just to beat her. A few fights are this way so I think thats a draw back. I love difficulty and challange but unfairness I cant handle.  Another draw back is the source points. I dont think the magic spells should use up these source points. I think the source skills should because regaining your source is kind of rare. You spend a lot of cash getting these awesome spells you level  and put points in for but you need the damn source to use it.   Another thing I dont like is the limited of AP points. It just feels like it limits the strategy and you do the same battle over and over. Turn 1 you teleport or travel to them. Turn 2 you use your strongest attacks. But with that said it still is very very good and fun. You still get a good dose of strategy too.  One thing I really hate about this game is the cryptic quests. Nothing holds your hand and thats a good thing. But the problem isnt doing the quest, its the completion. The problem I am finding is that so many quests seem to intermingle with eachother that actually turning them in is a god damn mystery. First playthrough on the first chapter: I have done about all the quests I could, but, I didnt know how the hell to turn them in so they left me unrewarded when completing the chapter. I dont know maybe I was just too impatient or not reading carefully. But there are so many cryptic steps to these quests that its overwhelming and annoying.  It's too precise, you must kind of be linear, but there are many ways to go about it. Thats the fun part. But trying to actually turn them in and deciphering which quest is actually what for each pertaining method is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  Oh and there's bugs (current state)  I love the game and highly recomend it. I dont think it's better than the first one. Theres a ton of dialogue with a good portion of it worthless. It's pretty slow. But the game is very long and it's got good graphics, good music, good story, good level up system and good combat system. UI could be better. Cluttery inventory is unavoidable in this game.  If you like the first game you will like this one. The modding community looks really good. But I think the first game is better. Well worth the price.

Do you like strategic roleplaying games like Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, Arcanum, Fallout 1 & 2, Dragon Age (the first one), or XCOM 2?  Well, you're going to love this.  This game combines the roleplaying depth of Dungeons & Dragons with a strategic feeling similar to XCom 2. Practically speaking, what this means is that outside of combat, you can do damn well near anything you can think of. In combat, you can do the same. If you want to break into that house, kill that lady, steal that gold, and escape into the night, you can. If you want to be the daring hero, and save shackled stowaways on a sinking ship, you can. This game gives you the freedom to truly explore the "RP" factor of Roleplaying games. Very few games these days can hold a candle to the amount of roleplaying this game encourages.   I think a number of groups of Dungeons and Dragons players will likely abandon tradtional and even virtual play, and just move their games over to Divinity: Original Sin 2. It's easy to learn, hard to master - not unlike D&D - and it's also aesthetically gorgeous in both music and graphics. Can't recommend this game enough. Buy it.

I found the story as well as the voice acting in certain parts cheesy. I didn't play any previous games, so I might not be fit to judge the story but that's the impression I got. It didn't really bother me though, maybe they were going for the old school cliché RPG story.   The funnest part of the game is the countless ways you can tackle quests or objectives. I'm not a big fan of turn-based combat but the one in DOS2 really did it for me. It's challenging and the way you and enemies can interact with the environment (for example wet ground) is really awesome and leads to alot of funny moments co-op.   Every side quest felt unique and it didn't feel like I was doing anything pointless.   The RPG elements are implemented amazingly well. I was impressed by how much your civil abilities, attributes, race as well as the backgrounds you chose at the start (Scholar, Jester, Noble..) of the game affect your dialogue options and ways you can do quests. The game doesn't tie you down when it comes to character builds and there are lots of interesting skills you can combine and play around with. The one thing I didn't like so much was the lack of armor variation for races other than humans, they all look kind of the same to me.  I played through the whole game in co-op which made the experience much more enjoyable. If you can find a friend who's willing to play with you from beginning to end it's tons of fun. I also have a save where I started a playthrough with an NPC companion (Fane). I was pleasantly surprised by how much depth NPC companions have. They have their very own storyline that which you completely miss out on if you don't make them join your party.  I recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a decent RPG, even people who prefer action RPGs.

Have you ever asked yourself what would happen if they could make D&D into an actual videogame? Well look no further! I've been on the fence about buying this game for a while, I finally picked up this game on sale and I'm so far 17 hours into playing this game. All I can say is this may be the greatest RPG I have ever played. Does it have the greatest graphics? No. It is mouse click controls as opposed to WASD. This game more than makes up for all of that with the richness of it's story and lore. In additition the character customization as well as the sheer amount of decisions you can make to complete a quest are vast and astounding. For a game that is not that graphics intense it is still 26 GB and you can see where all that memory goes. You can talk to every single NPC and animal (if you have that skill) in this world and they all have a voice you can actually listen to. You can kill any NPC you want but keep in mind that everything has a consequence in this game. Combat is interesting and again, depending on what skills you have, can be approached in multiple ways depending on the challenge. You can be a ranger with wings, fly up to the high ground and have a tactical advantage. Have a battlemage, shock the most powerful foe, stun lock him while the rest of your party kills all the others. Be a rogue and give every enemy the suprise buttsecks.... everything is a possibility in this game. If you have looked at the game description and been intrigued but maybe not convinced to buy this game, don't even think about it just buy it. You will get your money's worth. This is a game I see myself replaying multiple times in the future.

I am not someone who enjoys isometric RPGs. I love the likes of the later Fallouts, Elder Scrolls, and other first-person action RPGs, but never things like Pillars of Eternity or older isometrics. I am also not a fan of turn based combat, I find it slow and often boring and difficult to pull off well, the only game where this is not the case for me is XCOM. So when my friends kept telling me I needed to play Divinity: Original Sin 2, that it is everything I've ever wanted, I found it hard to believe. It seemed to be the antithesis of what I enjoyed, and on top of that it was more expensive than any game I've purchased in the past three years and I didn't want to take a gamble on it.  That lasted for a couple of months until the summer sale where the game was on sale for $35 and I was looking to spend money so I said what the hell. If I didn't like it, I could always refund it within two hours of game time.  Don't get this game on sale. Get it at the most expensive possible price to give the developers as much money as you can because god damn do they deserve it.  The combat system that I thought I would hate is exactly what I expected, but is nearly perfect along the lines of how XCOM's systems are near perfect. The creativity allowed for in planning encounters around environmental hazards and playing the terrain and elements to you benefit is infinitely entertaining and allows for some truly memorable moments to arrise from seemingly meaningless fights. The isometric view and movement took some getting used to and still is annoying from time to time when it comes to interior environments, but after a couple hours it becomes second nature like any other game.   The absolute, main golden goose of this game is its storytelling. There has not been a game with better storytelling since the Witcher 3 and Divinity even knocks that out of the water. Not in its main overarching story, mind. That in and of itself is wonderous and expansive beyond imagining, nor in its world building that somehow manages to make tolkein-esque fantasy feel fresh and unique without feeling gimicky. But where Divinity really shines is in its moment-to-moment encounters. Almost every single character in the world is given a name and backstory, and all of them are suprisingly deep. Even the animals are given names, stories, personalities and quests, some of which are hilarious and some of which are absolutely heartbreaking, all locked behind one trait you might not even pick.   This is the great beauty of DOS2, the absolutely stunning density of its storytelling and the unbelievable nature of its originality. With something like this it is very easy for quests and stories to become repetitive and boring, but somehow DOS2 manages to keep them all fresh and inventive with characters that you truly, achingly care for even though you've only just met them.   You will get sucked into the world of DOS2, and you'll stay there until you finish it even while you aren't playing. I thought I wouldn't like this game, and even though I am barely halfway done with it it is already one of my favorite games of all time. If you're on the fence, get off that fence and play it. If you aren't interested, rethink your priorities. This game is a modern masterpiece and it will be remembered for years to come.

A delightfully fresh game (Fresh meat's back on the menu boys!)  This game is one of the best CRPGs you'll ever play, however there are some design issues that are objectively awful.  Random loot, sure it sounds like a stock-standard idea. Randomized loot. but it gets irritating swapping out old stuff with the new every level on all four characters. Trying to remember who needs a new piece of equipment and checking every time is a whole lot of 'belgh.'  Instead of having so much focus on the differnce that levels and equipment makes, why not put it on making unique armors and weapons? There are already exsisting unique items, but they're useless because you're always getting something better. A focus on tactical gameplay rather than numbers, because it's only ever tactical when the enemy is a level above you or there's a load of them kicking thy butt.   That's my biggest gripe.   Spells are fun and the interactivity is novel and satisfying at first, but by act three the player should understand the rather simple mechanics.   Combat, now I liked the combat at first. Then the fights started getting longer, and watching characters cast the same spell and seeing same damn animation everytime really begins to grind on one's nerves. Why not speed up the animations? Or have an option to do that? Why do I have to sit here and watch ten enemies stroll around and take five seconds (the approx time spent casting a single spell) to cast each of their spells.   Crafting blows harder than stormy daniels. I'm not going to carry all that stuff in any of my inventories. Organizing is a chore, so I just get rid of everything except my potions and lotions.   Quests are neat, and the devs know that players will, can, and may do whatever they want to win fights. Break the game. The game is self-aware. It parodies itself and the genre. Sneak mode (haha), and numerous other things I can't remember.

One of the best games I have ever played.  Several bugs and lack of features make it fall just short of that #1 however.  My main concerns are in multiplayer. You have to play as the hosts party characters and not your own. That means playing an archer with a level 2 bow, all stats in wits and other useless talents. There is also an endless amount of bugs with multiplayer. For example, if I am host and start a multiplayer and someone joins me as say The Red Prince and I save, restart whatever, that character then becomes bugged. Instead of reverting back to The Red Prince after that player leaves, he bears that persons name and is unable to be reset, or even dismissed. You normally can talk to npc's in your party and say you want to go your seperate ways and recruit another party member, nope. bugged.  Another example is I use one of my npc's for dialect options since they have persuasion stats and my main is undead. Someone joined the game and took control of MY character and when I leveled up he butchered his stats and skills and those remained on my character after I kicked him and / or restarted the game.  These things make multiplayer extremely frustrating and have forced me to start brand new games probably about 6 times now. I haven't even been able to get through act 1. I am very wary to play in multiplayer due to all these reasons and despite preferring multiplayer in it's theory am forced to play single player to avoid game breaking bugs like those i mentioned. I wish I could provide some feedback or get some kind of bug fix on this bug I don't see an option for that. Thankfully the developer is very involved in the game and will probably fix this at some point. I am now hoping that a user created mod will fix many of these issues in the future (thank god this game has mods)  Despite all my frustrations this game is absolutely incredible in every other aspect. Everything is voiced, every npc which is amazing. Graphics are good (not great) especially for this type of game. Quests are actually fun and not all fetch they actually have lore. There is an absolute freedom: you can kill every npc and still proceed with the game. The gameplay is some of the best ever. This genre has been ruined in the past decade with games like the Final Fantasy series dropping the traditional turn-based combat for an active combat. Yeah, thats nice in some circumstances but it is extremely boring hacking and slashing repetitively just like every other game. The combat in D:OS2 is calculated, and detailed. Everything is listed and heavily focused on strategy and statuses. The game encourages using environments such as high ground and environmentals like barrels and puddles in order to gain favor in battle.   The best part of the game is the fact it's challenging. The default difficulty will probably be too hard for average gamers and those not familiar with the genre or the first game. There are two higher difficulties on top of that which are extremely challenging (I normally play on the highest difficulty in every other game) The next best thing would be that the developers aren't EA, Ubisoft, Activision, etc and force paywalls on an incomplete game and don't support the game after launch. This dev actually cares and I have personally downloaded atleast one patch per day and they have already stated that they are going to implement being able to use your own character in multiplayer which is something I look forward to. Can't wait to see what's next for this game.

Pretty good RPG with a classic feeling to it. A lot of content and a lot of replayability. The fact that you can play it with a friend and give him control over characters (4 party members, so we played 2:2) is just awesome and led to many laughs. I would recommend it and I'll just highlight 3 aspects of the game that were memorable about it in the good, the bad and the ugly (okay, the neutral).   The good: I hate any tactician turn-based game. Often they're overcomplicated. But this one? This one was ... definitely complex but somehow I came around to like it. Everything made sense and learning how things works by setting EVERYTHING ON FIRE was a fun experience. Gameplay is just fun, making a builds and testing them out was great, there's a lot of possibilities to go around. Lots of things to find, lots of ways to resolve an issue, lots of surprises. If gameplay is what you're after then you won't be disappointed.  The bad: BUGS. Oh my god the bugs. Not many - true, but one extended turns in a certain boss fight to make it last forever for enemy to finish his turn. Another one made me lose about 15 hours of progress, because I couldn't access "home-base" waypoint and had to load older save. And yet another - by a chance we found out a bug that can make you immortal duplicating an Idol that ressurects you for no cost at all so you could gear up your whole team with immortality idols and pass the game in easy mode. What the hell. Larian fix your game, bugs in key moments are not acceptable, especially after the game came out of early access.  The neutral: Story and lore. Honestly only story for your companions was any good and made you care. Overall the game is about ego trip to become divine and often we were in a pretty good spot to not care about anyone else than our own quest to power. Factions and key characters even when they started as good, sooner or later they ended up not so rightous to a point I didn't mind killing most of them. Never felt there was any greater incentive to be "the good guy" or choosing "the lesser evil" in this game. The whole world felt not worth fighting for. Maybe that is the point? It's not bad, it definitely had some depth to it, but still felt "meh".

Long have I been looking for a big RPG game in the trend of Baldur's Gate/Planescape Torment and to a lesser extend NWN and NWN2. That wait is over.  Divinity: Original Sin 2 gave me that same feeling I got when I first played Baldur's Gate 2 so long ago. It has a giant sprawling world with so many things to do and so many mechanics to make it even more fun, I spend so much time plotting on how to rob merchants off their goods/money. The turn-based combat is very addicting, I am normally not a fan of turn based combat, but D:OS2 does it incredibly well, very much like X-Com.   For those of you who loved Baldur's Gate 1 and 2 and are a bit turned off by the turn based combat, please give this game a chance because it's the closest thing we have gotten to BG.  The story of this game is alright, there are plenty of mysteries and questions unanswered at the start and middle of the game to keep you engaged. But the main focus in this game is its story and game mechanics. The way the quests and maps compliment each other makes it very addicting to completionists. You want to complete every single quest in each area. This combined with amazing visuals and great sound, it is definitely worth all the money.  I finished the game in about 140+ hours on my first playthrough, and every hour was worth it, I cannot recall a single game (next to BG/BG2) that gave me this many hours of fun in a single playthrough.  Divinity: Original Sin 2 gets a solid 9 from me.

A great game. But it seems they ran out of resources at some point mid-development.  Nice story, nice graphics, a lot of quests, none of the quests is repetitive, all the voice actings, and all that. The game itself is fantastic and exceedingly immersive as I've spent around 200 hours to finish just the first playthrough.  However, it is apparent that they rushed on finishing the game from somewhere like 2/3 of the way. The most noticeable evidence, which a lot of people on the discussion forum complain about, is that somewhat rather many quests will not properly be completed. For instance, even if you've done everything and the quest log also says so, the quest remains uncompleted and say something like you abandoned the quest, when you move to the next area. The next problem, from my experience, is that I've noticed some slopinesses here and there throughout the game. For example, some dialogue options are just null, which means the game (or npcs) doesn't recognise the dialogue options and just quit the conversation. For another example, there is a quest in an earlier chapter involving an npc which implies there is more to be found in later chapters about the npc, but nothing ever mentions anything about the npc as if she never even existed, even if the npc has been on the same boat (literally) to the very end of the game. They are not like game breaking bugs, but still, annoying and feel like that their care for polishing the game has been started decreasing at some point.  Overall, I'm not saying like the game is bad or anything like that, it's just that I've noticed these small things (maybe big?) throughout the game and they were annoying. Consider it as a small complain. But still, it's a great game and worth every penny, and that's why I'm giving it a yes to 'Do you recommend this game?'. It's been a great experience and well spent over-200 hours. I highly recommend the game. If they do some patch-works, I think it would be safe to call it a masterpiece. :D

This game has to be one of my all time favorites. Tactical freedom is close to rediculous. From the team you pick, the weapons you choose, the small moments the world interacts with you, or you realize that an entire area's storyline has changed (ever so slightly, but with some weight) because you chose to be a baddy for 3 minutes, the second time. This game is the perfect example of how games should be.  Divinity Original Sin 2 has depth, amazingly fun gameplay. Can be massively challenging and punishes those who run into danger without thinking. I'm currently on my honor run close to the ending of Act 2. This is the hardest difficulty with permadeath. Meaning... when your party dies, you lose your savegame. And no... this is not Xcom where you can Alt-F4 when♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan. The second a character dies, the game saves for you. Good luck getting yourself out of that pickle. With good preperation comes great rewards. Fights can be easy at times, but if I think for one second that I'm overpowered..? The game punishes me hard.  And that is what I love. It's like advanced chess, but you don't play "the same pieces", your characters evolve, become stronger. No pure warrior, naaah... give him some heals and necromancy spells to leech the blood out of your enemies. Making him the most dangerous guy on the field at all times. Feel like your character isn't strong enough? Give your archer some support spells to boost each others moves. Now your dangerous guy has the potential to kill four characters in two turns. And who needs a shield when you have a healthpool of 3000 health, hit with 500 dmg per swing and heal 70% of the damage done? One good area attack and you are healthy as an ox. And I know that when my warrior gets nuked with stuns etc? My archer is there with the right support spells to get him out again. And at no time am I really overpowered. Two times I almost lost my savegame because I misjudged a few skills from enemies. The constant struggle to play with the best optimisation and adapt to the game's AI. It's simply amazing.   Don't expect too much from the main story. It has depth, interesting aspects but you buy this game 100% for the gameplay. Do know... you CAN kinda abuse the game at later levels. There are skills that can be abused so you absolutely trash everything with the proper respec. Keep in mind that figuring out how the game works, what spells do etcetera, THAT is where the most fun is.   Some other Pro tips: - Stealing is great fun, saves tons of money and keeps your party geared up (probably the best tip, do not-not steal).  - Undead are awesome, but start with a regular team, different mechanics can mess your party up if unprepared.  - Stick to either full physical damage OR full magical damage. Trust me on this one, you will thank me later.  - Summoners are overrated. They kinda make fights last 3x longer than needed. Only pick them if you absolutely love the mechanics.  - Figure out how to use stealth in combination with teleportation. You can "cheat" some fights that will otherwise trash your party.  - You can respec shortly after the end of Act 1, which is - on average - 10 hours of gameplay - Crafting... almost EVERYTHING can be crafted. You only get to see 10% of the recipes that actually excist. Just google a crafting wiki. Thank me later. Don't wait until you find the books. If you want to make something, you probably can.  - Make sure your characters can survive alone as well. If they are too dependent on each other you will have a hard time nearing the endgame.  - Last but not least... Aim to finish about 80% of all the (side)quests. You will need the experience until the middle of Act 2, after that the game becomes a little more flexible when it comes to XP.   Downsides of the game? It can be buggy, but rarely game breaking. AI can be brutal, feel unfair... but there is a pattern to exploit at all times. Quests can still be bugged out because you did something so complex that the game doesn't really know what you actually did.

I'm so accustomed to sequels being lack luster or over hyped for what they become.. But not Larian Studios.. These mother ♥♥♥♥ers know what they're doing!   I can NOT recommend this game enough. One minor gripe though, in my first playthrough I couldn't quite get the ending to trigger properly as it was bugged. I did make some very odd choices along the way and was playing just a 2 man party so maybe that might have broke a few things but still ... it really bummed me out. At any rate, aside from that it's a fantastic game and one that I can recommend to anyone who wants a really deep, replayable and enjoyable RPG.

One of my most highly recommended RPG games to date. This game has really been a prime example of a true Roleplaying game ought to be. From gameplay, to storytelling, character customization, and character builds that is entirely up to you.  I'll break down the game by its Pros and Cons, and add some of my feedback or advise at the end to help change the game.   PRO'S: - Character Creation is very open and fluid, but not restrictive. Playing as Humans, Elves, Dwarves, or Lizards as well as undead counterparts;  These races all have their unique traits and uniquely recognized in the game. NPCs react differently on the race you play.  The customization options certainly could always use more; but you can always find a good look for you.  - Combat is all about problem solving. All dependant on the builds you create to help expertly pass speicifc fights. If you don't specialize in Persuasion to avoid some fights all together.  Whether your team is all ranged, melee, magic, or mixture of all three. Your job is to figure the best tactful moves to assure victory. Wether you have multiple healing aiblities spread across the team, or one dedicated healer.   - World environment is gorgeous. Even wtih a top-down view. You can always look through the area and see such attention to detail . Not a single place in this game feels like a drag-drop copy. And it all flows perfectly.   - Voice acting is top notch, whether you play an Origin Character or Custom Character. The Origin followers have brilliant commentary that give their personality great depths. NPCs all are uniquely voiced with very few reprisal roles that still achieve a personality.  Even better how all the NPCs have hundreds of dialog branches based on your race, gender, and background tags that you select or have as your origin character.  - The game rewards thinking out the box. Whether you skip a puzzle through mobility moves, or attack specific NPCs. IF you get a grasp of specific play, the game will recognize clever  behavior and will speak of it in later gameplay.  (**Minor Spoiler**: Dallis the Hammer, a primary antaognist can be attacked as soon as the beginning of the game. If you manage to defeat her, she escapes and leaves a very powerful hammer, and comment on it when you engage her once more.) ----------------------- Cons:   - Character Creation can be a bit limiting for specific races that lack additional features such as beards. If an update patch or DLC added more options. It would make the uniqueness of your character stand out.  - Some weapons like wands become weaker in the late game and could use a numerical change to come up to par. Often one will drop wands for a staff due to the lack of numerical value.  - Some design choices for mandatory abilities such as Bless require a memory slot despite the high volume of times in the game its required to be used. Some changes for it to always be memorized would be beneficial to match.   ----------------------- Advise / Feedback: I would change the ability: Bless to not require Source. The ability has great demand in the storyline; but mechanic wise; its primarily the weakest option only because Source Abilities are rarely used until middle/late game. Bless becomes increasingly worthless the further one progresses.   It also acts as one of the only few counters against the Cursed Status, which is a huge problem in the later game when one faces the Voidwoken.   The Pet Pal: Talent should be changed for those who have the Sir Lora DLC To whomever he follows; he should grant the Pet Pal talent to. If one lacks the talent; this little squirrel sadly becomes more of an annoyance than a fun little mobile dialog through the story.   More Origin choices for custom characters - Currently the only origin ability that custom character gets is a protective dome. If we should choose from a selection of Origin abilities, it would give us further importance on decisions. Though I could see why it'd encourage more people to play differently.

I'm going to keep this pretty much short and to the point. On the whole I really enjoyed this game, but there were a few niggles that stick out. Nothing show stopping, but there nonetheless. I liked the story and I loved the characterisation. I feel it developed well as the gaem went on, though I feel the 3rd act was a little off kilter from the rest and teh 4th was a little rushed as the end came near. I'd argue this could have held upa 5th act fairly easily and left the story pretty well rounded out. As per the orignal game the graphics are excellent and with the characterisation I actually felt this the better of the 2 games.  But a few things stood out as cons and depending on your game style/preference this may affect how you approach the game. - Some quests are difficult to work out. The fact some can pop into your journal with almost no exposition beforehand and/or they have obscure solutions that can be almost a fluke to complete breaks the story for me. It's mainly side quests, but when you are trying to max experience to level up your characters its annoying to chase half way across the map because you missed something. And the fact some characters can remain 'red flagged' even after completing a quest is plain annoying. - Necro fire is overdone. With all the possibilities of surface/cloud mechanics, this gets tired quickly. Especially in act 2. - It's not clear from some spell descriptions exactly what they do. It's pretty annoying to fire off a spell and find it didn't work because you missed a line of text or the like. (Along these lines, it also annoys me that after spending effort on writing up descriptions for things they are often unreadable because the descriptive box doesn't draw correctly) - Determining the correct responses/best persuassion chances is sometimes almost random, and the fact in some conversations your ratings almost do not matter. It would be more realistic to be able to explore a characters wants and needs and then come up wiht the right answer to a question, than to plain guess in many instances. This breaks the narrative for me and the fact the wrong conversation option in some places can all but break a quest is jarring. - Depending on how you levelled up, selected spells etc. the end can be almost an anticlimax. Wrong choice can get you wiped out in a couple fo rounds, 'right' choice can win it for you very quickly. Tactics are almost taken out of the last battle entirely.  But it still a great game. I still haven't completed PoE, let alone picked up the sequel. DOS2 at least has an easy to follow plot and characterisation to carry you along. If you can put up wiht its foibles, its one of the best in the genre.

This game does not hold your hand. Remiscent of older AD&D CRPG's. You control a small 4-player party Baldur's Gate-style around a big world map. Each character in your party has unique skills and abilities. Learn them, train them, master them. You can only have four (4) characters in your party so choose wisely.  Expect brutally and sometimes unfair dice-roll turn-based combat. As for questing, again, don't expect any hand-holding, you either figure things out on your own or you look up a walkthrough. Your quest journal is light on hints as well. They DO give hints but they only give you a nudge in the right direction. NPC conversations contain more detailed hints so you have to really pay attention to what they're saying. Oh and important NPC's CAN die and mess up your progress and you will either have to find another way to complete a quest or reload a previous save. Or just live with the death of that NPC and move on. And speaking of saving, this is a game where you either save-scum or you live with the consequences of your choices.  I can recommend this to hardcore CRPG players who are looking for fun and a challenge. I can't recommend it for RPG-lite players who are used to thinbgs like Oblivion or Skyrim.  My overall assesment of this game is: "Brutally challenging and interesting without being difficult for difficluty's sake like Dark Souls"
This game is super fun, even more so with friends. 100% worth full price, my GOTY for 2017.

Have you ever asked yourself what would happen if they could make D&D into an actual videogame? Well look no further! I've been on the fence about buying this game for a while, I finally picked up this game on sale and I'm so far 17 hours into playing this game. All I can say is this may be the greatest RPG I have ever played. Does it have the greatest graphics? No. It is mouse click controls as opposed to WASD. This game more than makes up for all of that with the richness of it's story and lore. In additition the character customization as well as the sheer amount of decisions you can make to complete a quest are vast and astounding. For a game that is not that graphics intense it is still 26 GB and you can see where all that memory goes. You can talk to every single NPC and animal (if you have that skill) in this world and they all have a voice you can actually listen to. You can kill any NPC you want but keep in mind that everything has a consequence in this game. Combat is interesting and again, depending on what skills you have, can be approached in multiple ways depending on the challenge. You can be a ranger with wings, fly up to the high ground and have a tactical advantage. Have a battlemage, shock the most powerful foe, stun lock him while the rest of your party kills all the others. Be a rogue and give every enemy the suprise buttsecks.... everything is a possibility in this game. If you have looked at the game description and been intrigued but maybe not convinced to buy this game, don't even think about it just buy it. You will get your money's worth. This is a game I see myself replaying multiple times in the future.

Fantasizing about your wizard cast a rain spell and your ranger pulling out a electric arrow from his backpack and stunning the enemy is delightful. With definitive edition, online pvp matches got an overhaul and it definitely got better. Only problem is there is not much people playing online so when you search for matches you find 2 rooms which are both full for example.  Having the choice of playing with diffrent characters is a wonderful edition to the first game. Commanding your team and living the story through each  4 individuals perspective in one go might be a bad thing for some of us but the choice is yours. You can choose to go through 2 - 3 diffrent playthroughs and each one would be a bit diffrent than each other.  Or maybe you want to play co-op online,local or on LAN with your friends and go to your seperate ways in the same game! Larian did an amazing job by keeping the loading screens to minimum-none; meaning you can teleport around the map, find your friend in a faraway pub in a seemless transition which why this game doesn't let you go and captivates you.  My displeasure with this game is its art style for character models and portraits. Of course everybody have their own tastes but for a beautiful game like this, characters seem a bit off putting for me. Also the first part of the game can get repetetive after multiple playthroughs which can stop you from starting over again after a few times. Maybe diffrent beginnings for each character or a more sandboxy start would be better in my opinion.  Songs and voices are great. Humour is there for the ones looking for, so the game is not edgy or too dramatic. Larian really busts their asses to give you quality content and making the definitive edition free for the owners of the original game only deserves appreciation. Definitely worth playing. Best RPG on the market for now.
