Overall: 11/10 for a RPG fan, probably two points down for other people due to it's sheer RPG monstrosity.  Gameplay: 10/10 Awsome in terms of RPG. At the beginning the game starts pretty-ok-but-not-really-great, but don't worry dears! It get's *really really* more interesting in fun-wise, quest-wise, and lore-wise aspect the farther you are from the beginning and it doesn't seem to stop omghosh! Game offers zillions of approches with few standing out at the apparent ones. Game doesn't force you to attend to every choice or thing, you can really go your own build or be a jack-of-all trade. Ofc you can screw up hard, but than again, why you invested points willy-nilly in the first place? Good interface. Good outlook. Little to no glitches or bugs I found after 50 hours of real ingame (don't watch my 300 hours I sometimes forget the game in the background.)  Difficulty: ?/10 I play RPG my whole life. On hard settings I have really hard and frustrating combat sometimes. Paradoxically not with bosses but with semi-bosses and larger battles. Like reloading 5-6 times before I come to a solution, some battles just cannot be won by sheer force and positioning. But hey, they said it would be hard, right :D ? I believe on normal this is more normal, right? :D  Graphics: 8/10 As the isometric RPGs goe, this world and it's architecture is just wonderful. BUT there is one little bad thing that is big in impact though. Small items are often nigh impossible to see with your own eyes. Like keys, coins, gems, plants... :( it really forces you to hit alt to see all items in vincinity and spoiling the fun of being observant. The very first Divinity was impossibly great with it's keys hidden under the door mat, hidden switches behind barrels you had to move etc. Those were the days... but you could have seen those items, here, you really can't unless you have a 10x zoom in your cybernetic eyes, Larian, wtf, we are not all Krytons you know :(  Sound: 8/10 Everything is fine. Music is fine, sometimes even cool, though for me, there are no realy memorable songs or compositions. Voicing is really nice and suits the characters well on the other hand. Sound is good as sounds can go.   Fun:: 10/10 - Absolutely one in a million chance to play this as coop multiplayer. WTF MAN, shut up and take my money and my friend's credit card... - Teleportation spell. Oh my goodness. You'll know all the uses soon enough. - Healing undeads with poison? ok lol, wait it get's even stranger... - Chicken spell + Haste + Rupture tendons on enemies. HAHAHAHA - Hero remarks, having a Talk to animals skill makes you able to apprehend animals with their silly little quests, being often reminded of the points of morality more then from a fellow human :D, funny locations, easter eggs, Fane's view of the world, and his strange experiences being a lesser being :D.. - So much to explore, and being rewarded for being dilligent or observant of the lore and people's relations (but not much of the surrounding, as you now know). Or not, just go your own hacky-slashy way, you will have fun too. - Probably some replayability with the different characters, the game is huge as are the numbers of approaches you can take, but still, you might not want to play this beast after 200+ hours in it again.

Larian turned gold to lead, but this game is probably worth it, provided that you know what you do.  First off, choose wisely your play level. I chose tactician as a veteran of RPG. I was well served. Indeed, tactician it is! But it doesn't say that you should also scratch every single little advantage that you can (steal as much as possible, stack on potions etc.) in order to be well prepared for the last fight. It also doesn't say that you shouldn't expect your characters to be heroic! Indeed, in many situations at that level you will have to resort to cheesy tactics such as some characters fleeing the combat to recover skill timers, heal, then come back while the combat has been frozen because you left one character or invocation hold it... Or by reloading consistently because you were not prepared for a nasty surprise in a combat and had nothing left to deal with it; so you reload, come back with smart prepositionning and the combat will go smoothly. I remember a fight against some outrageous horror -helped by numerous cronies, all of them more powerful than my characters despite being one level above-, which I easily lost head to head, then won after reloading, placing my characters far enough, engaging with invocations and keeping my characters far enough -actually out of combat- that I could always cast a new invocation when one died. I finally won that fight without a scratch. Smart ? sure. Pleasurable ? Hardly.  So unless you like going very slowly, always moving like there is a fight at the next step (or reloading often), managing inventories to be sure each character has the absolute best equipment, has the necessary consumables,  and so on (i.e. total micromanagement), skip the tactician level. At normal level, the game is going to be challenging enough for most players. Especially the last combat, which I never finished -I have done quite well in the first part, but am hopelessly outnumbered in the second part. I probably know what is wrong, but I won't be going back batching the potions that I am missing, respecing my characters to more useful stats, traits and spells, changing runes for more useful ones etc. you get the picture for tactician level.- So, I won't know the end of the story line I chose, and I won't change my storyline just so the last combat is easier. That's a bit sad.  And NO: YOU CANNO'T CHANGE THE DIFFICULTY LEVEL DOWN! That's a real shame!  Also, there is no excuse for larian in turning an excellent character development/combat system into the mediocre thing that it has become. In that respect, Original Sin 1 was way better. The current system has clearly been designed in order to foil the player and outrageously favor the opponents. You cannot inflict secondary effects (blinding, stunned etc.) as long as the target has magical or physical armor (a new protection that comes above your hit points.) This means that the first rounds of combat are always going to be damage dealing: you won't have any crowd control coming until you've done some attrition first. Worse: the system favors teams which choose a damage type and stick to it. I made the mistake of wanting a balanced party: the result is that I am too weak for the last fight. Actually in some fights, I had characters standing aside, watching the combat go because they did not deal the right kind of damage...  After all this has been said, I still recommend this game because the story looks good, the world is well developped and generally speakig as RPG go, it stands on the top if you don't fall into the trap where I fell.  EDIT: I finally found the courage to do what I said I wouldn't do, and of course finish the game. As expected, I had to respec my characters, and decided to go for lone wolf. The advantage in lone wolf lies not in the power of the characters (they indeed are stronger, but you have overall less firepower), but in the fact that you don't have to bother about the survival or such and such character, as well as reducing the drain on your consumables (you use two instead of four for a similar effect.) The fight was easy [SPOILERS (light) AHEAD] mostly for use of the special tea sold by Mrs Kremm, combined with at least +50% full elemental protection potions and five star dinner -i.e. all elemental damage did heal me, which both let me remove most healing spells as well as use my own offensive spells for healing-, the pawn and duck duck goose (for good movement, not mentioning spells.) Other talents which I thought would help did not (guerilla) [END SPOILERS] ; I changed my main character from pure mage to hybrid melee (fighter) / mage, helped by an archer/assassin ; as explained above, this was a choice to favor physical damage over magical damage, choice made necessary by the difficulty of that fight. I of course had to spend considerable time to prepare the characters and the consumables, buy or craft the required potions and books as well as redistribute equipment. The trouble is that in that fight I did not recognize the character(s) I played consistently from the beginning (no respec before the end), which is annying (to say the least) for a RPG! The other trouble is of course that I could not have to feeling that the hero was well above the other contenders to deserve my victory. Indeed, the stats of all other human opponents were consistently above those of the hero. Understand who can!

--No spoilers--  Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a game that at first kind of looks meh. The graphics might not appeal to some and others might find the spells and other things clunky at first. But the game is rather quite the opposite of those problems. It's a great game but a game you need to get invested into. I enjoy the combat greatly because there is so much to do and so much to interact with. I also really enjoy sidequests and this game has a ton of them. There is a lot to explore and discover.  At the time of writing this I have about 116 hours and still haven't completed the game. Do not think that it tastes that long to finish a campaign, but merely there is a lot to look and do. One of the problems of the game isn't even the game's fault. It is the players. Some people drop games or get to busy to continue.  I've restarted the main campaign about a dozen times (sometimes my fault) before finding someone that would go all the way. But it really is a blast when you are with a friend or friends.  Though I must say the crafting system is kind of lackluster when it comes to anything but potion making. I barely use it unless it's to make potions. Some places are annoying to deal with and that one battle with oil slugs or whatever they were called didn't do my computer any good. Loading screens are longish but you barely have to do any load screens at all because the entire map is just available to you. The dialogue and narrator are also one of my favorite parts of the game.   Overall? I recommend it highly! It's absolutely worth it.

I have sunk a lot of hours into the first Divinity: Original Sin on console and worried how my epierience with the game might change on the PC. But the controller support has been incredible according to my co-op partner and I personally prefer PC controls now.   This is one of those games that you can brew a tea while playing, which is something I can respect. But then forget that it is there because you forgot for one turn that undead heal off of poison so you are too busy white knuckling your mouse to drink it. I've been there, it's not the best of times.  But real talk, this is one of my top 5 games of all time. The dialogue ranges from tense and engaging to absolutely hysterical and whimsical. The two Divinity: Original Sin games take the concept of co-op rpg to a different level. It allows you to play the game exactly the way you want to. The build variety is incredible and nobody in the party is ever feeling like a deadweight. Sometimes the wizard has better gear or the assassin has found better spells. Some builds scale better into the end of the game then others, but none of that even really matters if you are playing this game, because at the end of the day, this game is just endless ammounts of fun and excitement. The feeling of making a clutch play in this game and thinking with portals in the middle of combat to use your spells in a way you never had before is a glorious feeling. And then there is also saving your co-op partner with a spell or two they haven't seen yet. There are just many good times to be had here. I love this game, and I hope you will as well.

- Prenote - This is a review from the perspective of someone who does not usually enjoy this style of RPG; I usually play action-oriented RPG's that don't use a turn-based combat system (Dark Souls, Skyrim, Devil May Cry, God of War, Metal Gear Solid, etc.). So, this is not a review that should be read by anyone who is a larger fan of these older-style RPG games - waste of your time. If you are one of those people, buy the game, it's right up your alley.   As for those who are new to this genre but heard of this game through glowing reviews and maybe friends, here's what I have to say.   TLDR; The combat is, surprisingly, the most entertaining part, while the story's pacing and general creativity are top-notch for the genre, but comparatively predictable, cliche-ridden, and generic for those who care. Leveling and playstyle customization is awesome, but the world does a not-so-subtle job of locking you out of areas until you've hit the next level.    The Combat: 9/10  I'm a fan of action-packed games with tense, reactionary elements and high mechanical skillcaps, so moving over to Divinity 2's much more tactical and strategic system set itself up as an obstacle for my enjoyment of the game. Surprisingly, it turned out to be my favorite part of the game - combos, while sometimes stale depending on your party comp (running 3 out of your 4 with Battle Stomp gets a little dull against anything less than 3 enemies), prove to be an exciting and rewarding aspect that I had thought gimmicky at first. Mobility is, per the usual in almost all games, the best abilities to have off of cooldown, but nevertheless, almost all builds and classes are very viable in almost every situation (though I don't recommend taking 4 characters who all deal physical damage exclusively).   The Characters: 8/10   Characters and dialogue are all excellently written, though some stand out far more than others (The Red Prince is an absolute must-have, both for combat capabilities and sheer brilliance in writing). Voice acting is additionally top of the line, though, as is the case with most RPG's, you'll start to notice the same person raising the pitch of their voice to act as another character. The singular downfall is that aside from the suggested companion characters that are brought with the player at the beginning of the game, companion options are bleak, with other companions being generic mercenaries hired for coin. It felt odd to see the original, suggested companions popping up throughout the story, as though they could not be replaced with Act-unique new characters. I don't want Beast the Dwarf, I want someone new. But in all seriousness, take. The. Red. Prince.   The World: 7/10   I have little to praise, but little to shame either. The world is top-notch, but falls into an unfortunately generic fantasy RPG rut, with little thematic or aesthetic originality. To some degree, this can be excused as Larian was working off of their previous entry in the series - however, without a strong terrain/world thematic foundation, there wasn't much that surprised me. Without rules of theme set, there is little that doesn't seem out of place, and little that does seem like it belongs any more than the next setpiece.   The Story: 6/10   This suffered from the same issue as the World - though superb in it's own right, the story is unoriginal and fails to make any significant impact on the player besides helping to push them along an ascenion route that summarizes the player's ultimate goal as "become stronger". This is hard to avoid when the premise of an RPG of this style is to make the player an all-powerful wrecking machine, but it's also a destination that I wish RPG's in this genre would have the nads to diverge from. I know where the story wants to put me from the very beginning cutscene, and though I don't have any qualms with knowing the good guys win, I at least want it to be less obvious.   Overall, Divinity: Original Sin 2, in the perspective of a non-RPG player, is a strong first game to break into the genre, but worries me to whether I'll like others, seeing as how lauded this one is.   To someone who doesn't typically play these games, I say wait for a sale - you might not get past the slightly weak opening segment.   To someone who does typically play these games, you'll love this one. Gung ho.

6/27/2018  Right, so thus far I've played for ~17 hours and I gotta say, this game is great.  So why is it great?  I started this game expecting my years of experience with rpgs to make this game a breeze. Oh boy was I wrong. This game punishes you for not equiping both you and your teammates. DON'T FORGET TO EQUIP YOUR TEAMMATES.  for the record I was playing it on classic difficulty(normal).  All I did in these 17 hours can be summed up in 2-3 sentances. Later on I found out that I could have done the progress I did in those 17 hours in less than 6 hours. So here's what happened to those interested:  I got on a prison island and met up with a few companions, I got equipment and got myself arrested hoping to get into the fort joy castle. I did and from there I escaped through the front gate. Then I met up with the resistance and got a superweapon to destroy the enemy superweapon in order to get a ship to get out of the island.  In any other game this would take place in the span of 1-2 hours and would have no player control. You would be doing a sort-of "tutorial" and by the end of it you would be set free (kind of like in every elder scrolls game). However in this one the tutorial is you playing. You are trying to get off the island, the game is not going to help you, giving you waypoints and saying "HEY DUMBASS GO TO THE GUY I'VE MARKED ON YOUR MAP AND TALK TO HIM AND THEN COME BACK". The game is going to tell you to do something and you have to figure out how/when/with what to do it. Like for instance 1 quest generally is listed as a jouranl. and as you gain more information about how you can complete the task/quest that journal fills up with info that you've learnt through exploring/conversing/fighting. It doesn't show you a magic waypoint to your next objective, nor does guide you as to what you should do(or what you will encounter). After escaping the fort I found 150000 different (WAYYY easier) ways of escaping the fort that could've saved me like 5-7 hours of playing. This is one of those games where there are so many ways you can do something you will probably never see all the things you could've done in each given scenario. It kind of reminds me of a more refined "Hitman: Blood Money" in that way.  I haven't touched the coop, nor Gamemaster, nor Arena modes, however that is what I'm going to be diving in once I complete my playthrough and master the mechanics.  GameMaster I'm really interested in, seeing as I love the idea of actually playing a DnD game with actual game mechanics and a GM.

Divinity Original Sin 2 is an isometric computer RPG in the tradition of old-school pen & paper RPGs (such as Dungeons & Dragons) brought to the digital age.  In DOS2, you'll take on the role of one of six characters (or create one of your own) to explore, interact with friends and foes through interesting dialogue options, and engage in tactical turn-based combat encounters.  Whether you build your own character or play through the story of one of the six Origin characters, you'll be able to fully customize your character by choosing skills, assigning attributes, and picking talents that all synergize to make interesting and unique builds that change your options for interacting with the environment, with NPCs, and in combat.  As you play, you'll recruit the aid of up to three other characters (chosen either from the remaining available Origin characters or hired from a mercenary captain), but be warned; while choosing to travel with fellow Origin characters will open up new and interesting storylines to explore, your goals will sometimes be at odds. Like your main character, you'll also be able to customize your companions, creating a party that can stand up to the challenges that await you.   Alternatively, play with up to three additional players, and explore Rivellon together in jolly cooperation.  Although DOS2 is not procedurally-generated, and encounters are placed and not random, the choices you make and actions you take have long-term consequences that can dramatically alter your play experience, but in a way that feels surprisingly natural - even intended!  DOS2 is complex, and what seems intimidating to start quickly becomes a deep and engaging experience that both challenges you mechanically and drives you on to experience more and more of the story it has to offer.

This game is fantastic, let me get that out of the way first.  It has a gripping story and an extremely fun intro sequence that will keep you glued to your seat for hours. The story you start with is really just a set piece you have to follow, but there are tons of quests hidden within the world that you will find by accident most of the time. This game truly embodies what it is to be an RPG. It simply let's you do everything you want(within reason and without going to an A rating), you can be a hero or villain, coward or brave fool, sneaky assassin or loud barbarian, etc. etc. There really are too many scenarios to think of, but the game really makes you feel like you are in control of your future in the game.  There are some problems though, certain boss battles are kind of cheap since the bosses have to do certain things so they can one shot you or skip party members leaving you to watch your team die one by one. The second act is by far strongest, totally eclipsing the 3rd act and making you kind of have to drag yourself to the end. A few of the quest lines seem broken tbh, there were certain times a quest didn't end or just didn't proceed for no reason, even though these were small side quests I was still frustrated at not having been able to finish them. Also, there is no autosave feature, so sometimes you'll get into a fight you can't escape from and are too weak to win, so you'll die and reset to a save file from a half hour ago because you're not really used to saving, not gamebreaking, but extremely annoying, especially in a game like this. Other than that I don't really have any complaints.  I really recommend buying it, I guarantee you'll get your money's worth very easily and have a great time developing your Godwoken into true Gods!!!  Right now I'm eagerly waiting for whatever expansion is to come.

What can I say about Divinity? It is a series I remember stumbling upon ages ago, but never really gave a fair chance. After playing D:OS2 I can safely say that was a shame. What really makes the game shine however is its story elements. OS2 has such a fleshed out story with options that branch out in so many ways that it really seems absurd at times. Rarely can I say that a game really made me question each interaction I had with the various characters strewn throughout. In my time playing there have been many moments where I participated in an event, met a NPC, or even stumbled upon a secret that made me think about what I wanted to do the next time around. What if I befriended so and so NPC next time? What happens if I don't help that one guy? What if steal the key and check that basement? Absolutely great game, I would highly recommend it to anyone who likes games with powerful storytelling.

TL;DR: Extremely well designed RPG overall, Great visual/graphics, Engaging and well written story, deep, fun, and challenging gameplay, would totally recommend this game if you are a fan of the genre  Aesthetics (Graphics, Visuals, Music): Absolutely top notch- the amount of detail in this game is astounding on a visual level. From each character looking fantastic, to the detail in spells and animation, to the level of beauty in the environment, overall this game looks great. The only drawback to this is that it's more demanding, resource-wise, than similar games. The music is also phenomenal and really follows the mood of the story without being too intrusive.  Gameplay: the combat system in this game is pretty similar to other CRPGs, but goes above and beyond. My personal favorite touch is the amount with which the environment can contribute to combat scenarios. There is a small learning curve which basically makes it the Dark Souls of- just kidding. There is a weird issue with balance where being overleveled by just 1 or 2 levels makes some fights trivial while being underleveled by 1 or 2 levels makes some fights annoyingly difficult, but overall, the game seems to do a good job of leveling the playing field... unless you're like me and added a mod that doubles the amount of enemies. One thing that is really underappreciated is how civil abilities affect gameplay. Characters have to balance environment and gear interactions, stealth skills, luck, and persuasion/bartering all in one pool of points. This can lead to balanced jack of all trades (master of none) characters, or min-max characters. This game also allows a lot of freedom in how to play by deciding lone wolf or travelling with a full party and by allowing you to constantly respec yourself and your companions.  Story: Extremely deep and interesting. I have found myself underwelmed by  lot of RPG stories as of late, thut this game was definitely an exception. Each of the comanions/prebuilt characers have their own stories which are fairly interesting but the main story and most of the side quests are captivating. There seems to be just enough instruction that you have an idea what to do, but this game will definitely not hold your hand and tell you exatly where to go. You can get lost or have absolutely no idea where to go, but it doesn't take a lot to get you back on track. Decently replayable - story length can be 30-70 hours depending on how into the story and side quests you get.  Notes: I haven't tried the multiplayer or GM mode yet

6/27/2018  Right, so thus far I've played for ~17 hours and I gotta say, this game is great.  So why is it great?  I started this game expecting my years of experience with rpgs to make this game a breeze. Oh boy was I wrong. This game punishes you for not equiping both you and your teammates. DON'T FORGET TO EQUIP YOUR TEAMMATES.  for the record I was playing it on classic difficulty(normal).  All I did in these 17 hours can be summed up in 2-3 sentances. Later on I found out that I could have done the progress I did in those 17 hours in less than 6 hours. So here's what happened to those interested:  I got on a prison island and met up with a few companions, I got equipment and got myself arrested hoping to get into the fort joy castle. I did and from there I escaped through the front gate. Then I met up with the resistance and got a superweapon to destroy the enemy superweapon in order to get a ship to get out of the island.  In any other game this would take place in the span of 1-2 hours and would have no player control. You would be doing a sort-of "tutorial" and by the end of it you would be set free (kind of like in every elder scrolls game). However in this one the tutorial is you playing. You are trying to get off the island, the game is not going to help you, giving you waypoints and saying "HEY DUMBASS GO TO THE GUY I'VE MARKED ON YOUR MAP AND TALK TO HIM AND THEN COME BACK". The game is going to tell you to do something and you have to figure out how/when/with what to do it. Like for instance 1 quest generally is listed as a jouranl. and as you gain more information about how you can complete the task/quest that journal fills up with info that you've learnt through exploring/conversing/fighting. It doesn't show you a magic waypoint to your next objective, nor does guide you as to what you should do(or what you will encounter). After escaping the fort I found 150000 different (WAYYY easier) ways of escaping the fort that could've saved me like 5-7 hours of playing. This is one of those games where there are so many ways you can do something you will probably never see all the things you could've done in each given scenario. It kind of reminds me of a more refined "Hitman: Blood Money" in that way.  I haven't touched the coop, nor Gamemaster, nor Arena modes, however that is what I'm going to be diving in once I complete my playthrough and master the mechanics.  GameMaster I'm really interested in, seeing as I love the idea of actually playing a DnD game with actual game mechanics and a GM.

As with its predecessor from 2014, Divinity: Original Sin II's setting remains the D&D-infused fantasy land of Rivellon, but the clock has been moved forward centuries from the original game so you don't need any familiarity with the backstory to quickly get up to speed with what's going on. You take on the role of a Sourceror, a name referring to those that draw arcane power from a mystic material called Source. This substance is controversial in Rivellon, because using it seems to inadvertently summon interdimensional monsters known as Voidwoken. Deploy Source powers and these bizarre creatures show up to kill everyone in sight. Because of this, you're viewed as a danger to society by the Magisters, a governing body of inquisitors and warriors who claim to serve the Divine Order and protect society by rounding up and "curing" Sourcerors.  This epic saga is a big undertaking. Expect to use up the better part of 60-70 hours to complete the main quest line and a good portion of the many side quests. The story isn't just extensive, though; it's detailed and gripping, largely due to how it avoids good-versus-evil fantasy archetypes common to RPGs.   The Good     Spectacular scope and depth that could easily keep you playing for over 100 hours      Detailed plot set in a world that seems completely lived in and authentic      Expansive tactical combat with seemingly unlimited options based on spells, skills, gear, and ever-changing battlefield terrain      Deep character creation and customization options due to extensive ability and skill options      Beautiful visuals along with an evocative musical score and impressive voiced dialogue   The Bad     Confusing journal makes it hard to keep track of individual quests and the plot

This game is, by far, the best RPG game I have ever played in the history of all my 20 years of gaming. I cannot wait to put thousands of hours into it. The only issue I have with it, however, is how limited the character creation system is, but I guess no game can be absolutely perfect. That said, here's why I love this game and will enjoy playing it for likely years to come.  The story:  I've only ever gotten so far as ACT II, but even still, the story in that time is so rich it'd put the CEO of the Amazon corporation to shame. The openess of the story makes for excellent roleplay elements. It'll keep you hooked and wanting more and more the further you delve into it.  Gameplay:  The only class restrictions are literally how you choose to build your character because of where you choose to put your attribute and ability points. That sky's the limit, and any kind of character imaginable can be built and played in this game. I would even go so far as to say this game is the closest game to a D&D simulator there can be without actually being D&D.  Combat:  Generally, I'm not a fan of turn-based combat outside of games like CIV games, but the system for this game really takes the cake. While the combat is turned based, the way it's set up to function is absolutely marvelous. The great minds at Larian Studios definitely didn't go wrong with it--at all.  Customization:  This game is open to steam workshop elements and modding. It also has a Dungeon Master aspect that allows you to create and run custom campaigns for you and four of your friends. However, I recommend playing the game as the vanilla version before adding mods to it, as some of them can be quite game breaking. Trust me, though, you absolutely won't regret it.  All-in-all, this game is pretty much perfect minus my only aforementioned problem with character customization. Other than that, I would definitely recommend this game and have absolutely nothing but good things to say about it! I give this game a 9.9/10.

Do you like strategic roleplaying games like Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, Arcanum, Fallout 1 & 2, Dragon Age (the first one), or XCOM 2?  Well, you're going to love this.  This game combines the roleplaying depth of Dungeons & Dragons with a strategic feeling similar to XCom 2. Practically speaking, what this means is that outside of combat, you can do damn well near anything you can think of. In combat, you can do the same. If you want to break into that house, kill that lady, steal that gold, and escape into the night, you can. If you want to be the daring hero, and save shackled stowaways on a sinking ship, you can. This game gives you the freedom to truly explore the "RP" factor of Roleplaying games. Very few games these days can hold a candle to the amount of roleplaying this game encourages.   I think a number of groups of Dungeons and Dragons players will likely abandon tradtional and even virtual play, and just move their games over to Divinity: Original Sin 2. It's easy to learn, hard to master - not unlike D&D - and it's also aesthetically gorgeous in both music and graphics. Can't recommend this game enough. Buy it.

I don't ever do reviews normally because I always think, why the heck would anyone be interested in what you've got to say?! lol! But this is how strongly I feel about this game!   A bit about me ('cos hey this is what you came to read right?! Nah, I just thought if you're like me you might enjoy this game too) I'm a 37 yr old female gamer and I love games ranging from GTA:V, Mass Effect, Battlefield, CoD, The Elder Scrolls Online, Skyrim, Dishonoured, God of War, The Witcher 3, Final Fantasy to Stardew Valley, Command and Conquer, Tropico etc, as well as all the retro Nintendo classics on NES, SNES, N64 and Gamecube etc.  So I've got a pretty eclectic mix of games I like, and I'm definitely not a gaming pro, more a casual gamer who just happens to get absolutely addicted to great games!  I stumbled on this one day browsing my queue and I'm beyond happy I did.  I actually think the storyline's ten times better than Skyrim (and boy do I loooooove Skyrim!).  The graphics are stunning and the music is so on point it's unreal. I've sank over 130 hrs into DOS:2 and if I didn't work full-time for a living I'd have probably sank in triple that amount, this is how engaging I've found it so far!   From having played games like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and Neverwinter Nights back in the day, DOS:2 immediately caught my eye as I fancied a nostalgia trip.... but damn it was SO much more than that! The narration is brilliantly engaging, witty and fantastically acted, and the love that Larian have put into building their characters backstories is blindingly obvious and unparalleled.  There's so much depth in there and it's so well padded out that I honestly can't fault it in the slightest.  Larian just became one of my favourite studios and I wish I'd known about DOS:2 when they were securing funding over on Kickstarter, because hell yeah I would have backed them!  The only thing I struggled with to begin with was the difficulty, in that modern games tend to spoon feed us tidbits and tips on what we should be doing in a game, they're full of map-markers and quest highlights on the map etc. specifically guiding us to the people and places we need to see, the tasks we need to do.  DOS:2 on the other hand demands that you think on your feet and outside the box! Sure it has a journal function with your quests loosely written in (actually in a journal format though), but it's absolutely down to you to work out how to accomplish that quest and there's zero hand holding.  But to be honest with you, it's actually something I've come to love about this game, for once it's a game that actually really requires to start using your brain, otherwise you're going to miss key elements of a fantastic story.  Enough waffling from me, just do yourself a favour and if you love RPGs of any kind, buy this! - I'm over 130 hrs in and I'm on Act 4 already looking forward to my next play through!

tl;dr:  Divinity OS2 is one of the best RPG's and one of the best Co-Op games out right now, and quite possibly the best game I have played in years.  A friend of mine got me this game as a Christmas gift, and I have not been able to put it down since. I enjoyed Divinity OS1 before, but this game manages to outdo it in most aspects still.   The story is amazing. It truly makes you feel like every small decision you make matters, and changes both the course of the game, the way your characters personality forms and how they interact with party members and the world in general(and obviously how they react to you as well).   Most if not all dialogue is fully voiced by great voice actors(including the narrator), the sound track is atmospheric and immerses you straight into the fantasy world, and the graphics and world design are gorgeous.   When I played the OS1 for the first time the slow-paced combat kind of turned me off at first (I thought it was quite hard to survive, and kind of confusing), but once I got more into it I grew to like it, and with Divinity OS2 all my doubts about the turn based combat have vanished. It is a lot of fun to plan out your next moves with your friend. The game wants you to be creative and tactical in combat, so you better not try to run head first into every fight, or else you will probably end up dying many times.Rather you will often use the environment to your advantage( which reacts to pretty much anything you do ) applying status effects, luring enemies away to overwhelm them in numbers and combining elements with your party members to cause havoc.   The companions have rich stories, are fully voiced and quite interesting (I had a hard time picking a follower because they're all quite cool).   That's pretty much all there is to say: if you like (Old-School) RPG's and don't mind the slower paced more tactical combat system, this is probably the best game out there right now.

This is a game I see myself replaying multiple times in the future.

This game somehow reminds me of Deus Ex and Fallout/Skyrim in that you can accomplish certain tasks in many different ways, which is most evident in the tags system in dialogue. However, in this game, the character you choose/make, the build you create, and the companions that follow you feed into the choices you will make, the way you will fight, and the way you play the game moreso than any game I've played before. This game really puts the "role-playing" in RPG. Also props for taking away my handholds, and, for the most part, getting rid of the giant arrow pointing me where to go and just teling me what to do through dialogue, exploration and experimentation.  Bad: Some of the UI and the save system annoy me: I have accidentally walked somewhere instead of reviving a teammate countless times, and one has to get used to quicksaving a lot. This is a good game and you should buy it.  ...  Now if you actually want the REASONS why, rather than trusting my impeccable judgment...  Music: AAA+ Graphics: Good and easy to read, amazing design on a lot of stuff. Performance: Pretty good, high settings on a medium-tier setup and it runs just smooth except for one or two rare places where a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of things are happening at once.  And then there's the gameplay and writing. Now, the writing has some ups and downs, but mostly ups. There are one or two places where they tried a bit too hard to make something gross, or got a bit too flowery on the prose, but by and large, the writing works. If you hate a character, you can tell it's because the writers wanted you to feel that way about them, not because the writers couldn't figure out how to make them sympathetic. Storyline's interesting and has enough twists to keep you interested, but with enough info that they're not Shyamalan-esque, rather, you have a good shot at guessing them ahead of time if you're observant, which is satisfying.  The gameplay is... if you liked the original Original Sin's gameplay, take that, then improve it in literally every way. And also prepare to be punished, viciously, if you're playing on Tactician mode(which of course you are, you want the most challenge out of this, don't you?) but encounters rarely feel *frustratingly* difficult. The game will happily let you wade into fights or areas that are way out of your depth, so sometimes you need to step back and gain some levels or gear in other places first, but unless you're actively sabotaging yourself with a build you know to be terrible and have no synergies, there's always a way, it just requires you to think creatively and maybe not engage enemies that are four levels above you AND outnumber you two to one.  The only downsides is that the game is a BIT buggy. Occasionally some fights will hang on start because enemies won't figure out they need to take their turn(only had this happen once in close to 100 hours of play, mind you), some quests won't finish properly(probably because you can sometimes start quests by finishing them or picking them up halfway through their storyline by stumbling on a quest-vital NPC or note), the journal is a bit useless and something is VERY wrong with the lizardman consulate area.  Also loading times in the second area, the Reaper's Coast area, are a bit atrocious due to the size of the area. Even on an SSD.  Still, cosmetic issues, for the most part. GET THIS GAME.

first serious review in my steam career!   As this games is being hyped AF currently i wanted to add my (more critical) perspective.  Highly anticipated sequel to Larian Games' Divinity: Original Sin 1 that continues the pros and cons of the first iteration. Divinity: Original Sin 2 has been in early access and was recently released to steam as "full" title.   Pros:  - good artdesign and graphics  - highly polished, no crashes, bugs, solid performance  - multiplayer (2-4 players) easily set up via steam overlay  - good voiceacting covers more or less all dialogues in the game and the majority of the dialogues are written well  - vast amount of races and classes to choose from during character creation  - heaps of abilities to utilize in combat - fights are highly tactical (different armor classes, combination of elements like water and eletricity) and quite difficult which makes them very engaging  - lots of hidden secrets to discover in the world (caves, shortcuts, loot chests, etc. etc.)  - multiple ways to solve quests (sneaking, slaying, talking)  - neat crafting system  - intense dialogue systems with various dialogue options and different outcome based on your dialogue choice    Cons:  - no "visible" character progression on level up as new abilities are exclusively acquired via skill-books that are (rng) looted from enemies or the vicinity leading to the effect that your whole gang levels up but you essentially use the same skills for 5-6 levels or even longer - that can get really boring and grindy eventually  - 0 player guidance which can cause confusion and feeling overwhelmed (quests,  - unfair design decisions, i.e. resurrection of fallen party members post-combat needs to be done with scrolls that are very expensive and hard to get; this greatly slows the whole flow down (note: im certain there is a resurrection spell that can be learned, but you need to find it based on rng - see point above)  - overall sense of "low powered fantasy" as your gang is wearing rag armor and no helmets even after 10 hours into the game (which also intensifies the difficulty)  - larian games is famour for their "humour" - i sometimes find this style of homour "childish" and i think it doesnt really fit into a violent, medieval style world but that of course is personal gusto   all in all a very good RPG with lots of clever ideas, highly functional mechanics and solid storytelling. it does however fall short on character progression and should sometimes offer more guidance for players.   8/10

To say that this is a great game, actually does it a disservice, it is a phenomenally made game with amazing RPG elements and spot on tactical gameplay. A few key gear purchases and suddenly I was taking out fights that I had an incredibly difficult time before.  The combat does a great job of making you feel powerful while never making it feel easy.  Your tactics matter.  From your choices of companions (and what specializations they have) to the positioning on the battlefield, to trying to create your own ambush instead of getting ambushed is just amazingly done.  The game does not hand hold you along, but at the same time it does not feel hard to keep up with all the different quests and side missions that you have on your plate.  Not every fight is meant to be tackled the first time you see it and the game rewards you for taking out something in an ingenious way with an every increasing power level on your gear.  You are always advancing in one way or another.  I never write reviews, this is probably my first so hopefully that says something.  Such an amazing game, do yourself a favor and buy this!

Fantastic strategy RPG that doubles as a platform for online D&D.  Pros: -80 to 100 hour campaign -Massive replay value -Fun and creative turn-based strategy combat -Completely free-form leveling system -After the beginning area you can respec all your characters for free forever -Every line of dialogue is voice-acted, complete with an amazing narrator -Comes bundled with a complete creation kit you can use to make mods, maps, and campaigns -Easy to use co-op, plus a GM mode. -You can kill anyone you want. -No forced morality system. -Quests are very creative and usually have different and interesting outcomes.  Cons: -Tactician mode (hard difficulty) requires you to cheese most fights -Usable items you pick up will automatically be placed on your hotbar, cluttering it unless you manually disable that option -Some quests can be bugged if you accidentally do things before the game expected you to. It's never game breaking, but it can be annoying having unfinished quests cluttering your log. -Ambient voice acting gets very annoying, especially if you are at a vendor sorting out your items to sell and you have to hear the same line from nearby NPC's over and over. -Sometimes it's hard to select specific targets if there's a lot of things near eachother, and the slightest movement of your mouse can accidently change your target just as you cast your ability.   All in all, one of the best RPG's to come out in a long time and I highly recommend it.

At first I was hesitant at getting this. It looks great, and like a lot of fun, but maybe not worth the price. I thought maybe I'd pick up the game on a sale or something.  But I'm very glad I got it.  The story is very rich and there's so many ways to play. I'm excited for my second and third play throughs.   You can steal from anybody, kill anyone, befriend NPCs, talk to your followers if you choose to have them, and each story is different from character creation. Each race is treated differently, you have different dialogue options if you're an Outlaw, or Scholar, or even if you play a smart Wizard, you can persuade people with your smarts, or intimidate people with your strength.   The combat is very fun, and comboing spells and attacks is awesome.  Classes aren't really set in stone either. If you're a Fighter but decide you want to shock people, or grow some wings, you can very much do so.   And the GM mode is amazing.   As a Game Master for D&D games, I've always wanted a game to play it in, to immerse the players, and let them explore with out having to explain every small detail. And this game does it very well. You can create custom items, NPCs (even down to what hat they wear), allies, and customize the pre set maps the game gives you. I would honestly buy a DLC that includes more maps. But there are plently right now, I'm just afraid that through multiple play throughs we'll all think "Oh, this map again."  This game is a masterpiece, but it's not perfect.  The combat is very hard, even on the easiest difficulty it sometimes feels like I need to kill a couple NPCs who don't deserve it so I can level up and continue the story. And sometimes this makes the game feel linear. I don't know if I'm missing something, or I chose bad classes for my party, but either way that's a big down side for me.  That being said, at the time of posting this review I'm 71 hours in, and I havent even completed my first play through, which is a good thing. I'm taking my time, exploring the world, talking to every NPC and living the world.  UPDATE (very minor spoilers):  I finished the game, and I have to say while the ending was good, it was very buggy. I was unable to use res scrolls, enemies would teleport everywhere, and some other minor things.  Arx also felt very bland for what it could have been. Driftwood and all of Reaper's Coast felt huge, and there was so much story there, but Arx... You were there for one thing, and that was to beat the game. I tried to find more to do there, I tried to find side quests, just anything, but there was nothing. Maybe I missed stuff, maybe I didn't. Either way I feel the game no longer deserves my original score of 8.5/10.  8/10

Okay, I've been holding off on reviewing this for the game to be fully released. I felt that making a review of an unfinished product would be unfair to the company and their hard work. With that being said...  This game is a single/multiplayer RPG that features "competitive co-op", in which you play one of several pre-made characters OR a custom character. From my experience the custom characters have far less story and interactions than the pre-made characters. This is because your race and your origin are one in the same. I feel like this is a lost oppurtunity and makes all the custom characters feel a little more samey than if you could be a dwarf sent to assassinate someone or a lizard that's also posessed by some sort of ethereal being like a demon. Instead we're left with the custom characters having nothing unique about them other than their racial traits. To combat this, the pre-made characters can be of any class and have any ability. Which allows you to play any class you want while retaining the amazing work put into their pre-made stories.   UNFORTUNATELY, there isn't a premade character of each race. There are no undead dwarves, undead lizards, or undead elf companions, Which sucks, since my favorite race is the undead elf (for Corpse Eater on an undead).  The crafting system feels a little less intuitive than before and more divorced from the game and it was a feature I kind of overlooked as I quickly forgot all about it. Though you are reminded of it by ONE quest I came across while playing, but beyond that, you'll run around looting EVERYTHING in hopes that combining things in your inventory will produce SOMETHING of use or value but later, usually while selling things in town, you'll completely forget about what you were doing and sell either all of your ingredients only to remember you were saving them for "something".  Beyond these two issues, the gameplay is SOLID! The combat grabs your attention and lets you plan your moves carefully so you can combine abilities and environmental hazards, the voice acting is spot-on, the story is well written and easy to follow. Multiplayer and co-op features a seemless drop-in drop-out system, giving players 2, 3, and 4 control of one (or more) of the companion characters following you around. Multiplayer and singleplayer savegames are interchangable... And the loot. I'm ALWAYS scouring the ENTIRE map for more loot.  Which reminds me, I strongly recommend you read every book and note you find, They sometimes add context to what you see in-game.  So, with all that in mind... Do I recommend this game at it's current sale price of $45? I'm actually torn on this one. I LOVE the game, don't get me wrong. I'm about to go play it RIGHT NOW... but... is it worth $45? That's only $15 less than a AAA game, featuring higher quality graphics, full 3D animation, more cutscenes, a stronger focus on character-integration, usually a more intuitive crafting system, but... it's still a solid RPG and I think EVERY library of RPGs wouldn't be complete without it. SO, to a person who is a die-hard RPG fan, yes... it would totally be worth it but if you're on the fence about this game AT ALL... wait for a sale.

Also the enemies had double the armor you had so they would be able to land spells and cc on you much earlier than you could to them.   With that said, that aspect is still part of the game but to a lesser extent. They added new spells to target certain types of armor and overall, it just feels like I can break through the armor easier and be able to use my spells to their full effect. I don't feel as frustrated anymore and I've actually grown to like the armor system because certain enemies have more or less of certain type of armor. Caster will have lots of magical armor so you want to send in your dude with lots of physical attacks and lock him down.   I can't recommend this game enough. Well lets start off with a brief description of the game. You're a captive on a ship, a Sourceror, one of the most hated people across the land. Your foul magic attracts monstrosities known as the Voidwoken, nightmares from another dimension that seek to claim this world as their own. However, things quickly roll out of hand, and it ends with the ships destruction. Finding yourself on the prison island known as Fort Joy, you discover that you're no ordinary Sourceror; you have the potential to become a GOD. From there, the game plays out quite literally as YOU choose it, be it as a benevolent hero seeking to save the world or as a malicious villain who seeks to gain ultimate power. And, just maybe, you'll find an option that no one else expected, one that takes you through the Void itself... and finding power that scoffs at the Gods themselves.  As you can probably tell, there's a lot of choices to be made in Divinity 2 : Original Sin, and maybe you're thinking "Oh god, it's another one of these games that plays out as a visual novel instead of a rpg". Well if you are thinking that, shut the ♥♥♥♥ up, strap in, and read up ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ because there's quite a bit more to the game than that.   Now, the best part about this game is it's combat system and character progression; there are few other games where I can actually feel the progression of my character and the impact it has on the world around me. For example, in my very first TRUE playthrough of the game, 100% it, I did it with just two characters, both of them basically assassins; it was hard at first of course, but by the end of the game I could clear a room of 12 heavily armored characters with 2 characters and taking no damage. It truly felt powerful, and is one of my favorite gaming playthroughs of all time. So I thought, ♥♥♥♥ it, lets try a magical playthrough, might not be as fun as the first, but we'll get through it. Well. Lets just say a full elementalist party is quite a unique experience. The whole 4 person party felt powerful the entire game, and we destroyed everything in sight that we deemed "Unholy" or "Unclean". Felt ♥♥♥♥ing hilarious the entire way through, and I don't regret a moment of it. For my thrid play through, I went in with a full melee team, and got the exact same results, which has blown me out of the water and clear into the sky; the fact that no matter what kind of team you play you know you'll become a force to be reckoned with is fantastic, and lets you cook up some pretty kooky team compilations. If you don't believe me, go on youtube and look up some of the SOLO builds people can make; they play on the highest difficulty and can quite literally nuke entire areas with a single character. But I digress, that's a bit off topic, and not relevant to this review. So if you've ever felt let down by a characters power or capability, trust me, you won't feel that with this game.  Let's talk diversity for a quick second here. There are 4 main races in the world, the Dwarves, Humans, Elves, and Lizards. Each race has its own unique capabilities, and it's own racial traits, meaning that yes, while you can have a Lizard assassin, making it a human so it have bonus initiative (how soon it gets to move in combat) and extra critical chance (random extra damage) means you'll have an easier time. Or maybe you'll choose a lizard for your geomancer because you have the innate ability to breath fire, and ignite your oil based abilities. A dwarven Inquisitor stands ready to rush into your opponents because they have extra defenses against all forms of damage. And maybe your necromancer is an elf because elves can eat parts of their enemies to learn memories and skills they'd normally never obtain. No matter what it is, you'll find tons of combinations based off of race alone to make a unique and fun character. But is that where it stops? Nope, that's where we're just getting started. See, there is a unique twist you can put on a character; you can make them UNDEAD. Yes, that's right, a skeleton that walks and talks, and which offers other unique pros and cons. For example, an undead character will heal when poisoned, and take damage when healed normally. Skeletons can use their bony fingers as infinite use lockpicks. And most importantly, Skeletons don't have any nasty organs to inhale Deathfog, an uncommon terrain in the game which kills anything that breaths it, meaning that Undead are free to wander through it as they please. The only real downside is having to wear a headpiece at all times. (Which isn't even a downside, like, why would you decide to not wear an important piece of equipment?) But lets say you dislike making all of that troublsome character stuff, you just want to get in and have fun. Well, there are already a ton of premade characters with their own stories and quests to go on if you so choose! There's literally no way to go wrong with making a character in this game!  Hey, we almost missed the most important part of the game, the part where you become a god and stuff! Well friendo, that's what I saved for last because that♥♥♥♥♥♥is called SPOILERS, and I know that some people dislike those. So let it be said now that if you don't want to read any spoilers WHATSOEVER, then you should skip the next paragraph. Cool? Cool.  So as your character progresses through the game, they will discover the ability to use Source to fuel abilities. These are their godly powers, and are only usable by player characters and certain other npcs. This includes the abilites; Bless : Buffs an ally and clears any and all curses that afflict them. Spirit Vision : Is actually free to cast, and lets you temporarily see into the spirit realm, where you can see parts of the past, and even talk with the dead to gain their wisdom. (Or even just to taunt an enemy who bugged you.) Devour : Not it's actual name, but I don't use it often enough to remember it. It's also free to cast. You basically target an enemy corpse (or even just directly target their ghost.) and devour their essence, regaining a source point. Doing this too many times however can mark you with the "Villain" tag, which is not what you want to have on you if you're roleplaying as a benevolent hero. Gate : Again, isn't the true spell name, but works the same as the D&D version, creating a permanent link to another location within range that anyone can go through at any time. It sounds kind of dumb at first, but it lets you pull off some pretty wacky stunts in the game, and I've taken it on every character I've made so far. There are of course tons of other abilities that can be fueled by source points, far too many to list them all here, as each class has a few "Ultimate" abilities that you need source to use. But if you're interested in learning more about these godlike powers, then just look up a class guide and check out their abilities to get an idea of what you can work with!  Alright, well I think that if you've read everything I've said so far, that you'll get the idea I'm trying to tell you. The game's fantastic, and fun to play, especially with friends. One of the best campaigns we had was one where the entire party split up and fought to become the ultimate character. So if you enjoy shennanigans like that, and you love the sound of this game, then take a go at it! I really think that you'll enjoy the hell out of it!

7.5/10  I played Divinity: Original Sin 2 with a group of friends as a Persuasive Lizard, focusing on Summoning and Geomancy. Though the boulders and oil that can be thrown with Geomancy are effective, I initially focused on it to serve as a healer for our Undead tank. Undead are healed by poison, so your party's usual healer can't help them out. However, Geomancy also gave me access to Fortify which I could use to restore physical armor, and Artillery Plant, which was my favorite thing in the game. Artillery plant is a summon that exists in the Geomancy tree, whose level is determined by your Summoning skill. In the game, your most powerful skills cost "source" to cast (sort of a special type of mana). By the end of the game, you will be able to possess three source points at a given time. Source is rare to come by during most of the game, and even towards the end it's not necessarily unlimited. Artillery plant costs a single source point to cast, but then it can cast an extremely powerful spell called "Acid Spores" every two turns, among other strong abilities. If your character were to cast "Acid Spores," instead of the summon, it would cost you two source points every time!  The type of discussion you see above is what makes Divinity: Original Sin 2 so exciting. How can you support the other characters in your party in combat, and what is the optimal way to use your source or action points? If a member of your party has the "Loremaster" ability, you can examine enemies to learn their abilities, talents, and resistances. If an enemy reduces and redirects damage dealt, you may want to attack his friends first. If he has the opportunist talent, you do not want to walk away from melee range as it grants him an attack. If he has a fire resistance of 150%, fire will heal him. You want to constantly take stock of enemy composition and the skills of your party.  If Divinity: Original Sin consisted of a more linear story with more combat encounters, and lasted about 2/3 of its current length, it would be a 10/10 game for me. However, as it stands, I have a few gripes.   Although I'm sure that many players appreciate the ability to complete quests in multiple ways, I just found it frustrating. Some of the solutions are obtuse, and require a lot of poring through documents. Some of the late game puzzles, like pulling levers in a certain order or playing the enormous "pipe dream" game, were just tedious. There are many many quests, and in a multiplayer party it just felt like I was always receiving experience from somewhere because someone in my party was progressing on one of the many many quests in my quest log. While I'm sure some might say that I should've played with a different group of people, there are so many quests with so many solutions that often we made quest progress by aimlessly walking around.   Another issue I had with the title is just how quickly my character advanced. Each character has a maximum of 40 in an attribute, a maximum of 10 in each skill or combat ability, and a maximum of 5 in each civil ability. Each character in our party maxed out at least one of these categories well before the end of the game. In addition, the highest tier of skills in the game become available at level 16, also well before the endgame. Though perhaps others are drawn primarily for the story, this severely hampered my enjoyment of the game. After learning all skills I was interested in, maxing my summoning and my persuasion, I just didn't have as much to look forward to.  I enjoyed most of my time with Divinity: Original Sin 2. The argument could be made that this type of game just isn't for me, but I enjoyed the combat so much that is was worth some of the other irritations.

Highly recommended to fans of rpg and turn based games. Do you need to play the first game or any Divinity title before this? Not at all ,you can learn more about the world as you play along. Play alone (like i do since friends didnt come with the game) or play coop which your friends can drop in and out anytime or get straight into the fight with the PVP Arena mode.    The good stuff:  -Interesting main/side story and meaningful quest (no more of that boring fetch or kill this mobs quest) -Play as 1 of the 6 origin character which have predefined backstory and unique events. -Or create your own and team up with those origin character. -Dynamic relationship system which your companion can either hate/like you or if you like become intimate with -Owh did i mention that you can play as an undead that ripped other people face to use as a mask? (both origin and custom character) -Your choice and action effect the story and the game (so dont think that people will not notice that apple you just stole) -Challenging combat which force you to use every trick up your sleeve (no more potion/scroll etc that you will probably never use till the end) -Do things your way.Be persuasive,do favors or even do the exact opposite of that favor or just kill the guy and loot him its up to you. -Fully voice acted and beautiful soundtrack that fits the theme of the world -Alot of other interesting stuff like crafting,surface effect etc that you can use to your advantage or be use againts you. -Explore the world and be rewarded for it or suffer for it (who knows,you could find a curse helmet that may contain an evil spirit inside it)    The bad and not so bad stuff:  -Bugs,this game is not totally free of them.I havent found any game breaking bugs yet but remember to keep saving every 15-30 min or so.F5 quicksave is your friend here dont relied on autosave to much.  -The combat difficulty can sometimes spike alot that it can be brutal to new players,i suggest starting the game on the easiest mode (Explorer mode) and get a good feel of the game first before jumping on the more harder one like Classic mode.  -The armor system seem to have alot of mix opinion among the community (Its was absent in the first game).What this system does is that you cant apply debuff like stun to the target unless you destroy their magical armor or physical armor depending on the debuff.The good thing  is that it also apply to your party meaning that your 250 physical armor warrior can just go in and cut down those archer at the back without the fear of being knocked down and your party dont have to be feared of being 1 shotted by some enemy mage AoE spells at the start of the fight.The bad  thing is that enemy usually have 2x or sometimes more armor than you,this forced the player to make a burst dmg character to quicky remove that armor which in turn  limiting the player to mix their classes without hurting the dmg potential the character can dish out per turn.   Overall the game get a solid 9/10 from me and 1 of the few game i dont mind paying more money.Unlike some of the game that we get now that doesnt fit the unreasonably high price tag (Looking at you *AAA games*)

TL;DR  7/10 score from my side.  Longer read  - It is a good RPG game. It follows good ways of approaching the genre. And it attempts to fix problems the first game had. - There are some things which still call for improvements. But it's probably not something which will make you hate the game.  Very long read  Awesome:  - Story. Well, this is as much as it states. Who doesn't want to become a divinity? And you decide which path do you take to get there. - Combat geometry. Altitude and different surfaces make it feel great and diverse. You really want to position yourself right. You really want to make use of surfaces or prevent enemies from doing it. And in most of the cases  - you can/ - Voice acting. They have every little dialog covered and I think at least 7-8 different voices, that's great - Game looks. It is about world and is applicable for those who have fairly good PCs. Speaks for itself.  Good - They improved the initiative problem. As any turn-based game, the turn order will make it a problem of stacking the speed/initiative/whatever serves the turn order boost. Here it's no more so much of an issue. - Many immunity talents are removed which is a good decision. It's just too much of a mandatory pick in the first game. - Not such huge power creep. Over the course ov the levels, like till 15-16, you don't feel the exponential numbers growth. So it makes it managable to plan the combat - Minor fixes like ranged weapon influencing bows AND crossbows. It may be not so impressive, but when combined - it leaves a good feeling  Not-so-good (what made it 7 out of 10)  - Cannibalist elves. I mean, yes, one can argue "you live with stereotypes" - and I can't deny it's partly so, but look - if you're taking a race which is invented long before you and make it into something that's completely opposing the perception of majority - it will get tricky. If they would not call these guts-devouring people elves I would have no questions. But it's a bit over the board  - Overall game characters design. Lucky me, I play male characters where appearance means not so much. But I would imagine a disappointment for those who plays female characters. I just wonder how they managed to create face presets which seem to compete each other in ugliness. Oh well - it's about personal tastes, sure - but still.  - Items and loot. It is just too... random. It's hard to find something appealing for your character - you will always have that redundant parameter you want to replace. And may be it's not a problem for those who play a lot, but for 10-15 hours of play it may be an issue  - They removed one of the best things I liked in the first game - the D&D-like saving throws. Instead there are these magic/physical armor concepts which just looks too... simplified and makes many magic abilities weak. Especially if the damage-dealers are physical-type (rangers, fighters)  Overall - I would recommend you this game. It is worth the full price. It has it's flaws, but it follows the best canons of an RPG-type game and it won't leave you disappointed. If you're not so much into customisation and aren't obsessed with the perfection of how your avatar looks - then the visuals of this game is one of the best you can find in the genre. If you're fine with simplification of the effects/counter-effects part of the combat - you'll like the new armor system. But in any case - if you like RPG - you'll like this game

This is a great game with some nearly game-breaking flaws. There were a decent amount of bugs in my playthrough. The combat is mind-numbingly slow. The stories are just okay IMO, maybe that's because there are so many stories going on that it can be hard to fully get into one, maybe it's just a "me" problem. I was tempted to go back and playthrough again, but I'm not very interested at this point, hopefully in the future I will be ready for round two. My playthrough was somewhat completionist (in that I completed every quest I came acrossed), and apparently took a hundred hours. That is a pretty long game! While the play time was long, the story itself felt somewhat short, or stilted. Perhaps it's because there are not that many regions/maps to play, perhaps it was because the slow combat effected the rest of the game so much. I really enjoyed the creative level design and the ability to go about things in a variety of ways, with only one playthrough under my belt I'm sure that I missed a lot of these extra details. There is no throwaway function in the game, which was a breath of fresh air. I expected spirit vision to be a one-and-done or very limited use mechanic but it comes into play all the time.   If they would fix the pace of the combat this game could be vastly improved, hopefully either the developer or modders will come up with a solution. I'd recommend waiting to buy it on sale, especially since the game will probably be in a better condition at that point anyways.

EDIT: Giving this a thumbs up now, not because larian changed anything, though they have fixed a couple of bugs, but because of the mods coming out for it. Larian laid the foundation and gave a great game but the modding community makes it better.    Good game,.   In my opinion the armor system makes the game tedius.  I don't believe it was well thought out.   The way armor works is that each mob has physical armor and magical armor, then they have their health.  No crowd control that deals with physical attributes will work on a mob unless the physical armor is 0.  The same goes for magical armor and crowd control for magical attributes.  Armor also keeps mobs from being hurt, so as long as they have any armor on they won't recieve damage.   For physical armor you destroy it by beating them with weapons and a select number of spells, (remember the effect of those spells won't do anything through) and to destroy magical armor you have to hit it with spells in order for magical effects or damage to be felt.  Once the armor is destroyed you can then damage their health and inflict status effects.  This may sound great but in the end it leads to tedius battles.  Wade in, hit the mob with swords as that is the easiest way to destroy the armor, then crowd control.  There is NO chance a status effect won't work once armor is gone.  The person or NPC is pretty much dead after that.    For me this just ruins the fun of what I have come to love and enjoy about D;OS, being able to expirement with different spells and effects to see how I can control the battlefield, (or be controlled.)  This also means that traps do almost nothing.  I just walk through them because they don't hurt.  Poison, who cares.  Electic field, ok, fire, sounds lovely to stroll through, as long as my armor is ok.  Outside of combat its easy to keep your armor up.  Everything else about the game is fine.  As for me though, I think I'm going to have to wait till a mod comes out that fixes the issues I've talked about which makes me sad since I spent over $150 in order to download and buy the game.  ($44 for game, $60 for data and another $60 when I need more data since I was having to use a tethered phone.)

Narrative: DOS 2 has a true fantasy story. It is one steeped in mystery and pushes the boundaries of creativity.  Each character has a unique subplot completely entangled with the main story. The side quests tie in with the games central themes and main narrative very well. Accordingly, they dont seem out of place or tacked on but are very believeable in the world crafted by larian studios. Music: The music works. It sets the tone quite nicely for the various parts of the world. It goes from epic to playful to somber to tragic in parallel with the envirement or scenario. Gameplay: The gameplay is very strategic with nuanced application. You must defeat intelligent and powerful Antagonists. Your set of abilities can be used envirementaly and you must keep your wits about you for the entirety of the game for both battle and exploration.  Characters: the ensemble cast of main characters each have their own ambitions, dreams, and philosophy. They are not just along for the ride. If you dont want to play as one of them you can create a character whose complexity and depth extends as far as yourself. Most if not all of the NPCs have believable ambitions and reasons for either deterring you or assisting you. there are many factions of npcs and 2/3 of them will seek your destruction depending on your choice so replayability is permitted. I have finished this game once and this is a reflection of that experience.  Since this is truly a great game, I wish everyone to play through and experience its wonders, for that is why I recommend the exploration mode for anyone that is turned off by the difficulty, so they can focus on exploration. I say that because the world and its characters are a spectacle to behold. This is the purest Role Playing Game i have played and I look forward to the future of its developer, Larian Studios.

REVIEW UPDATED AFTER GAME COMPLETION -----------------  +Same excellent, engaging combat system as the first game. Some expanded functionality +Some quality of life UI changes which make everything better +Better skills / attributes system which makes character creation more flexible +VO in the initial release (as opposed to being added in EE of D:OS) +2 player co-op was fun; 4 player co-op is awesome +When I first reviewed this game I said the story was "marginal at best" part way through Act 2. I've since changed my view on this; the characters develop very nicely through the rest of the game, and all of the plotlines of the individual characters tie up really nicely by the end. There were lots of things in the game that really made me say "Wow. These developers really poured their blood and tears into this." However....  -I do feel the game was a bit too long. 160 hours for one playthrough was tedious, and I put the playthrough on pause for a few months and came back to it. I think they could have done without Act 3 entirely, and done a second mega act in Act 4. The playtime also would be significantly mitigated by the below mentioned quality of life changes. -Simple things like: please don't allow lucky charm to roll on equipment. It's super annoying to switch gear / drink alcohol everytime I want to look something. -Still an inventory management simulator. Developers should really break out crafting ingredients into its own menu / sorting system. I spent a lot of time crafting scrolls, potions, and grenades as combat contingencies for Honour and this would have made a big difference in my gameplay experience. -Skillbook description poorly communicates spell range, making it hard to figure out the best skills for a build -Huge minus: crafting system is incomplete. Why can i only craft chest pieces, and not gloves / legs / helmets? Why are so many recipes that were in the first game missing from this one? -Huge minus: buggy as hell. Should have stayed in Early Access longer to fix these.  I originally reviewed this game as 7.5 / 10. I'm going to go with 8.5 / 10 with my revised view of the story / characters. With QOL changes and a tighter playtime, the next instance of this franchise could easily be a 9.5+ masterpiece. I'm very excited and will definitely be contributing to a kickstarter if there is one.
