So, my original review was too long for steam, so I have had to cut it down in places  Let me just say here that I love the game, although it isn’t perfect I admit. It is one of the best co-op games I have ever played, and this adds extra replay value for me personally. I have never been interested in the PvP matches, so I can’t speak of that myself. Below is all I could squeeze in, but I hope it showcases my opinion and experiences of the game.  Divinity Original Sin 2 (DOS2 from here out) is a CRPG with players having a party of up to 4 characters. The game uses a fairly familiar stat pool, which you can increase each level (Strength, Intelligence etc), but also includes talents (Feats) for some cool bonuses and ability points which can add things like damage, access to new skills, lockpicking and so on. Combat is turn based, and gets really interesting with the combinations of elemental puddles, clouds and status effects in play. The story is divided into four Acts, across four separate but distinctive areas, with side quests and companion quests spanning each one.  I love a good story in my RPGs and CRPGs so I usually put a lot of stock into this aspect of the game. DOS2 story was ‘good’ and felt interesting enough, with enough little twists to keep my attention for the duration of the game. As a story overall, I didn’t think that it did anything majorly unique, it didn’t challenge the players concepts of anything in particular, but it served the purpose as a framing device for propelling the player through the acts nicely. This may seem like a criticism, but really it isn’t any more than the ‘feeling’ I had playing through. I felt DOS2 does a lot better job with the story than Pillars of Eternity 2, but perhaps not quite as solid as something like Baldurs Gate 2, so take that as you will. The theme is somewhat a mixture of serious plot, with little nuggets of humour thrown in, which I like. In places the game absolutely does not take things too seriously, and there have been multiple times where I have had a little laugh out loud. Not tearing my sides or anything, but there are many chuckles to be had through the game.  The companions are well done, for the most part. Each has their own quest line and unique interactions with other NPCs throughout the world you’re in and this can lead to some genuinely surprising moments, and in some cases just having a specific person with you can land you in hot water. I personally applaud this because I feel it makes the world a little more ‘alive’ than some other titles. You might play through once with certain party members (or with none) and then on a subsequent game you might take other companions and get different reactions with NPCs you’d never really noticed before. The quest lines for your companions are (for the most part) well done. They’re long and detailed enough that you care about their story, and don’t feel like it’s a glorified side quest. Voice acting is done well throughout and I’m glad Larian Studios took the time to implement it into the game, and then improve it for the Definitive Edition, in places it felt a little lacking. Just a little side note here…If you’re standing in a densely populated area of NPCs, expect to hear lines of dialogue repeated ad nauseam. I’m looking at you market place of Driftwood…Still, it’s not quite as irritating as the man with many cheeses from Original Sin 1.  Graphically I love how the game looks. Traversing the world feels wonderful, and if it’s a new area you never know when a fight might break out or a dialogue option pops up with a player decision to be had. The animations of the characters are a pleasure to watch, and personally I love the look and feel of the spells. I have made a purely Air based mage for this reason alone, and I’m having a wonderful time so far. Another thing I have been critical of in the past is when battles take place in previously used ‘maps’ or ‘tiles’ (sorry to bring you up again Pillars of Eternity 2). I believe Larian deserve praise for not having this in DOS2. I appreciate that, when entering a battle, it is not like other games where you’re ‘transported’ to a ‘battle map’, it just happens in real time, but when I was exploring or fighting in the game I never felt like “Oh, this area again” and I appreciate that.   I do want to point out that the music in this game is just amazing and really adds another dimention to the experience. I know Larian spent a lot of time on this, and it really pays off. I find myself humming the theme music and battle music on a constant basis after I've played (much to the annoyance of those around me, since I am as musically gifted as a deaf otter).  Quality of life issues have been improved upon from both the first game, and the non-Definitive version of this game, which I really appreciate. Managing the inventory is nice and easy, transferring items between characters is fairly intuitive, the journal has been improved to be a little less of a cluster duck, and overall the UI is well presented. I’d like to expand this section, but I don’t feel there is anything specific that needs addressing. It simply works, and works well, so I’ll leave it at that.  DOS2 does not use a traditional ‘class’ system. Sure, you can make an archetypal Rogue, or Mage or Warrior etc, but you are never locked into anything. If you’re playing a heavily armoured Warrior wielding a two-handed hammer but you like the look of a buff spell like Fortify, just drop a point into Geomancer upon level up and learn the skill. Done. This adds a great deal of flexibility to character builds and playstyles, which really helps the combat of this game and your feeling that this is *your* character. I could talk all day about builds and ability combinations, but for the purposes of keeping this to a (somewhat) reasonable length I will say that character customization is huge part of this game.  Combat in this game is perhaps the biggest positive I can say, which is why it will be another long section (sorry, not sorry). As previously mentioned it is turn based, and tactical combat. The combat works on a 360 degree movement range (that is to say, it isn’t grid based), with advantages to having higher ground (insert Episode 3 meme here), and controlling the battlefield through a mixture of crowd control abilities and surface types. You can create combos with yourself or other party members by mixing certain elements too. For example you can make it rain, which adds the ‘Wet’ status effect to enemies in an area, then go for a frost type spell, which will then potentially freeze your opponent(s), making them skip their next turn. That being said, Armour types are a thing introduced since the first Original Sin. If you want to get certain status effects onto an enemy you will need to strip them of their ‘magical armour’ to do so. Usually by hitting them with magical attacks. For players using physical attacks, you will need to bust through enemy physical armour, before you can do things like knock them down, or cripple them, etc. This is such a huge part of the gameplay that it is impossible to cover in a review without going on for days, or making a lengthy video, so please feel free to look on YouTube or wherever if you want to see this in action.  Balance can be skewed through the game, which is my only real negative point (something which Larian has worked on to improve). Act 1 can be rough, but by the time you hit level 16, you definitely notice a jump in your parties power, which can trivialise some encounters. For those looking for a more consistent challenge I recommend Tactician Mode.   Overall I highly recommend this game for people who are fans of CRPGs and like (or don’t mind) turn based combat, with a real focus on positioning and a tactical approach. It isn’t perfect, but it’s extremely enjoyable to play either solo, or with friends.

This review is somewhat limited as I have yet to fully complete the story, nor tried the dnd mode, yet I have a good idea of everything the game has to offer.   I think Larian have done a fantastic job in creating a grounded, well-rounded, and enthralling RPG. The narrative is imagnitive and captivating. Characters and npcs are unique and interesting, with good voice acting they really feel like individuals who each have their own personalilty, some could respond well to charm, others might threaten to kill you. Combat is challenging, fluid, and forces you to stay alert, using your head to figure out the best action to take. The visuals are gorgeous for the type of game it is and help to preserve the verisimiltude of the world.   One thing I would note is that the game is designed to be challenging by nature and is sometimes very slow and frustating, so if you lack patience and prefer only action, it might not be the game for you. For those of us who grew up playing Final Fantasy or other turn-based games, it is a very refreshing reminder of how fun these games can be if done right, especially with the unique twists this title adds. I would fully recommend the game, to the stage I am even using it for a college project where my task is to create an informative video, similar to ones seen by Mark Brown.

This is a beautiful game, one of the best-looking games I've ever played. It runs smoothly at 1440p, and the detail is insane.   However, I've spent nearly 40 hours playing so far, and I've only just got past Fort Joy. I've re-rolled characters over and over again to try and find a build that doesn't get constantly slaughtered. I've also tried over and over again to get my party members to be more than useless, but I've had no luck.  This is a strange game to me, because I want to keep playing it, but every time I die I wonder why I'm torturing myself.  This is one of the first games I've played where you need to have a guidebook handy to remember everything. You have to remember which character class can heal, and how. You have to find hidden tricks in the game engine to stay alive in combat. You have to scout out areas without getting automatically sent into combat mode, so you can then arrange your characters strategically and then hope that they are far enough away to stay alive, but no so far that the game engine considers them to be outside of combat and their turn gets skipped.  In short, there is no learning curve to this game. It's more like a learning cliff - you either get it, or you don't. I recoommend this game, reluctantly. It's at least worth the two-hour refund window to see if you can handle it.

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is one of the best rpgs I have ever played. The music is wonderful, the gameplay is amazing, and the writing is top quality. The main selling point of the game is player freedom, and this game does not let you down when it comes to freedom.  This game is the type that you can spend any amount of time, or have any amount of runs going, and everything can still feel fresh and original because X npc didn't die on the second run, or because the cat became a friend, or because any other number of variables that can lead to a run being altered heavily. This game is about as close as you'll get to dnd without needing friends to play dnd with.  The combat is slow, tactical, and can be pretty tough when you haven't gotten the hang of it. Players can make builds that combine classes or are just a powerhouse in one particular type of combat, or they can put all their points into civil skills. Also, elemental combos are awesome. You can set fire to oil puddles or poison clouds, or electrify water/blood or steam, or teleport an oil barrel on top of someone who is on fire which causes them to explode. The amount of different ways you can tackle foes is truly amazing. It's fun, well written, has a great soundtrack, fun combat, and is an all around great way to lose countless hours to a game.

What a brilliant game.  I am not a great fan of turn-based RPGs (or at least wasn't till now) but D:OS2 really changed that. The combat system is simply epic, both in terms of visuals and dynamics. It is so much fun to fight with strategies and due to the well-balanced difficulties, most of the fights are very exciting.  Exploring is also incredibly fun. The game has maps of decent sizes but more importantly, each act is generously full of well-scripted contents. You never know what you will find but you always know you will find something that makes your exploration valuable!  The story is quite compelling. Side stories, however, are often even more compelling. Additionally, all characters you meet have a personality that speaks to you on a human level. The attention to details for creating such a lively world should really be appreciated. Even animals have individually established personalities that make meeting them much more fun. Similarly, the dialogues are of the same quality. Very good voice acting and very well written lines.  The open-world aspect is, again, very good. The number of options you have through the gameplay is vast and unlike most other open-world games, your choices actually matter. Abundance of options applies not only to your choices of progressing through the storyline but to each part of the game. Almost everything expects some decision from you.    Graphics are very stylish and they look really good. Just by looking at the screenshots you can tell that this is a game with a fantastic world that will immerse you 100%.   The price is completely worth is without a doubt. You can easily expect 100-110 hours of gameplay from D:OS2.  In my opinion, if you like the genre of RPG at all, don't even hesitate to buy this game. This is a RPG masterpiece.

Holy crap. This game is amazing.  So heres the run down. This game is in effect a massive game of dungeons and dragons, only the game is the dungeon master rather then your friend being the dungeon master.   The RPG aspects all feel really nicely done here, with concious effort being required to decide on how best to talk your way through a situation. The fact that every character in the game comes with voice acting is simply astounding, esspecially given just how many characters there are in this game.  As far as combat is concerned, its very similar to XCOM and atlas reactor. Each character recieves a turn, with the order being determind by each characters initiave stat. Much like XCOM and atlas reactor, every action has to have its strength and weaknesses weighted against the situation. To be completely honest, the combat system feels so smooth and effective, it makes the non-combat sections feel underwhelming as a result, and believe me, they definetly are not boring.  The multiplayer aspects are really nice. Personally, I recommend only playing multiplayer with friends, but that has more to do with ensuring cooperation then anything else. One nice feature of playing with friends is that it makes every moment feel more enjoyable.  All that said, I do have a few nitpicks about this game. The ingame market system can feel annoying at times, since only one person can foot the bill for an order of gear. Similarly, there will be many occasions where you can find yourself running through the same dialog again and again in hopes of achieving the best result.  However, despite everything else I have said, the single best thing about this game is its customizability. Built into the game is an editor that allows you to alter the map, the story, and where all enemies are located, which gives the game huge replay value. On top of that, the game is perfectly capable of accepting mods, which cranks this games replay value up to eleven.  Summary: Pros: + Absolutely amazing combat system that feels very familiar to anyone who has played XCOM. + Amazing graphics quality. + Insanely rich story and lore. + Dozens of hours per campaign. + Tons of replay value. + All voice acting is well done, and if you can talk to it, it has a voice. + Loot has a heavy ammount of RNG attached to it. + Everything is right there after you download the game (an increasingly rare thing these days). + Your starting class is completely flexible, and you can change just about everything about your starting class. + You do not need to stick to a specific class as the game goes on, allowing you to adapt as you go. + A ton of workshop content, and the games less then four months old.  Cons: - Things can get a little tedious at times, particularly if your not the best at keeping your saves up to date. - Purchasing from vendors is a little annoying, and I personally feel it could stand some more quality of life features. - You may find yourself restarting fights often as you realize what actually is happening.  Conclusions: Divinity original sin 2 is simply an amazing game. Almost everything about this game screams of quality, and feels like it is the result of honest game design. When people say this is a top of the line RPG game, they are not kidding. With extreme ease of modding, and a still growing community, its easy to see why this game is being called game of the year material.  Score: 9.9/10

TL;DR: Every minute spent playing the game is an absolute blast and definitely worth every penny.  The very strong points of this game are the amazing versatility of the spells and combat mechanic, making you feel like you can actually come up with a sensible strategy to beat certain fights instead of just ramming into the beef fest head first. Unless you're playing a lone wolf pure warrior, in which case these two concepts meet one another. The "puddle" mechanic is intuitive and very fun to experiment with, for example making it rain upon your foes before striking them with lightning and finishing them off by turning them into a pile of frozen electrified flesh.  The only problem you'll encounter is that you need to make your own replayability of the game in the form of changing playstyle, class or upping the difficulty as the content is nearly always the same.  A few bugs here and there towards the end of the game but nothing major, it's mostly just spells unslotting themselves if you reorganize them a bit too fast and the such.  The soundtrack is the perfect balance of soothing and tense, keeping you on your feet yet feeling like you're playing a D&D session with friends, great fantasy RPG feel. The voice acting is pretty good too even if you do get these moments YARROW GIRL! You. It is you. I have found you. Vermin. What's this? I found something!  A very solid game to play alone for a RPG feel or with friends for a great love/hate relationship that the main quest helps you build up and even actively encourages during certain parts of the game, much like the coop of Portal 2!

So there are many things you should know about Divinity Original Sin II before you buy it.                                                                - Time and Dedication -    1: This game is a massive timesink. You have to invest into this wonderful gem of a game in order to take appreciation for what it is. If you are unable to put in 100+ Hours? Probably dont buy this game. I am currently forty hours into this game and I feel like I am just beginning to scratch the surface.                                                                 - Patience and Understanding -    2: This game is quite punishing and can be frustrating when you lose to the same group of enemies 5-6 times just because you are outnumbered 2/1. But knowing HOW to approach a battle and WHERE is key and if you do it wrong? There is a good chance a relatively easy battle will be much more difficult from such a simple miscalculation. Now this game is not nearly as unforgiving as its original predecessor? But it is still punishing.                                                                 - Things I like -    A: The story. It does a MUCH better job of gripping you this time and actually keeps the player actively engadged with what is going on, and if you played the first one? You know exactly how dry the first one was.     B:  Combat is relatively the same but minor changes here and there, positional awareness and planning are key.     C:  This is a wonderful multiplayer title, I can not even bring to mind one that challenged this in terms of just raw playability and fun. IF you have a friend or two that can play this with you the entire game? It enhances the gameplay by leagues. This game was made to be played with friends.                                                               - Things I dont like -     A: It has strayed away from D&D mechanics a bit more than the first one? But that is okay. It makes it more accessible for other players that arent interested in this.                                                                 *This is a big one*    B: The introduction of magic and physical armor to every piece of armor and apparel. Now normally this is fine? But the way it works now? The physical and magic armor acts as a buffer to the characters health. They have 1000 Physical armor? Your Barb wont be able to touch him for most of the fight as attacks will only hit the physical armor portion of his health. They have 1000 magic armor? Well your mage is now out as magic will not be able to inflict and damage to their health until their magic armor is depleted. In addition each of these respective new "stats", they also act as a shield against status effects completely while active. Cannot burn someone with magic armor, cannot cripple someone with physical armor, cannot blind someone with magic armor. This system feels absolute and a bit broken because if you have enough of both? You are immune to damage and status effects for that stat type until the armor depletes.      C: It can still be quite easy to lose yourself in what is going on. I have to constantly be re-reading through my journal to make sure I know what I need to do. If you spend a week or two away? Expect to sit there and decipher the journal until you have retraced your steps enough to know where and what you need to do.    Anyways.. This game is amazing. I love it and highly reccommend it if you have the time to put into it and of course a friend or two to play with. If you are on the fence about this? Dont be. Get it.

So, I finished the game. What can I say to those, who came to read the reviews, thinking about buying this game? I think I'll use default pros/cons list of things doesn't mentioned on the game page:  +  Content/price ratio. It will probably took you about 80~100 hours just to complete campaign. Can be more, can be less.  +  Great feeling of adventure, even the main quest line feels more like an exploration rather than just following the markers on the map (hello to Skyrim main quest).  +  Neat battle mechanics. And again, it's not a straight line of pushing the buttons to deal damage (hello to Dragon Age combat). You can explore the possibilities of different spells effects, you must check resistances of your enemies, you should care about positioning your heroes and seeking good spell combos (at least on high difficulty settings).  + Good storyline (highly subjective opinion). Some nice twists (one final twist actually can be predicted long before it's happening by watching closely on a particular NPC characteristics, which is nice), characters with different stories (both past and ongoing).   - Despite the story being good (highly subjective opinion), I didn't find characters catchy or very interesting. I would rate them as "okay, I guess". None of them, I don’t know, touched my heart and made me worry about him/her. I guess it's because they rarely showing their personalities through some sort of a tete-a-tete dialogues with your hero and very limited interaction between party members.  -  Bugs. Few in singleplayer (mostly side quests that can't be finished properly and incorrect dialogue sequences, nothing critical, but still it is an unpleasant experience) and a lot in co-op mode (you can find lists of current issues on reddit if you really want, it's constantly changes because old bugs being fixed and new being discovered). Developers fixing them and rolling patches very often, but I think the game without a publisher demanding the product here and now should be polished better on its release.  - When I selected "tactician" difficulty, because default level was too easy and then I find that the “tactician” is easy too, I couldn't go higher because "tactician" doesn't allow changing the game difficulty. WTH?  - Patches are breaking localization. I played the game in Russian, but after some patches some spells began to use English names and some entries in the quest log changed the language.  -  And lastly, I want to mention the dark side of highly variable combat. Huge possibilities mean huge exploits and when battle was too hard for me, rather than winning because I learned something from my mistakes and improved tactics I usually won because I've found a way to cheat the game.  Major "cheat source" is stealth mode and NPCs reaction to it. I have been looking for an "old school" RPG for a long time along the lines of Baldur's Gate.   This game reminds me of what I fondly remember those games to be. The games I used to play weren't as good as this, so I must be getting senile in my dotage.   Pro:  Character Creation. This is the first time I really wanted to play a non-human character. In older games you would get the same old Tolkien-esque non humans to choose from that in the end were just humans with different stat caps. The non-human characters in Divinity 2 actually give a whole other way to roleplay your campaign; from special abilities that shall we say, might be a little too gastronomically challenging for squeamish players to ones that add a delightfully morbid sense of humor to the game. Time to break out of our "humans only" team leader habits.  Tutorial. The first third (or so) of the game can be considered a tutorial for how to maximize your party's effectiveness. Much better than simply throwing you in a training room and showing the basic button clicks to make a fight happen.  Graphics/Art. I'm usually not overly concerned with every game having absolutely jaw dropping graphics to be entertaining. That being said, Divinity 2 is gorgeous. The attention to artistic detail has led me to walk into more than one trap while admiring the art on the walls.  Story. I'm not going to go into a great level of detail here, I want you to discover the story yourself. What you get however manages to balance what we expect from a fantasy RPG while adding new elements that keep you guessing whether you really are the hero or not.   Side Quests. Plenty to do there to take up all of your free time. One feature I really enjoyed is that there isn't always a good solution, and that solution might have repercussions down the road you did not expect. No Mass Effect Paragon system here folks.  Cons:   Learning curve. After the tutorial adventure the difficulty can seem to ramp up very quickly, I found this to be primarily due to the sheer amount of customizability you have available to you. Be patient, save often.  Pathing. Sometimes your party does not like you and wants to go sightseeing when you are clicking on the next objective. Keep an eye on where they are going.   Divinity 2 is a fantastic game that shows you don't have to go to the AAA publishers to have a memorable experience. Give it a try and gnaw on a couple of dismembered arms for me.

I am over 200 hours into the game now. And I can say by now, this is my personal game of the year 2017. It's brilliant. It's a great coop game as well as a great solo game.   I would have to write several pages to review why this game is good. But I'll try to keep it very short:  + Full voiced over  + Entertaining NPC talks with a lot of laughs you get from it  + Interesting and often suprising story, that will change in the details, when you play another character build.  + By far the best turn based combat system I have ever seen in a game. I usually hate turn based fights, because it often feels like playing chess. This game does it so much better. Just go on youtube and watch some videos on fights. You will see how nice it is designed.  + A pretty intelligent and challenging AI that makes combat really hard and strategic if you like.  + Beautiful graphics. The world looks amazing.  + Beautiful music / soundtrack  + Very good level design. When you enter the world, you want to explore it, and you can get lost in it in a positive way.  + Perfect coop implementation. You can join a friend's game at any time and take control over one of his companions. Or you start together and create your own characters.  + The skill system is pretty huge and you have a lot of customisation options.  I really try to balance this review and tell you good and bad things about this game. But I have hard times to find any bad. This game is just so bloody good. But here aare things, I would like to see improved. They are highlevel critic on an almost perfect game:  - The quests in this game are recorded in some kind of diary. I like that kind of questlog, but it needs more information added to it: It doesn't tell you what level that quest is for, which is kind of a problem, as you have quests ranging over 6 and more levels in a region. I started to explore a region but didn't do every quest I got right away. So when I started to solve quests later on, I ran into a lot of enemies that were 2 or 3 levels higher than my group. In this game such a difference in level often means you don't stand a chance, especially on higher difficulty. So I would like to see a level written to each quest in the diary. At the moment you pretty much have to finish quests as you get them, which makes it a bit of a linear experience. I would like to be more flexible.  - Also the log doesn't tell you where you got a quest and not all of them get pinned on your map. So it's really hard to remember all the locations, which could also be improved.  It's very hard to review this game, because it has so many aspects. The world of DOS2 is full of things you can discover, I got a lot of laughs out of the dialogs and I like the story. The story also really surprised me at times, you can't predict how it will go and in the details it will be different depending on what character you play. Which is brilliant and gives this game so much replayabillity. I am in act 2 at the moment and I am almost 200 hours into the game. This game is vast... it's just huge. You get so much content, I didn't expect this game to be that big.  I love this game to be honnest. It's probably the best RPG I ever played in over 10 years.  So, there you are, this game is worth every penny. Great Story, amazing voice over, great combat, great RPG, great graphics.... what else? I love it.

It's hard to find games like this anymore.  The care they put into it shows, it comes packed full of content, you can easily get hundreds of hours of gameplay out of it; the story is extremely rich and really long, and the turn based combat is fun, interactive and also challenging. If you like tactical turn based combat I recommend you choose Tactician mode, it will make you earn every combat you start. Enemies will not respawn in this game and there is a finite amount of experience you can get, which is good because it saves you from having to grind to level up.  The music is really good too, it gives the game its personal touch and adds a lot to combat and exploration.   The gameplay is a callback to the classic RPGs era: isometric camera, point and click movement, multitude of meaningful different dialogue choices and choices in general, a strong emphasis on exploration to find secret caches and treasure, and a quest system that will not hold your hands. This game rewards you for being attentive and reading, more often than not you will not get clear quest markers that show you exactly where you need to go and what you need to do, you'll have to figure it out by yourself. The same goes for puzzles.  The world building is great, you will feel very inmersed into the lore, the characters and the world you're exploring. The world you play through is divided in 4 giant maps that you will access sequentially, however, you can freely explore and do things in the order you prefer within each one of these maps.  The writing and voice-over is also excellent, although sometimes a bit cheesy, but it's clear that most of the times it was intentional. The story is a lot more mature and dark than the first original sin's. Humor is nice. I recommend you take the Pet Pal talent with at least one of your characters, the dialogue with animals is just too good, sometimes hilarious and other times depressing.  As for difficulty, you have 4 options: explorer, classic, tactician and honor, which are easy mode, normal mode, hard mode and hardcore, respectively. Honor mode will delete your save if your entire party dies so you have to start over from the beginning, definitely not recommended for your first playthrough. Tactician is challenging at first and it will make you sweat each and every victory, but it's also really rewarding, and once you get the hang on the game's mechanics it will feel a lot more natural and accessible. Classic is still challenging especially if it's the first time you play the game, but enemies will have less health and armor, and the AI will be more prone to making tactically inefficient decisions to give the player some more room for mistakes. Explorer is the difficulty for people who just care about the story and want to breeze through the combat as quickly as possible.  And finally, multiplayer and extra features. Coop is a blast, playing a campaign with a friend is great. Up to 4 people can play together. the game adapts perfectly to multiple people playing the same campaign except for one thing: the dialogue. Only the person who starts a conversation with a NPC gets to choose the dialogue options, which honestly can be a little frustrating when you and your friends don't agree with something, but otherwise everything else is perfect. The game also features a GM mode where you can create and edit your very own campaign, and then share it with everybody else. I can't talk too much about this feature though because I have only checked it out real quick, it looks very complex and the editor seems like it gives the user a lot of tools, so all I can say is that the potential is there.   Overall, I won't be surprised if this game becomes a classic and we start seeing a lot of new CRPGs being born thanks to it. The developers have earned this success, and this is a 100% recommended purchase for every lover of the genre, and also for people looking for a great time even if they're not very keen on the genre.

This is a great game, but you need to be aware of a few very frustrating game mechanics. You will be thrown into battle with enemies who, even if they are your level, will have far better spells/skills/abilities at their disposal and will almost always have far better field position than you do to start the battle(even if you attempt to position your forces prior to starting the encounter). You will also frequently be outnumbered even if you have a full party and you will probably die horribly if you take on any group that's above your level. If you're a fan of loot pinatas, you will be disappointed. You will fight and win very challenging batlles where the odds are stacked against you only to loot bodies that are mostly empty or have junk loot. You will be frustrated and rage-quit if you don't approach every battle with caution and aren't prepared to cheese your way through fights, when needed. The game is still rewarding despite these things, but it is not a simple hack-n-slash RPG.

If you are a fan of games like Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights, and other RPGs games based on heavily entrenched lore, you will most assuredly love this game. It's polished, has a lot of history attached to the world, and every character feels important in some way or another. On top of that, every tiny thing I move or interact with feels like it has changed my game for the good or for the bad.  Pros: -On my brand new Alienware desktop, the game looks pretty dang good. There are a few issues I can mention, but it would only be me nipicking. I'm not a huge stickler for graphics anway.  -Everything feels ALIVE and like I am just a tiny part of a huge world. -The combat feels fluid and well-refined. -The story is enthralling. Cons: -The combat, though fluid, has a few issues. The first is that there is a great deal of metagaming that takes me out of the world. On many occassions, I found a battle completely impossible until I restarted the game, positioned my characters around the future battlefield for an advantage, and then triggered the battle. It feels like I'm cheating, and I don't like that! -I know it's for space, but I'd like to have an option to have a free roaming world where I can travel between islands. Once you're done with a location, it locks you out!  Other than that, this game is splendidly done and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys a good story. :)

When I started reading reviews calling this "the greatest RPG ever made," and even "the greatest GAME ever made," I had to  try it. The reviews reminded me a lot of The Witcher 3 and it was for the same reason that I bought and played that game way back when and it's now considered my favorite game of all time. So yeah, I got a little excited.  Then I played the game and I felt kind of disappointed. It seemed extremely difficult and I wasn't used to getting the cold shoulder from a game. By that I mean compared to most games this one does not hold your hand, you won't get arrows pointing you in the direction you need to go, everything you need to know is actually in the dialogue and/or read in notes and books (and sometimes a rare hint from the narrator). I kept feeling confused on where to go and who to talk to and the quest system seemed kind of clunky and hard to understand at first.  I'm ashamed to admit, I asked for a refund at about the hour and a half mark. Then I went a couple days thinking about the game and that I couldn't believe I couldn't get into it. And then I thought about it again and again and realized that something was nagging at me and I couldn't stop thinking about it.  So yeah... I bought the game again. I looked up tips this time around on which characters people like in their party and which skills really help early game (Lone Wolf changed everything for me). And most of all I had to learn to slow down, stop running through rooms like nothing matters. This game made me change the way I approach video games. I started to appreciate the detail and get into the story, and I have to say, the story is absolutely amazing. The characters are all interesting and the situations I found myself in during certain points in dialogue had me on the edge of my seat.  Now I'm 40 hours in and I can confirm, absolutely one of the greatest RPGs ever. And I haven't even had the pleasure to experience co-op with a friend. 10/10

Best RPG game I have ever played. If played with friends, it can be one of the funnest times, whether you take it seriously and strategize, or you troll your friend by lighting them on fire. Game is a blast and has a lot of replayability. So many options make the game a little bit intimidating at first but after you start to get into it, it becomes an addiction. 10/10 Would highly recommend, even at full price it is a steal.

Wow, this game is just a breath of fresh air in an age of sequels and recycled gameplay.  I've been playing through this almost exclusively co-op with a few friends and it has just been one of the best co-op experiences I've had in a long time.  I can’t really think of a comparable quality story driven, co-op RPG on PC since maybe Neverwinter Nights and that is 15 years old.  I really like the fact that everyone is free to run around and do their own thing and have their own conversations without generally locking the party into cutscenes or anything like that.  You can choose to follow your companions around and listen in on them, or you can split up and report back what you've heard in your own conversations.  Not having control of your character usurped every 5 minutes for an unskippable cutscene is quite nice.  Over the last few years, I’ve played some Dungeons & Dragons on Roll20, Skype or Tabletop Simulator.  Playing through this game feels very much like the D&D experience, even borrowing many of the mechanics like passive perception and attacks of opportunity.  Both in and out of combat, the game gets a lot right in this regard and really shines as a result.  And speaking of the tactical turn-based combat, it is really great.  I’ve mostly played it co-op with friends, but I played the first little bit single player as well.  Either way you go it is very fun, and can be quite challenging at times if you get in over your head.  And you can’t just eat a lot of deaths either because your resurrection options are limited, at least early on.  A lot of the combat revolves around elemental mechanics similar to that of Magicka.  So for example you can spill oil on the ground, ignite it with fire, put the fire out with some water thus turning the water into steam and then you could shock the steam cloud and make it electrified.  This makes for interesting situations in combat and there are often unintended side effects if you are not careful.  The combat AI of the opponents seems passable enough.  I have seen them do some pretty questionable things at times though.  In particular, during one fight we had an enemy archer spend 2 or 3 turns shooting arrows into a barricade because it didn’t have a clear shot at our rogue.  There have also been a few other instances where they would take actions which seemed to benefit our side more than theirs.  We’ve only played on the ‘classic’ normal difficulty though so I can’t really comment on the higher difficulties.  The controls can also be a bit tricky at times, leading you to accidentally move when you intended to use an ability or vice versa.  But this mostly just comes down to being patient and paying attention to what you are doing.  If you try to do things too fast before the animations finish it can mess you up.  Also the game won’t tell you if your ranged attack (bow/wand/staff/etc) will hit something in the environment so you just need to be aware of things.  Although I’ve somewhat taken a back seat in the story development process in our play through, the fact that all the interactions with NPC’s are voice acted really helps.  And while every side quest isn’t Witcher 3 levels of amazing, I haven’t had any complaints.  You can even take a perk and talk to the animals if you want to be just a little be more depressed along the way.  All in all I have been thoroughly enjoying this game and would gladly buy an expansion or another sequel in this series.  I look forward to future releases from Larian Studios and hope they can continue to provide truly phenomenal games without all the shady modern business practices like endless microtransactions and loot crates.
Great game, the story is fine. The sheer amount of choices how to screw with the game using teleport or just abusing mechanics is teriffic.

After over 100 hours this game kept my interest to the very end. From someone who needs to open every basket and complete every quest this was a joy to play and explore. each map held so much variety and captivated me with every plot turn and engagement with npcs. The humour, the combat, the visuals, the story... One of the best games I've played!
By far the best cRPG to come out in the year 2017. Great combat, characters, plot and music all combine to make a timeless masterpiece. Pillars of Eternity II needs to try really hard to top this.

If you're thinking of getting this game: GET IT. Let this be the sign you're looking for. I've managed to somehow log 28 hours in only 3 days.   If you like true RPGs, this is for you. DOS not only combines skill point allocation and XP levelling up, but lets you command a party of four to your specifications and builds. You want to combine a Ranger with a Battlemage, and a Dwarven Knight with a Witch? Sure, go for it! Each character will have their own focuses and strengths that will aid you in individual battles. The game is played in realtime except battles which are turn-based with each character having a maximum number of Action Points to use which gives you time to consider you moves but also a liimted number of options available to you at each turn. Focus is on your approach to battles, your teamwork and use of environment.  The world is vast and loot is plentiful and rewarding, and quests are very interesting. Overall it seems like a better, more polished version of DOS1:EE. Crafting and inventory has been vastly improved, as has magic armour/physical armour/health systems and spells have been honed and buffed.   If you haven't played the first DOS game, no stress - you can jump right into this game without having to know too much. Get the game. Get it. You won't regret it.

I had to write a review for all those people like myself...i REALLLLYYYYY Do Not like isometric/Top Down rpg's. I just can't get immersed in them(MAINLY BECAUSE OF THE VIEW)....it may seem odd, but if you're like myself, you will understand what i mean. When I want to play an RPG i look for something like the witcher, skyrim etc...an awesome adventure, where I feel as if i AM the character, in a manner of speaking, So I can really enjoy the game, and get attached emotionally and physically to the story..( i know im getting to deep here ill tone it down LOL)..... HOWEVER...I have been looking for a new rpg to play recently and this popped up...You can understand my hesitance even with the reviews of people creaming over this game :P...because this game is isometric/top down...   SO know after 20 or so hours I GOTA say a few things...ONE.....this game is hard as F**K lol...BUT I RESPECT THAT.. :) no easy ride for this pizzaman..TWO.....im, what some might call a graphics wh*re...and this game is pretty as F**K :)...and lastly.....YES..it is top down, and YES i freakin hate that view...BUT...these developers, have created something MAGICAL...i cant quite say what it is..but I can NOT stop thinking about this game....I have ACTUALLY managed to feel pretty freakin immersed in it aswell...I am VERY HAPPY to say :) .  Considering I literally could not STAND playing any game like this in the past( diablo, this, etc...) I would definately recommend it. Thank you developers for opening my eyes to a new world of video game..ing..age...ness ;)

Best 'western' RPG I've played in ages, brings back memories of playing Neverwinter Nights and the like back in the day. The game is pretty similar if you took elements from D&D and turned it to a more XCOM style turnbased game. The writing is excellent and got me hooked immediately and there are so many different ways to play and interact depending on your characters. You're free to choose the party you want and the characters are all pretty unique (went with a lizard, skeleton and a possessed mystic myself)...and you can play it all in co-op instead if you prefer. Just regret not checking out the original when it came out, but this sequel is extremely hard to pass up.  Soundtrack's great too, and just about everything in the game is fully voiced which was a pleasant surprise.

Probably one of the best top down RPG games I've ever played. It's certainly the best in recent memory. The way the different abilities interact with each other gives a good tactical strategy element and I'm always impressed when the AI manages to catch me off-guard.

I'm sure by now you've seen many reviews raving about the pros of this game (and there are many pros). So rather than rehash everything that's fantastic, I'll keep this review brief by listing my few quibbles with the experience.  1) Misclicks: I've had a number of irritating cases of accidentally clicking on something I didn't intend to. Outside of combat this generally means I accidentally stole something because the vendor I tried to click on moved. It would be great if there were a "don't steal crap" option to avoid this. In combat it usually happens when I try to attack an enemy and click terrain instead because their model isn't static, resulting in wasted AP at best, and being on the receiving end of attacks of opportunity at worst.  2) Companions: The only complaint I have here is that they seldom seem to react to your choices and actions outside of direct conversations with them. So far it's seemed too easy to keep all of my dramatically different companions happy as clams - even two who would or should be trying to kill each other in their sleep.  3) Co-op: Sort of a pro and con... Your online experience may vary. The game puts no real restrictions on the behavior of other players in your game. There are a lot of ways they can help or hinder you (including betraying you in the middle of a battle). So, like with traditional pen & paper games, the people you're playing with determine whether or not you will get any enjoyment out of it.  If none of those serve as a major deterrent for you, then you are going to greatly enjoy this game. I honestly can't recommend it enough to RPG fans. I've enjoyed all forty hours that I've put into this game at the time of this review, and I feel like I've barely scratched the game's surface.

+ Co-op All the game!  + Good dialogues. They are all voice acted and well written. It does not bore you to hell to listen to people. Some talking options are sometimes a little vague but it's water under the bridge.  + A Good story Not like it's an emotional tale, but the game takes the extra effort to give you actual characters with backgrounds and sets you in a cool world, built neatly.   + Cool Combat Turn based combat has its downsides but this is one of the games where it is fun. You have a nice variety of useful skills and combat options. Also you can build your characters as flexible as possible and respec them if you want.  + Tons of Content You have all these different routes and dialogue choices to explore throughout the game, which is a heaven and a nightmare because you feel lost in it and have to sink your 150 hours into the game.  + The Art It looks and sounds good.    This would be the best game ever if it was not for a series of intersected problems. They're not so bad themselves but together these problems make me think twice if i want to play the game.  - Entering the combat in a wrong way. If you did not get a good headstart and hit your enemies before entering the turn-based combat or get your characters in the right positions, you might as well as load. Most of the time you're the underdog (even more with higher difficulty) and have a power/stat disadvantage. They could've at least give the player half a turn to move, not even to attack.  - Random Encounters Entering the combat feels a little clunky, but what makes it worse is that you won't know when you'll be entering the combat. Were you talking to someone? They turned hostile. Were you exploring a cave? You were ambushed by high level monsters. They are fun and interesting when they are sparse but turn out to be a hassle if you come across them in a row and go into a dozen of long/difficult fights. This game needs more fights where you can actually plan before going in.  - Turn-based combat takes time Who knew you'd have to wait your turn right? You wait for AI to think. You wait for the animations to happen. You wait for your co-op mates. You miss your turn if you get stunned. So if you walked into a random encounter, or get defeated in a fight and want to try again, you will sit there for a while.  - Loading screens take time I admit this might be on my end because my hard disk is getting old. But i can still tell the game is hard on my hard disk. When i get into combat, i always find myself having to decide whether to load right there to get a better headstart or wait to see if i can somehow pull through, learn the fight then try again. So I end up waiting for something. The need to load often does not help.

Just finished the first play-through on tactician difficulty... still sinking in at what was said at the ending and ponder the strange feeling I have now that my adventure has come to a close. This game has the most intriguing, twisting, imaginative, and board-sighted story line. In my first play through, because apparantly I have built my character so strong that I defeated the final final boss with the click of two bottons (though involveing some tricks), the combat has not been the actual high lights. It was the stories that kept me hooked. I never knew where it would take me, never knew what's the truth of this world that I am in, the relationship I can develop with my partners, the images I could fill in with my imaginations to paint the world as what I want it to become... It is just a shame that this has to be only a game, not a real universe; the ending had come too fast: where my own imagination truly ran wild and where the game presents what should be the most remembered part of the story, it just felt that it ended very quickly. But this is no complaint of the game, endings like this had me recalling every past moment of my adventures and together the ending actually painted a very big picture, but it was just so good that I can't help but want more!!!!! I could honestly play the ending over and over and over again!!!!  If you decide to play, my best advise would be to paint a picture of the world while you advance through the stories. With every conversation, quest, discovery of secrets, encounters, the picture would become a little bit clearer. Through this you can capture the true beauty of this game! I just hoped that I didn't have to realize this until the ending and had to take it all in at once :)

THE STORY: This is by far the most densely rich lore I’ve played through from any game I’ve played, where almost everyone and everything is connected in one way or another. Creating a living and breathing world, where one’s actions and decisions will affect their adventures through Rivellon. The part where this game shines the most, is how it gives the player choices on how they want to advance the story in any way the player chooses to play. Choose to be good, evil, just or whatever mood you choose, this game adapts to it and guides you to the end that your choices led to. While I’ve only completed Fane’s Story (in the moment of writing this), the endings it gives you will satisfy however you played. While you can choose how your adventure ends, the game lets you know how those actions will affect Rivellon in the future. The reason why I love this story is how grim and real this story plays out, no one is truly good or evil, it’s all a grey area, but it’s your choice on how you want to navigate in it.  THE COMBAT: There was never a dull moment every time I went into battle, or stumble on to one. While combat is turn-based, pre-battle is when things become interesting. Some approaches I found to be more fun is laying out traps and pre-emptive attacks on unknowing enemies. I can go into combat with my enemies clinging on 5% health and wipe them out with one attack. This is true liberty that this game gives to players, it gives you the tools and it’s up to you on how to use them. And this is just combat, skills can give a creative twist to combat. You can chain attacks to deliver devastating blows to your enemies or toy around with them by unleashing various Statues Effects and skills that can either immobilize them or transform them into chickens. All this creates a simple yet complex toy box you can play with. Finding out what seems fun and effective will make you want to seek out the next battle and unleash your battle plan.  THE MUSIC: I do not, in any way, have any complaints or criticisms about the music. The only thing I can say is that it is Divine. The music makes Rivellon and in turn makes you believe that it is a real place and these characters who live in it are part of a giant play. The 4 instruments that you can pick (while you build your character) creates the mood in how you want to play and you can change it any time you want.  This is the best RPG for this generation. While there are quite a few bugs the developer needs to fix, this doesn’t affect how much I love this game.

We were somewhere around Fort Joy on the edge of the ocean when the source began to take hold. I remember saying something like "I feel a bit sourcemuted; maybe you should fight..." And suddenly there was a terrible storm all around us and the sea was full of what looked like huge slugs, all swooping and screeching all around the ship. And a voice was screaming: "Divine Lucian! What are these goddamn animals?"  The early looting had also given me 300 gold in cash, most of which was already spent on extremely important revival scrolls. Our luggage looked like a mobile junk shop. We had two bags of food, seventy five notes we didn't care to read, five tomes of crafting books, a salt shaker half full of stardust, and a whole galaxy of multi-colored potions, bottles, grenades, spellscrolls and also a quart of healing brew, a pile of intencies, a case of portraits, a bunch of rabbit paws and two dozen golden spoons. Not that we needed all that for escape, but once you get locked into a serious trash collection, the tendency is to push it as far as you can. The only thing that really worried me was the crafting. There is nothing in the world more helpless and irresponsible and depraved than a man in the depths of a crafting binge. And I knew we'd get into that rotten stuff pretty soon.

In addition the game does not cradle you one bit you will find yourself quickly defeated in any fight where you don't play to your party's strengths and avoid their weaknesses. and with turn based combat fighting lots of enemies at once can be a massive challenge forcing you to eaither set up traps or pick them of a few at a time. I spent over 150 hours on this game right when it cam out and that brings me to the cons as i see it.   Cons: This game has a lot of gear in it so you are often getting new items and then you have to go through and see which out of all the items is better for you and there no fast way to do that. That mixed with the crafting in the game means you can even augment certain weapons making them do tons more damage. I am unsure where to begin with Divinity 2 at this point. This game has been and still is an amazing journey you can take on alone or with your friends.  I am hardly convinced with most of the games I play but Divinity has me on a collar. I cannot look away or stop playing it. I already am at 50H and haven't even experienced the whole singleplayer campaign.   The fact that you can talk with every single NPC, including animals (if you got the "Pet Pal" Talent early on), that you can explore every corner, find new clues and ways to secret caves or find treasure chests. All those aspects are a big yes for me to recommend Divinity2.   But was that all? Hell no. I haven't even covered 20 percent of what this game is capable of yet! I really enjoy freedom. I want to choose what to do, how to do it and, that should I take the wrong path in a conversation, have to deal with the backfire. Each race reacts differently towards NPC's (as do they. A lot of racism going on in this game) while adding more tags to your character such as "Barbarian""Scholar""Outlaw""Mystic""Soldier""Jester" and "Noble" gives you the options to get more information out of them or successfully persuing them after they saw you stealing. (I have to add this since it caused me great pain. Do NOT click on a trader while they are walking by. I accidentally stole a bottle of wine instead of talking to the trader and hell on earth broke out. Never steal wine guys. NEVER.)   Each races armor looks different depending on what armor you give them. The same helmet looks differently for each race which means just getting out all the armor sets probably took ages and I am glad they put so much detail and work in this game. You can see the development teams heart in it. A great game that is meant to be so much more.  It is sometimes hard to keep the playerbase or even raise those numbers shouldn't there be options to replay the game after "finishing". Divinity did everything right. I am putting the word "finish" like this simply because of the fact that you will be having a hard time completing this game 100% if not impossible. So many options depending on what you chose while creating your character, while talking, whom you talk too and how. So many options to go, so much to explore, so many ways you can complete a single quest will make it hard for you to not get lost in this wonderful world <3  And I haven't even started to talk about the Game Master aspect. So far I have't been able to look at them simply because of the fact that the moment I have freetime I play the campaign.... I might be addicted at this point.  The option to create your own campaign, invite your friends or upload your work on Divnity's Steam Workshop will give you a never ending adventure.  My friendgroup started to use Divinity as DnD platform. Our GM creates the world and through Divinity you don't need to only imagine it, you can actually see and play your personal adventure.  Since the game is turn based you have everything a little RP heart needs to be happy.   In short: If you enjoy exploring, a never ending adventure and have a great time with your friends while playing Divnity's campaign, a downloaded one from the workshop or your own this is the game for you to play.  A long awaited tripple A game that has been worth all the wait. Hands up for an amazing adventure I will be enjoying for a long time!

I loved it. It gave me the same feeling I had when I first played Dragon Age Origins, and I couldn't wait to wake up in the morning and get back into the game.  The turn by turn combat is rather well implemented. There aren't really any "easy" fights, or if so, very few, and as such each and every encounter has it's own importance.  If you read the forums a little you'll find out that there are both people complaining that the game is too easy and people claiming it's too hard. I think it is rather well balanced. Succeeding in combat relies a lot on knowledge. This means that you might find the first few battle frustrating . You will fail, but what's important is what you learn from each failure. Some fights can require quite a few reloads and changes in both strategy and equipment. As you learn to optimise your character as well as fully utilize the environment to your advantage you will progress.  The story is engrossing. I am unfamiliar with the previous games so I speak as an initate to the world of divinity. Each character of your group has a well-fleshed out backstory that you'll want to discover and a personal arc that you will want to see to its end. Dialogue is in general rather well written. The lore is easy to get into. There are a number of well-written books and scrolls you can read, but you can do without them. You'll grow familiar with the world as you interact with it, and nothing ever really confused me. For those of you worried it follows the current "You are the Chosen One" trend, well, it does, but only kinda. You are A Chosen One, not The. The world doesn't bend over backwards to suit your whims. In fact, Chosen Ones in this game seem to get very little respect.   The quests are all excellent. There isn't any "filler", you're never really told to go kill and 10 people. I think we can all fondly remember in specific games we played a select few "memorable" side-quests, distiniguishable by the fact that they had an actual story with their own characters and that they lasted more than ten axe-swings. In this game, most quests are as such. And they nearly all have multiple possible endings, depending on how you approached them.  The music is top-notch and the graphics are rather pleasant.   The wide-variety of possible character builds, the character stories to live through, and the multiple endings to each quest grant this game an immense amount of replayibility.   As someone who isn't really a perfectionist but does try to empty his quest log, my first run-through took me about 40-50 hours. For a 45 euro game, it's a fair amount of bang for your buck.

D:OS 2 is a thrilling and beautful adventure across the fictional land of Rivellon in search of becoming the next divine. The combat is deep and unique, and especially more fun on the higher difficulties where more strategy is involved. The voice acting is spectacular, particularly with the main cast of pre-generated characters.   However, where the game falls flat is its lack of originality in the main storyline. Esentially it brings upon the typical "hey theres a bad guy and hes bad and powerful and we gotta be more powerful to defeat him", with a few extra bits thrown in there. It continues like this until the later acts where it picks up. Thankfully, there are individual character stories that take place between for those before mentioned pre-generated characters, if you happen to have any in your party.  Overall, being a $45 title with easily 65+ hours content on just your first play through alone, this game is easily worth the price. And even being, there is an upcoming "enhanced edition" which is said to improve on the main story. I cannot recommend this game enough, despite its downfalls in the story and is easily in my top 3 games of all time.

It's a great game !  I got the feeling that I played a good old paper RPG like D&D: no proper "classes" (you mix your own), lots of characters, speeches, way to fight, ...  BUT it's definetly not for everyone. It's like you have a sadistic GM: it's tactical, it's hard, it's unforgiving. Prepare for looots of quicksaves, or you'll live with the consequence of your acts Wrong move ? Dead. Wrong answer to a pnj ? Dead. No characters with this ability ? Quest almost impossible to do  Exemple: (very very light spoiler ahead)  I could talk to a Scarecrow: i start the discussion, and then there was NO way, at least for my character as i build it, to avoid the fight with 10 scarecrow 2 level above of me -> F8 to last quicksave	  For those who know/liked the 1st opus: run for it ! Same base, but everything is enhanced, with a lot of quality of live changes, etc ...  I highly recommend for anyone who like hardcore tactical RPG. Btw, the 1st opus is absolutly not needed, for lore-lover, a quick wikipedia summary is enough.  -----------------------------------------  C'est un super jeu !  J'ai vraiment eu l'impression de jouer à un RPG papier oldschool genre D&D: pas réellement de classes (on construit celle qu'on veut), beaucoup de personnages, de dialogues, d'actions possibles ...  MAIS, c'est pas un jeu accessible/plaisant pour tous. Comme dit plus haut, c'est comme avoir un MJ sadique: c'est très stratégique, très dur et impardonnable. Préparez-vous à souvent faire des quicksaves, ou alors vous vivrez avec les conséquences irrémédiables de vos actes. Faux mouvement ? Mort. Mauvais réponse ? Mort. Aucun personnage avec telles compétences ? Quète quasi-impossible.  Exemple: (très très léger spoiler)  Je pouvais parler avec un épouvantail, je lance donc le dialogue, à partir de là, il n'y avait AUCUN moyen, pour mon personnage tel que je l'avais construit, d'éviter le combat avec 10 épouvantails 2 niveaux au dessus de moi -> F8 vers la dernière sauvegarde rapide	  Pour ceux qui connaissent/ont aimé le 1er opus: prenez sans hésiter ! C'est la même base, mais tout est amélioré, avec beaucoup de modification "quality of live" , etc ...  Je recommande vraiment pour tous les fans de RPG ou tactical game un peu hardcore. Au fait, le 1er opus n'est absolument pas nécéssaire, pour les puristes, un rapide résumé wikipédia est suffisant.

It's hard to find games like this anymore.  The care they put into it shows, it comes packed full of content, you can easily get hundreds of hours of gameplay out of it; the story is extremely rich and really long, and the turn based combat is fun, interactive and also challenging. If you like tactical turn based combat I recommend you choose Tactician mode, it will make you earn every combat you start. Enemies will not respawn in this game and there is a finite amount of experience you can get, which is good because it saves you from having to grind to level up.  The music is really good too, it gives the game its personal touch and adds a lot to combat and exploration.   The gameplay is a callback to the classic RPGs era: isometric camera, point and click movement, multitude of meaningful different dialogue choices and choices in general, a strong emphasis on exploration to find secret caches and treasure, and a quest system that will not hold your hands. This game rewards you for being attentive and reading, more often than not you will not get clear quest markers that show you exactly where you need to go and what you need to do, you'll have to figure it out by yourself. The same goes for puzzles.  The world building is great, you will feel very inmersed into the lore, the characters and the world you're exploring. The world you play through is divided in 4 giant maps that you will access sequentially, however, you can freely explore and do things in the order you prefer within each one of these maps.  The writing and voice-over is also excellent, although sometimes a bit cheesy, but it's clear that most of the times it was intentional. The story is a lot more mature and dark than the first original sin's. Humor is nice. I recommend you take the Pet Pal talent with at least one of your characters, the dialogue with animals is just too good, sometimes hilarious and other times depressing.  As for difficulty, you have 4 options: explorer, classic, tactician and honor, which are easy mode, normal mode, hard mode and hardcore, respectively. Honor mode will delete your save if your entire party dies so you have to start over from the beginning, definitely not recommended for your first playthrough. Tactician is challenging at first and it will make you sweat each and every victory, but it's also really rewarding, and once you get the hang on the game's mechanics it will feel a lot more natural and accessible. Classic is still challenging especially if it's the first time you play the game, but enemies will have less health and armor, and the AI will be more prone to making tactically inefficient decisions to give the player some more room for mistakes. Explorer is the difficulty for people who just care about the story and want to breeze through the combat as quickly as possible.  And finally, multiplayer and extra features. Coop is a blast, playing a campaign with a friend is great. Up to 4 people can play together. the game adapts perfectly to multiple people playing the same campaign except for one thing: the dialogue. Only the person who starts a conversation with a NPC gets to choose the dialogue options, which honestly can be a little frustrating when you and your friends don't agree with something, but otherwise everything else is perfect. The game also features a GM mode where you can create and edit your very own campaign, and then share it with everybody else. I can't talk too much about this feature though because I have only checked it out real quick, it looks very complex and the editor seems like it gives the user a lot of tools, so all I can say is that the potential is there.   Overall, I won't be surprised if this game becomes a classic and we start seeing a lot of new CRPGs being born thanks to it. The developers have earned this success, and this is a 100% recommended purchase for every lover of the genre, and also for people looking for a great time even if they're not very keen on the genre.

PRO'S -Great Story -Incredible attention to detail and good flavor text -Great characters (The sassy lizard man and sassy skeleton are my favorites) -Combat is INSANELY fun, yet difficult -There are easily over 100 hours of gameplay in a single playthrough. I haven't even finished mine yet, and I'm at 94 hours while writing this. -Tons of quests -Different factions you can help, or ignore -You can have sex with a sassy skeleton -Cool environments and areas -Magic is actually fun and useful. (Something that I think is sometimes rare)  CON's -Pathfinding can sometimes make you facepalm -Character creation could be a little more in-depth -Some quests could use a liiiiittle more direction to the player because it can be hard to figure out where to go

They simplified the way a lot of things work and the only one that irked me was Crafting. Crafting in Divinity Original Sin and Enhanced Edition really brought a lot to the game with money making and being able to stack resistances to make up for lower end gear that you just couldn't find an Upgrade for. In Divinity Sin Original Sin 2 you can forget about that and weapon enchants are down to just Two methods. Poison Barrel or an Eternal Object for Lightning. Poison Barrel adds Poison damage which honestly hurts for a ton of fights where you're partially healing the creature you're damaging(Undead).  The Dev Team is great, even after being released as a full game for this long they are still pumping out Bug Fix Patches and Game Balance Patches which shows they care about the Game and what the Community thinks.  I'd give this game an 8/10, Larian Studios really knows what they're doing.

Games like this are what make me appreciate video games. This game has it all and is so well constructed. Larian has outdone themselves here and I can not recommend this game enough.  Some selling points:  -Deep strategic combat possibilities which feel amazing to master. Not only that, but the battlefields are usually constructed to allow for many approaches to combat. Status effects, different types of armor, and a myriad of skills and abilities means hundreds of ways to design a character and a vast amount of unique ways to approach combat.   - Flexible character customization possibilities. The game doesn't lock you in or punish you for not optimizing your character construction, instead it allows you to respec after you gain a deeper understandning of how everything works.   - Extremely pleasing aesthetically. Th terrain, art, armor  and weapon design, all beautiful. I enjoy just walking around in the game not even doing anything.  - Gripping and Engaging Atmosphere. The game pulls you in and contains realistic elements that make it's world fantastical but also believable. People actually notice when you steal something from them. They notice when you have a fight in the backroom of a tavern and forget to close the door.  - Interesting Origin Characters with their own stories but also the option to forge your own character in that world.  - Vast amount of things to do, places to see, secrets to find, enemies to kill. This game is huge and only costs 45 dollars. That alone makes it an alluring investment.  Downsides:  - some bugs, glitches. I've found these are very minor and usually solveable. Journal wasn't working, restarted game, fixed. Helmet stopped displaying on character, didn't care didn't like that helmet anyway. Larian clearly cares about this game and I think they will continue perfecting it.  - Learning Curve. I will say the game is a complex one to master and at first looking through all the skills, stats, terrains, items, etc. you can feel a bit lost. So it requires some patience. I found the complexity enjoyable but others may not.  Really I think this game is the definition of adventure, I've loved every minute going on quests, exploring, and feeling like I'm not sitting in front of a computer. It's blissful escapism and exactly what you want from a fantasy adventure game.  To anyone from Larian that reads this: thank you very much for your work and what you've created. It's a masterpiece and a fine example of what is possible when games are taken to their highest level. You should be proud.

9.5/10 The only thing that this game needs is more content. The story is incedibly immersive and the character creation and development is 2nd to none.  NEW PLAYER ADVICE/TUTORIAL If your starting divinity as a new player, heres some advice before you start running into the game head-on thinking this is skyrim; as you will add to the list of players claiming this game is way too hard on classic mode...   No spoilers here btw.  STARTING THE GAME At the very start of the game you are asked to create your character (sorry, spoiler!). DO NOT RUSH THIS PART OF THE GAME. Before you even look at building a class, or rushing into the game, the classes in the game develop over the course of the game, so your playstyle with said character will also change. This game is very slow and methodical, not unlike a game of chess; you have to plan ahead and think through your actions, there is no timer!  For players that have come from COD, or Diablo etc. this is not hack and slash, so you cant just run in head-on; its like sending your king and queen in to try and kill the pawns as fast as possible. try to think about what will happen each turn, and plan 2 turns ahead.  SAVE OFTEN pretty much self explanatory, but you get jumped a lot, so safe often so that you dont have to retrack the past 10 mins of walking around.  READ EVERYTHING AND SPEAK TO EVERYONE. This is probabally the best piece of information i can supply, and without revealing too much. divinity is about tactics not hack and slash, so speak to as many NPC's as possible and explore every area. this will grant you more experience and access to more items. As the enemies in divinity are all level based, this will allow you to stand on equal footing with them, rather than being 3 levels; wearing a loincloth and wielding a knife on a stick (actual weapon, sorry spoiler!) against a group of 7 decked out enemies all positioned in highground and chokepoints. Also reading enemies weaknesses and levels/armor etc. will help you to control fights better.  YOU DONT HAVE TO GO THAT WAY! Many situations you come up against will look pretty damn scary, especially when you realize the enemies ounumber you, outflank you and outlevel you. This usually means you are underlevelled for the area you are currently in, so go back and complete a few more side quests, or just try taking a different route and coming back to said area (hint, you might not even HAVE to complete that area, but this could mean it holds some good items, and more levels!).  WHAT IF... This is the most important question to be asking yourself during the course of the game, and will mean the difference between winning a fight with 0 Deaths, and losing a fight without killing a single enemy... analyse what you can do, what can happen if you do it, and how your opponent can respond (sorry this is vague, trying not to spoil anything). abuse the terrain and your opponents limitations!  TO CONCLUDE This game is as difficult as you make it, which is why a large group of people find it so difficult, because their game is half complete! turn every area upside down before you move on, as there is probably about 3 quests you missed with 2 levels of xp. And DONT RUSH CHARACTER CREATION! Dont be ashamed if you start a new game after playing for an hour on your first playthrough, i did, because i realised i missed so much and learnt what i was doing wrong. Good luck and take your time!  (spoiler) PS. dont let the cat die...
