Larian turned gold to lead, but this game is probably worth it, provided that you know what you do.  First off, choose wisely your play level. I chose tactician as a veteran of RPG. I was well served. Indeed, tactician it is! But it doesn't say that you should also scratch every single little advantage that you can (steal as much as possible, stack on potions etc.) in order to be well prepared for the last fight. It also doesn't say that you shouldn't expect your characters to be heroic! Indeed, in many situations at that level you will have to resort to cheesy tactics such as some characters fleeing the combat to recover skill timers, heal, then come back while the combat has been frozen because you left one character or invocation hold it... Or by reloading consistently because you were not prepared for a nasty surprise in a combat and had nothing left to deal with it; so you reload, come back with smart prepositionning and the combat will go smoothly. I remember a fight against some outrageous horror -helped by numerous cronies, all of them more powerful than my characters despite being one level above-, which I easily lost head to head, then won after reloading, placing my characters far enough, engaging with invocations and keeping my characters far enough -actually out of combat- that I could always cast a new invocation when one died. I finally won that fight without a scratch. Smart ? sure. Pleasurable ? Hardly.  So unless you like going very slowly, always moving like there is a fight at the next step (or reloading often), managing inventories to be sure each character has the absolute best equipment, has the necessary consumables,  and so on (i.e. total micromanagement), skip the tactician level. At normal level, the game is going to be challenging enough for most players. Especially the last combat, which I never finished -I have done quite well in the first part, but am hopelessly outnumbered in the second part. I probably know what is wrong, but I won't be going back batching the potions that I am missing, respecing my characters to more useful stats, traits and spells, changing runes for more useful ones etc. you get the picture for tactician level.- So, I won't know the end of the story line I chose, and I won't change my storyline just so the last combat is easier. That's a bit sad.  And NO: YOU CANNO'T CHANGE THE DIFFICULTY LEVEL DOWN! That's a real shame!  Also, there is no excuse for larian in turning an excellent character development/combat system into the mediocre thing that it has become. In that respect, Original Sin 1 was way better. The current system has clearly been designed in order to foil the player and outrageously favor the opponents. You cannot inflict secondary effects (blinding, stunned etc.) as long as the target has magical or physical armor (a new protection that comes above your hit points.) This means that the first rounds of combat are always going to be damage dealing: you won't have any crowd control coming until you've done some attrition first. Worse: the system favors teams which choose a damage type and stick to it. I made the mistake of wanting a balanced party: the result is that I am too weak for the last fight. Actually in some fights, I had characters standing aside, watching the combat go because they did not deal the right kind of damage...  After all this has been said, I still recommend this game because the story looks good, the world is well developped and generally speakig as RPG go, it stands on the top if you don't fall into the trap where I fell.  EDIT: I finally found the courage to do what I said I wouldn't do, and of course finish the game. As expected, I had to respec my characters, and decided to go for lone wolf. The advantage in lone wolf lies not in the power of the characters (they indeed are stronger, but you have overall less firepower), but in the fact that you don't have to bother about the survival or such and such character, as well as reducing the drain on your consumables (you use two instead of four for a similar effect.) The fight was easy [SPOILERS (light) AHEAD] mostly for use of the special tea sold by Mrs Kremm, combined with at least +50% full elemental protection potions and five star dinner -i.e. all elemental damage did heal me, which both let me remove most healing spells as well as use my own offensive spells for healing-, the pawn and duck duck goose (for good movement, not mentioning spells.) Other talents which I thought would help did not (guerilla) [END SPOILERS] ; I changed my main character from pure mage to hybrid melee (fighter) / mage, helped by an archer/assassin ; as explained above, this was a choice to favor physical damage over magical damage, choice made necessary by the difficulty of that fight. I of course had to spend considerable time to prepare the characters and the consumables, buy or craft the required potions and books as well as redistribute equipment. The trouble is that in that fight I did not recognize the character(s) I played consistently from the beginning (no respec before the end), which is annying (to say the least) for a RPG! The other trouble is of course that I could not have to feeling that the hero was well above the other contenders to deserve my victory. Indeed, the stats of all other human opponents were consistently above those of the hero. Understand who can!

--No spoilers--  Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a game that at first kind of looks meh. The graphics might not appeal to some and others might find the spells and other things clunky at first. But the game is rather quite the opposite of those problems. It's a great game but a game you need to get invested into. I enjoy the combat greatly because there is so much to do and so much to interact with. I also really enjoy sidequests and this game has a ton of them. There is a lot to explore and discover.  At the time of writing this I have about 116 hours and still haven't completed the game. Do not think that it tastes that long to finish a campaign, but merely there is a lot to look and do. One of the problems of the game isn't even the game's fault. It is the players. Some people drop games or get to busy to continue.  I've restarted the main campaign about a dozen times (sometimes my fault) before finding someone that would go all the way. But it really is a blast when you are with a friend or friends.  Though I must say the crafting system is kind of lackluster when it comes to anything but potion making. I barely use it unless it's to make potions. Some places are annoying to deal with and that one battle with oil slugs or whatever they were called didn't do my computer any good. Loading screens are longish but you barely have to do any load screens at all because the entire map is just available to you. The dialogue and narrator are also one of my favorite parts of the game.   Overall? I recommend it highly! It's absolutely worth it.

But if I thought DOS1 was brilliant and needed changes, then I must admit I feel the same way about DOS2. My main issue being that the combat system filters you to certain ways of playing which DOS1 did too but DOS2 does in different ways. Party of 4? Stick to either physical or magical damage focus for all, as mixing stats makes both weak or one side essentially useless (but doable on explorer mode). Party of 1 or 2? Hit that Lone Wolf talent on character creation and you'll have the most fun the game can give. To an extent you can mix damage skills quite well and not have a bad character.   With that said, you'll have many hours of fun making characters that work and even those that don't (which you can thankfully fix after act 1).

Divinity: original sin 2 is my first game in the Divinity series, and I bought it following the overwhelming number of glowing reviews everywhere, including from friends. So I am now unabashedly jumping on the bandwagon, writing that the game deserves every praises and accolades showered its way.  As a computer role playing games veteran, I played its spiritual ancestors, the likes of "Baldur's gate", "Neverwinter", "Planescape: Torment" and "Arcanum", and I can say that I am feeling right at home with Divinity: Original sin 2. It feels and plays the same but not quite, with the improvements in technology providing luscious sceneries and sumptuous special effects, all the while with great sounds, voices and a haunting music.   The combats can be made as difficult as one wants, and there is a whole world to explore with its mechanics and secrets. Spells and environments combos are there for the finding (or the googling...). There is very little hand holding but at the same time the game offers many ways to solve its plethora of quests and side stories, and it is designed in such a way that walking off the most obvious path is rewarded "sometimes" so it leaves the player wondering whether he should. Compulsive item collectors will have either a field day or nightmares trying to keep track of everything, and new dialogues will open up depending on which character speaks or takes the action.  So if you feel like going on a great adventure, alone or with friends, grab the game, then your sword, staff or wand, and be prepared for the journey of a lifetime (or two, or three..).

Kinda game breaking if you use it.

1 hour in, and I already love this game.  You can tell they put a ton of effort into making every step a smooth experience. There is a ton of polish. And the world building is fantastic. I feel like I'm reading a LOTR series, except I get to take part in the events. There are kings and queens and emperors, and monsters and villains and heros and gods, and things going on over here and over there while I'm doing my thing.  Most current RPGs make it really hard for me to imagine myself as taking part in the story. For DOS2, it takes almost no effort. I really want to know what happened to my characters ancestors, and what my friend wants to do, and what their family is doing, etc. I can make decisions based on how I would react in each situation.  And on top of all of that, they have coop too! Like WTF, they don't know when to stop!  It really feels like a labor of love. For what you get, this game is wayyy undervalued - I'd be willing to pay at least $80 for all of these features.

Don't be fooled by my play time; I played offline quite a bit and it seemed to have missed that time. I have played quite a few Divinity games, Divinity I, Divinity I Enhanced, and now this one. sadly, I have not beaten Divinity one just yet...becasue this game has ensnared me it it's beautiful artwork, charecter classes, and story. In this game, Divinity one is turned around as you now play a sorceurer, the 'bad guys' from the first game.   As expected, the combat is tougher than the first since you start with the bare minimum. You can't run in swinging on the first Island, it takes quite a while before you reach the 'run and gun' stage of blowing away the compition. hell, I was wrecked by some silent monks because a spell went a little crazy.   The Island rquiers you to play smart...very smart. you need to watch everything and make sure you are not standing in water before you electrocute it. you have to look for archers hidding in the bushes. You have to heed the warning of 'don't break this jar or something bad will happen to you' (That something bad being five skeletons showing up an wrecking your face)  In short, the game is difficult if you are reckless. A single wrong click will screw you faster than a missed swing in Dark Souls. I recommend saving often and having a backup file just in case. the Island will trap you, and It will kill you. You have little hope of succsess... Welcome to Rivalon.   now, some positives and negatives: PRO: -Voice acting. Totaly worth it -stratagy to make my brain hurt -A litteral TON of loot -dark humor in a dark game that I shouldn't have found so funny. -steal EVERYTHING!....then die -Super Rewarding when you reach that point where you can actually fight, insted of flail and hope you hit. -A actual story, something that I miss in many of the other games I play, complet with plot, conflict, and a resolution...if I ever get there.   CON: -The mouse can be very picky when you click, and will not hesitate to f**k you over. It can be a real rage feast when you try to shoot an arrow, but insted you walk next to the guy with a sword bigger than you. -The Price. I got this a while ago when it was in development and I had the money. After playing Divinity one, I scooped this game up fast. If you are on the fence about the game, wait until it goes on sale. This game is totally worth the price to me, but I knew what I was getting into. 20/10

This game is a masterpiece, plain and simple.  I highly recommend it to all those remotely interested.  Coming from somebody who had not finished the original due to several factors, including; messy story-line and general boredom from the odd pacing set in the game, I can wholeheartedly say that this game vastly improved upon the original's flaws and then some.  The player comes for the game-play (advertised as no rules sandbox of sorts), and stays for the story (which kicks off rather nicely). And truly what magnificent game-play and storytelling it is. The adventure is told through both "Origin" characters and an unique "tag" system that allows the player to select titles of sorts that give additional dialogue options. Pretty neat stuff.  There is never a dull moment to this game as it is stuffed to the brim with content. Over 120 hours played and I still don't want to put it down. Adding mods to the equation just adds more and more replay-ability.  Granted while the difficulty can be rather steep for some, and having beaten it on "Honour Mode" (Ironman on steroids), I can say with certainty that truly enjoying the game requires both and open mind and a knack for the unconventional.  Thank you Larian, for easily the best experience the past several years.  Tldr: Play, Love, Kickstart Divinity Original Sin 3

I'm surprised that I haven't written a review of this game since I first started playing it. This game from my own perspective offers quite a bit.   Story: Every single quest has multiple ways of being approached and there is no system of good or evil. You could be doing good thing for terrible people or bad things for noble causes. You could just be pure evil for the sake of being a jerk, and you could make every kindhearted decision out there. There is no wrong choice and anytime you block a certain path due to a choice you made, there is always another option to be explored.  For the amount of choices that this game gives you in terms of social and story progression, it's worth a full price buy in that alone.  Gameplay: Honestly, there is no such thing as a game without bugs. For all the bugs that this game has, it has a devoted team of developers to constantly patch and repair whatever the community reports to them. For every feature the community asks of the devs, they take everything into careful consideration. The combat mechanics are simple and complex at the same time. Every attack has it's own property, physical or magic. Physical damage has no sub categories while magic damage splits into, fire, water, earth, poison and wind. What makes the magical damage so complex is how the elements interact with each other and the environment to make the gameplay more immersive.   Unfortunately, if you want to play the game for pure optimization and not immersion, most people go into pure physical damage builds to ignore the majority of elemental immunities that certain enemies might have in the game.  To sum it up, the game is great and worth more than it sells for.

REVIEW UPDATE Adding on some extra thoughts due to the Definitive Edition.   The Definitive Edition takes an amazing game and makes it even better. Performance improvement, glitch fixes, balance changes, a revamped ACT 4 and a lot of quests got extra dialogue to improve flow and better explain objectives. Inventory system and the Journal are much better now.  Nearly every improvement was for the better - the only ones that anyone might be upset about are the exploits that got fixed!   My original review is down below. But in short: The Definitive Edition is an improvement on an already amazing game.     -----ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW-----   Easily one of the best games I've played. You can go at it solo, controlling anywhere from 1 to 4 characters, or team up with friends for up to 4 player co-op.    A rich, beautiful world, memorable NPCs, great story telling and voice acting, fun quests. It's earned every single award it got.  Plus there's so many different ways to play! It has a very tatical aspect to it: building your character up, trying skill combos, moving around the varied battle fields, using mechanics to your advtange, controling the fights through terrain effects. It's challenging, but as you get stronger you actually feel stronger. As you leran more you start finding ways to overcome fights by clever use of mechanics rather than brute force. Of course, the brute force works juts fine!    There's no defined "class system" - as you level up you can put your skill points anywhere you want. As you gain more skill points in different areas (like say necromancy or pyromancy) you become more effective with those types of abilities, and can learn stronger abilities in those trees. You can freely respec anytime you want after Act 1, making the only cost to respec being your armor and skill books. This system allows you to try out tons of different builds: and a lot of them work! You're starting class only determines your starting skill points/abilities and weapons you'll get (which will all be replaced quickly). But even then you can customize your class during character creation.  You can go at it with origin characters, characters that have a lot of extra presonal story and quests built into it, or make up your own character! Want to be an undead lizard? Go ahead. Even if you aren't playing an origin character, you can still recruit them as party members to see their stories (but you won't have as much control over it).    It's an amazing game.

I have to say, they really did it this time. If anyone knows how to make a new game whilst improving on it, Larian knows how.  Pros- +Gritty- Honestly the first DOS was a bit too much on the comedy-irony side of the coin, and lacked the emotions I wanted from an rpg. DOS 2 on the otherhand, flipped that and made it a more emotional world where you connect with the people you save (or at least try saving). +Spell combination- Spells combined and formed new wonders in the first game, now it's even better with logical after effects. Stone skin putting out fire and stopping bleeding makes sense, and thats exactly what'll happen here. +Graphics- The graphics have improved, and no longer do people look like cartoonish buffoons living a care free life like in dos 1. Though I do hope they add in more customization to characters, and i'll get to that soon.  Cons- -Character customization- There was barely any in the first game when it came to choices, unfortunately it's the same here. At first I was hesitant at getting this. It looks great, and like a lot of fun, but maybe not worth the price. I thought maybe I'd pick up the game on a sale or something.  But I'm very glad I got it.  The story is very rich and there's so many ways to play. I'm excited for my second and third play throughs.   You can steal from anybody, kill anyone, befriend NPCs, talk to your followers if you choose to have them, and each story is different from character creation. Each race is treated differently, you have different dialogue options if you're an Outlaw, or Scholar, or even if you play a smart Wizard, you can persuade people with your smarts, or intimidate people with your strength.   The combat is very fun, and comboing spells and attacks is awesome.  Classes aren't really set in stone either. If you're a Fighter but decide you want to shock people, or grow some wings, you can very much do so.   And the GM mode is amazing.   As a Game Master for D&D games, I've always wanted a game to play it in, to immerse the players, and let them explore with out having to explain every small detail. And this game does it very well. You can create custom items, NPCs (even down to what hat they wear), allies, and customize the pre set maps the game gives you. I would honestly buy a DLC that includes more maps. But there are plently right now, I'm just afraid that through multiple play throughs we'll all think "Oh, this map again."  This game is a masterpiece, but it's not perfect.  The combat is very hard, even on the easiest difficulty it sometimes feels like I need to kill a couple NPCs who don't deserve it so I can level up and continue the story. And sometimes this makes the game feel linear. I don't know if I'm missing something, or I chose bad classes for my party, but either way that's a big down side for me.  That being said, at the time of posting this review I'm 71 hours in, and I havent even completed my first play through, which is a good thing. I'm taking my time, exploring the world, talking to every NPC and living the world.  UPDATE (very minor spoilers):  I finished the game, and I have to say while the ending was good, it was very buggy. I was unable to use res scrolls, enemies would teleport everywhere, and some other minor things.  Arx also felt very bland for what it could have been. Driftwood and all of Reaper's Coast felt huge, and there was so much story there, but Arx... You were there for one thing, and that was to beat the game. I tried to find more to do there, I tried to find side quests, just anything, but there was nothing. Maybe I missed stuff, maybe I didn't. Either way I feel the game no longer deserves my original score of 8.5/10.  8/10

This is the first time I have written a review on steam, and this game made me do it.  I'm playing honour mod, and after some 40 hours, and about 2-3 dead characters, I've succesfully managed to get to level 6 with a very solid party that is looking to become very powerful.   Lore: I haven't played any of the other divinity games, and am completely clueless to the lore. However, the NPCs do a good job of explaining their views on the world, and there's various books you'll find giving you insight on different, relevant subjects. I'm not the guy who usually reads books in rpgs, but in DoS2, so far at least, there's only a couple of pages long at most, with interesting content.  Companions: I instantly got hooked on the potential companions, legit within the first 30 minutes of playing the game and without even being aware they were potential companions. Very unique personalities, well written dialogue, excellent voice acting and actual, interesting backstories. It's so good it's actually difficult to pick who you wanna roll with. In turn though, that adds to the games replayability factor, so that's another plus.  Fane and the Red Prince though, those guys will probably be in all of my campaigns.   Speaking of replayability: You can get crazy inventive on your builds. There is SO much you can do with your talents and skills. Want a traditional DPS Archer? No problem. Death knight wielding necromantic skills, a big♥♥♥♥♥weapon and plate armor destroying the front lines? Sure. Support caster? Fire mage raining hell? Electromancer thundering all over the battlefield? no problem.  Also, skills combo really nicely with each other so not every comp is viable, and on the harder difficulties you don't want to spread too thin (Jack of all trades and master of none will not get you far). You also want to not create anti-synergy. A water/ice wizard will combo extremely well an Electromancer, obviously, but not as well with a fire mage or geomancer.    Strategic layer:  On the honour mod (perma death), this game does an exceptional job of encouraging tactical play and strategic decisions. Xcom2 - Long War on legendary difficulty comes to mind as a comparison, except you don't really have to deal with ridiculous RnG punishing otherwise brilliant play.  Combat: 10/10.   Story: Very engaging and immersive. Also you can do pretty much anything in this game. There's nothing stopping you from walking in the city, guns blazing, and attacking everyone in sight. Well, except from getting killed. So maybe don't do it at level 2.   Quests: Can be finished in a good number of ways. They're unique, they have flavour, are interesting and I have yet to find a single "Go fetch me 15 of x object" types of errands, or a quest repeating itself.  Like I said, I haven't played any of the other games and am completely new to this title. And yet this review still reads as if it was written by an avid fanboy. What can I say, it's just that good. For the quality this game offers, honestly, it should cost at least double. Get it. Stuff like this does not happen very often.

Oh boy, where to start?  In the past, I've played the original Divinity, multiple GOTY RPGs such as The Witcher III and Skyrim, along with playing Dungeons and Dragons for years.  After beating this game on classic difficulty, I've realized it is my favorite game of all time, trumping those previously mentioned.  Divinity 2 is the closest I've ever seen a video game get to DnD, near perfectly emulating the freedom of the players.  Notice how I didn't say sense of freedom or illusion of freedom.  Other games try to decieve you into thinking your actions matter, when in all actuality, they make little to no difference.  Here, the game responded multiple times to actions I had done dozens of hours prior.  Not only in simple little references, some had astronomical impacts.  There are also 4 different endings with significant, world-changing differences. You can try to kill anyone, try to steal anything, and have to live with the consequences.  It doesn't hold your hand, and because of that, it makes every decision and discovery you make feel like your own.  Divinity 2 is also a huge step up from the previous game, mainly in terms of overall polish.  The original game was great, however there was an incredibly boring starting zone, poor music, sub par graphics, and nonexistent character in your party.  This sequel does what any true sequel does and improves on the old, in nearly every way, while adding new elements.  Upgraded music, graphics, along with the introduction of origin characters with some of the best writing I have ever seen help breathe more and more life into an already thriving world.  The developers also streamlined the combat system while keeping the depth that make it the king of tactical rpgs.    One of the things that stood out to me was how good the story was and told.  With a lot of big, AAA games such as destiny, there is an amazing story, but the delivery is mediocre, turning a great concept into a meh grind.  Here, everyone is fully voice acted well.  You can tell from talking to people in game that this was a labor of love.  The actors poured their hearts and souls into their performance and it really shows.  The story is also brimming with twists and turns that you never see coming, which caused me on occasion to stop in shock, before yelling at the monitor or tearing up.  There is also one origin story character quest (Lohse's) which really hit me hard.  Never have I ever been so happy for a character before.  Then there is the multiplayer.  This game was a full and satisfying package on its own.  But on top of that, they added drop in and drop out multiplayer, so you can experience on of the best games ever with your friends.  There's an arena mode for pure combat.  AND A GM MODE TO CRAFT YOUR OWN GAMES.  This is huge.  The fact that I can run a Pen and Paper RPG for my friends through a medium such as this opens the floodgates to opportunities normally nonexistent if it was just a normal game of DnD.  It also gives people who host online games the option to give their players the  impression of a more living, breathing world.  The only negative aspect of the game I have experienced are the bugs.  They are few and far between, only amounting to a rare crash, or the voice acting not loading or being delayed.  However, Larian studios are hard at work and have been continually sending out patches to address these issues.  Best game I have EVER played.  I finished the game in 85 hours, doing everything I could along the way, and it's not even $60!    10/10  buy  this  NOW!

Wow. Just wow.  To start off, I had no idea this game was, well, this game. I'm in to RPGs like Skyrim, the Witcher, Dragon Age(ish), and fantasy stuff like that. I had always seen this game advertised on steam's front page in recommended for me, but i never took it seriously since it gave me a very "Diablo 3" kinda vibe, and that felt too grindy and un-fun for me. But eventually, I finally caved a decided to take a good look at it and felt i should try it out, since I've heard pretty much only good things (see entire review section of this game lmao). Basically, i didn't many expectations starting out.  Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ This game is good. Like really good. Like REALLY, REALLY good. I did not expect to fall in love as much as I did, nor to ♥♥♥♥ing binge the game and end up earning 80 hours played within a week. I believe a testament to this game's quality is how hard i fell for it, even without playing (or even really knowing about) the first Divinity. It's detailed, it's fun, it has a great story, the gameplay is engaging and does not get dull, and the sheer freedom the player has is incredible. The game's dialouge and overall feel gives me a big DnD vibe. There are many, many branches a dialouge, quests, and the story itself can break off into which will seriously affect how you go forward in the game, even affecting the ending in a very critical way, not the "good" or "bad" ending bs you normally get from choice-based gameplay like Dishonored or Mass Effect. Moreso, the games gives you more freedom in how you want to build your character, not confining people to class, but rather providing a "skill level" you must be leveled up to in order to learn certain abilities, which are all fairly low.  I don't have the ability like other people to give you a long review about every little thing, so I'll leave with this: If you are looking for a fantasy RPG that will reward you with a in-depth experience and let you truly craft your character to be exactly who YOU want them to be, then this is the game for you.  Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a calibur of game that belongs with the other incredible RPGs like Skyrim or The Witcher 3, and possibly has the potential to surpass them, in my opinion. 11/10 ♥♥♥♥ing fantastic

Can't stop playing! It's too good! I haven't been this engrossed in a video game since Witcher 3. The various systems of the game are so well crafted, and open up so many possibilities both in terms of combat and how to deal with quests.   The tag system and large dialogue options allow for proper roleplaying. There's a TON of things to do, and none of them are of the "icon clearing" variety found in your typical open world GTA/Ubisoft AAA bore.  The writing is very solid, it doesn't take itself too seriously and it's very funny, but deals with serious subjects (racial tension, faith, abuse of power etc...) in a mature way. The music is also seriously underrated.  The graphics are good in terms of the environments, but I guess I'm a not a big fan of the character models. The faces are quite ugly, and the fact that every "finesse"/rogue armor pieces are baggy pants and sleeves kinda irks me, it doesn't look very light and stealthy. A very minor gripe however, since we don't spend too much times looking are our heroes up close.  I've read that some people have encountered broken quests, and I guess it can be expected at launch given the insane number of them and unlimited possibilities (you can literally kill any NPC, steal any item etc...), but personally the only issue of that kind that I've encountered was just a completed quest (I got the item rewards for it) that didn't clear out from my quest log (The Imprisoned Elf).  I'll just finish by going back to how good and fun the combat is, the interactions between the different elements is a fantastic sandbox to play, and sometimes horribly fail, in. The AI is not exempt from that, I cried laughing last night when an enemy rogue went invisible and promptly revealed himself by falling on his butt after sliding on an ice patch he had created moments before! There are so many builds to be created and ways to approach a fight (including not fighting it at all sometimes, either through dialogue or sneaking/thievery), I can't see myself getting bored anytime soon!  The replayability seems huge as well, since you can have very different questlines depending on who you bring along in your party and who you're playing as your main character.  TLDR:  Fantastic RPG, breathes fresh air into the genre, most fun turn based combat this side of XCom, gives you a ton of freedom and fun with it's system. Serious GOTY contender! First time review here.  Just thought it was time to review a game I enjoyed more than most.  This is honestly my first dive into the hardcore crpg genre and as such I decided to dive in head first.  I have been taking my time to slowly read everything and triple check all areas.  That being said I'm ~20 hours into the game and I'm hooked.  Those 20 hours are over 3 days and I'm still enjoying every second.  Pros:    -Immersive gameplay that introduces you to your party and their backstory  -Voice Acting...simply put EVERY SINGLE LINE is voice acted.  This helped a newcomer like myself really want to hear all the dialogue and enjoy the story unfolding.  -Battle Mechanics...Every battle has a million ways of being approached and with the customization of your party you can take that to even more possibilities   Cons:  Only minor things that are more annoyances than cons...  -Party refuses to walk through status effects outside of combat.  Its nice that they auto walk around these things but the fact that they just won't follow the leader if there is no way around can be frustrating.  -Slower pace out of combat can tend to keep you out of the action longer if you are walking from one side of the map to another.  Nothing major here and honestly I'm reaching to find any cons so far.  TLDR: This is one of the best games I've played in a long timeand I think I've found a new favorite genre.

The mechanics of the game's system is somewhat similar to Pillars of Eternity, in that your character's stats function in terms of percentages and there is a skill system of sorts that you build from 1 and up. It is an open classless system where, while one selects a few options as a baseline at character creation, one is free to invest in any of a full variety of skills over the course of the character progression. However, it does turn out that, at least from an optimization or min/max perspective, maxing the Warfare skill ends up being the default choice for builds that care about damage. There are a few other potential balance issues with the skills, but that's the big one.   The overall combat difficulty in this game seems to be harder than one has probably come to expect from most new RPG's, even on classic mode (the equivolent of the "normal" setting), though things can get easier as one learns and exploits the system. But, especially when approaching it on my first playthrough, I too often found myself putting it on story mode ("easy") to overcome otherwise tough battles. I dislike doing such a thing in an RPG. It feels cheap, But I found myself doing it. The dual physical and magic defense system is simple and functional, though perhaps it is not the most nuanced or fun basis for combat in the way that it works. Combat becomes a matter of destroying enemy defenses in order to leave the enemy vulnerable to taking damage.   There is an attempt to have a little dialogue depth when talking with companions and important NPC's. I would say the dialogue and roleplay involved in it is okay. Nothing super immersive and detailed, nothing like a Torment game or a Dragon Age: Origins, but it's there more than would be the case in a more pure action RPG. There is some choice and consequence based on certain dialogue choices. Your companions have distinct back-stories and personal goals, and stories of their own that can play out over the course of the game. Further, due to the 4 character party limit, there is a little bit of replayability in terms of playing with different companions.   One of the problems with the game is that there simply is not enough explicit direction for the character to be able to follow or complete quests, since there are no quest markers and not much in the way of detail in the journal. Sometimes this is the case in such a way that breaks certain quests because of timing and choice/consequence issues. In and of itself, I don't object to a lack of quest markers or the idea of having the player have to work for things a little. But while it isn't much of an issue in the early game, by the mid to late game I found myself with a journal half filled with unfinished quests simply because I had no clear idea or memory of exactly where the characters I'm supposed to talk to are, or because I had progressed too far doing other quests and missed a vital quest cue or one-shot oppurtunity.   On a 1-10 scale, I'd give it an 8/10.

I don't usually play Turn Based games; when it comes to RPGs, I'm more of an free actions kind of guy (Gothic, Dragon Age, Witcher etc). However, a colleague told me about Original Sin and I've purchased D:OS EE and had a blast with it. Unfortunately, I arrived late to the party and didn't get a chance to help Larian with their kickstarter for D:OS2, but I did pre-order it (which I almost never do). And I'm glad I did.  The goodThere are some good changes to the first game: - you can choose your companion's class when you recruit them - you can respec your character and your companions at almost any time! - if you respec, you don't lose your learned spells/skills - you now have a skill bar with many slots at the bottom of the screen - summoning, hands-down one of the best class in the game; summons can really turn the tides of battles, especially since they can be infused with different elements - full voice acting (I know EE also has that, but the original D:OS didn't)  The so-soThere are also some changes, let's call them neutral; some I've learned to like, while others not so much: - physical and magic armor: you first have to tear through your opponent's armor before you can apply any CC to them; this bothered me a lot at first, when I didn't have the means to get rid of their armors easily, but, as you gain more skills and spells, it becomes less of a problem; there are still some weird things about this system, like you fight an attack dog and it has physical armor for no reason (I mean, I understand when a human enemy has physical armor because he has a breastplate, but a naked dog?) - you have to spend skill points on Memory, which increases your skill slots; I didn't like this at first, because I'd want to spend my points on other attributes; however, it isn't as bad, as you receive free Memory slots when leveling up at certain levels - Source Points; I still don't like this mechanic as some of the best abilities are now locked behind the need of source; these good abilities already had the disadvantage of using more than 1 Memory Slot, but you also need Source to cast them; of course, you can steal source from enemies or corpses, but enemies can also steal you source - a bit of spoiler ahead: the companions that are not in your party at the end of the first area will die, so you cannot see their storyline for the remainder of that playthrough; in my opinion, this is horrible game design, but I guess it helps with replayability - your party members can leave you permanently late in the game, depending on dialog choices, even though you had a good relationship with them (high attitude) until then; I was shocked when this happened, because I don't understand what the point of companion attitude is - new game modes: PvP and Game Master; I haven't tried these yet, so I don't know if they're good, but they're there - it also comes with a free Map Editor  The badThe game also has some bad parts, of course: - I didn't play it when it launched because I was sure there were going to be bugs. I've waited for a week or two and a few patches and played it without major technical issues (though I did have a 100% crash in an area that had a lot of lava around, but lowering the graphical settings resolved that). - on the gameplay side, as many have pointed out, the last part (Arx) isn't as good as the rest of the game, but it's not really that bad. There are some weird fights with respawning enemies in a certain embassy, but those can be avoided by sneaking. P.S.: When writing this review, I'm just before the last fight, so I'm not sure what that's like.  The uglyRed Prince and the lizard kin. They're ugly AF.  VerdictThis is a must buy for any gamer who likes party-based RPGs.

This is an absolute gem. It is absolutely incredible. The graphics, the story, the gameplay, the comedy, you name it. I typically find top down cRPGs rather boring but this is definitely one of the top 10 games I have ever played. Time will tell where it lands but it is incredibly good.  There are plenty of full reviews out there so read those if you want a general review. Here is what I specifically like about it: Larian loves its players and it shows.  They really do. In DOS2, you can customize this game to make it the game you want to play. For example, I am not a hardcore CRPG guy. I like a more casual experience and I also want to play this with my partner, preferably without having to cash out for a second copy. While that might be difficult for most games in the genre, DOS2 lets us set the difficult to Explorer (which feels perfectly balanced for us) and play coop in split screen. It also allowed us to redo our builds after the first act so that any mistakes made could be adjusted without having to start over again. It also autosaves plenty, so we could easily recover from any mistake.  I could easily see how I could play DOS2 by myself and love that too. Or to play it with 3 friends who really love hardcore games. In fact, this is the closest any videogame has ever come to being a tabletop pen and paper roleplaying game IMHO.  Can't wait for DOS3.

NEW PLAYER ADVICE/TUTORIAL If your starting divinity as a new player, heres some advice before you start running into the game head-on thinking this is skyrim; as you will add to the list of players claiming this game is way too hard on classic mode...   No spoilers here btw.  STARTING THE GAME At the very start of the game you are asked to create your character (sorry, spoiler!). DO NOT RUSH THIS PART OF THE GAME. Before you even look at building a class, or rushing into the game, the classes in the game develop over the course of the game, so your playstyle with said character will also change. This game is very slow and methodical, not unlike a game of chess; you have to plan ahead and think through your actions, there is no timer!  For players that have come from COD, or Diablo etc. this is not hack and slash, so you cant just run in head-on; its like sending your king and queen in to try and kill the pawns as fast as possible. try to think about what will happen each turn, and plan 2 turns ahead.  SAVE OFTEN pretty much self explanatory, but you get jumped a lot, so safe often so that you dont have to retrack the past 10 mins of walking around.  READ EVERYTHING AND SPEAK TO EVERYONE. This is probabally the best piece of information i can supply, and without revealing too much. divinity is about tactics not hack and slash, so speak to as many NPC's as possible and explore every area. this will grant you more experience and access to more items. As the enemies in divinity are all level based, this will allow you to stand on equal footing with them, rather than being 3 levels; wearing a loincloth and wielding a knife on a stick (actual weapon, sorry spoiler!) against a group of 7 decked out enemies all positioned in highground and chokepoints. Also reading enemies weaknesses and levels/armor etc. will help you to control fights better.  YOU DONT HAVE TO GO THAT WAY! Many situations you come up against will look pretty damn scary, especially when you realize the enemies ounumber you, outflank you and outlevel you. This usually means you are underlevelled for the area you are currently in, so go back and complete a few more side quests, or just try taking a different route and coming back to said area (hint, you might not even HAVE to complete that area, but this could mean it holds some good items, and more levels!).  WHAT IF... This is the most important question to be asking yourself during the course of the game, and will mean the difference between winning a fight with 0 Deaths, and losing a fight without killing a single enemy... analyse what you can do, what can happen if you do it, and how your opponent can respond (sorry this is vague, trying not to spoil anything). abuse the terrain and your opponents limitations!  TO CONCLUDE This game is as difficult as you make it, which is why a large group of people find it so difficult, because their game is half complete! turn every area upside down before you move on, as there is probably about 3 quests you missed with 2 levels of xp. And DONT RUSH CHARACTER CREATION! Dont be ashamed if you start a new game after playing for an hour on your first playthrough, i did, because i realised i missed so much and learnt what i was doing wrong. Good luck and take your time!  (spoiler) PS. dont let the cat die...

I don't write many reviews on Steam, but I just have to say that this is a RPG gem. If EA published this game, it would cost you thousands of dollars for this much content, which makes the actual pricetag a steal.  I haven't had this much fun in a top-down Roleplaying game since Baldur's Gate II.  If you're on the fence about buying this game, take it from me that you will be engrossed in the story if you wind up purchasing it.  It does take several hours to get into the swing of things, but after that, you won't be able to put it down.

This is my first review so I'll keep it "short" and try to get to the nitty gritty. I bought this game on a whim after seeing a friend of mine had it on his wishlist and couldn't figure out what to get off the store. I wanted something immersive, with serious replay value becuase I (like most people) don't care to drop $40 to $60 on a game you play for 20 hours and never touch agian. Knowing nothing about this series I went ahead and bought it totally blind to what I was in store for, and I'll go on record saying I have ZERO love in my heart for turn-based combat. This game has literally changed the way I feel about turn-based combat. I have never played a game that literally ran off an element I didn't like and still love to play the game, yet I'm drawn back to this title agian and again. In what time I have played it I've barely scratched the surface and I'm constantly wanting to know more. The world is BEYOND immersive, nearly every single NPC has some quest or bit of lore that you can soak up anytime you want, making you run from NPC to NPC trying to figure out the current task or quest you happen to be focusing on at the time. It is not an easy game, but the drive to learn and lose yourself in this world is so great the challenging combat becomes less about a challenge and more about a the actual world itself. I became less driven about the loot as I normally would and was solely driven by want to know more of the story. No game has done that to me since the original God of War. Basically if you want a game that you can totally lose yourself in, this is THE game for you.

Okay, after about 84+ hours into this game, you can assume that I really love this game considering the amount of time I put into it, and you're right. I LOVE THIS GAME. Now, I am not a fan of turn-based rpg's, but this one really made me reconsider. The combat in this game just makes you feel that you need to spend A LOT of time thinking about what your next moves will be because one wrong move can potentially destroy your hopes and dreams of winning the battle. You may think i'm exaggerating, but i'm not. This game really makes you use that thing between your ears. For an indie game, this gem is worth the price.  Lets get down to the pros and cons shall we?  Pros/cons (+/-): +Combat is really good. Makes you think. +ALL of the NPCs are voiced and just doesn't present you with a dialogue box with no one speaking. +Narration is godly +Build according to what you want out of your game. There is no godly class (well, there are some), play what you want. +++Free skill/attribute/talent reset +Amazing soundtrack +The ending(s) depend entirely on what choices you make. +You don't need a full party of 4 to progress. I've seen a lot of players do it solo and it's glorious. +Every map is massive and chock-full of secrets to explore +No loading when fast travelling to waypoints and going in/out of dungeons. +Romance. (There's no gender discrimination either) +Moddable. (check nexus mods for more) +Multiplayer! Play with friends, or play with strangers that could potentially destroy your game. your choice. +Caters to casual and hardcore players alike.   -Could use a little bit more character customization. (Not a lot of options to choose from) -Monsters don't respawn. Therefore, no grinding. :( -Some quests are confusing to complete. (Had to consult the wiki on how to do them) +/-Classic difficulty (aka normal) might come as a shock to new players (like me) considering the massive spike in the learning curve of the game. -Needs more rebalancing. Mages have cooldowns that are too long, Melee classes are too OP.  -Needs more skills -Some skills have a very long animation that makes some fights very long. (yes, im talking to you, source vampirism)  Questions people may ask:  Should I buy this at full price? -YES.  Should I wait for a sale to buy this? -Why would you even do that?  Do I have to be MLG to play this? -Nope. ;)  Overall: 10/10 HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

No doubt one of the best games of the year and likely to be considered one of the best RPGs ever.   I've been having a ball with this game. Its completely awesome in so many ways. The combat, the lore, the sound effects, the skills, the environment, the score, the voice acting.. just head to toe this game is crafted with every detail taken into consideration.  If offers tons of replay value, a nice variety of characters, and so many ways you can approach fights, dialogue, progression.   Its not a hold you hand game.. there are things you will find and things you will miss. It will frustrate you, it will challenge you, and it will provide you a feeling of satisfaction when you win or turn the tide of a fight. It will make you think, it will make you plan and use tactics, it will make you really work on your team and its synergies.   I've already clocked almost 75 hours and haven't gotten too far into Act 2 before I decided to start over now having a better understanding of the game mechanics (this time playing as a lone wolf build).   There simply are too many things in this game that I like to list off here.. as a long time ARPG player I don't tend to spend much time or money with turn-based RPGs, but this game has changed that standpoint for me big time. Its so well thought out, so well designed and is such an intriguing game. Get lost in Rivellon, go explore, talk to everyone, find all the secret loot and solve its many puzzles.   When you leave a game and realize that you're thinking about it when you're not playing about it quite often, you know that its something special. Haven't felt that way about a game in a while!

Rating; 9.8/10  Seriously engrosing gameplay! It's a blackhole that secretly sucks hours and hours until you realise that you spent 20hrs on the first island - and that's not even half the gameplay.  The story is rich, voice acting believeable, and it allows you to make choices - ones that matter, and ones that don't.  But not only that, the choices can be conflicting, it really forces you to think about decisions and consequences.   So actual features that I really enjoyed working with Character choice - kill them/ steal from them/ distract them and loot their home/ story choice/ choose who you want in your party [or none at all]. Combat is both easy and difficult - easy to understand basics, but every fight with my mages, I ended up standing ontop of cursed fire due to some ill-fated mistake I made. Explore! - so much to explore, rewards for exploring, and little tid-bits of joy in every corner Visuals are amazing - with specific areas having different ambient glows/effects, which can be like night/day For example the graveyard is dark and dreary, then you move several metres outside to the green pasture, and it is suddenly happy and chirpy etc.,, I have to wrap up this review, because I just subscribed to new mods for D:OS2, and want to play them, so here we go!  It's worth every cent! I was dubious at first, turnbased RPGs aren't what I would have said 'my thing', story rich games aren't 'my thing', but D:OS2 ties them in so well, that it's entertaining and just works well.  So many small things that this game brings to the table that are worth attention, but alas - you'll have to check those out yourself.  I have one con about this game; it's hard to play 'the bad guy', in the story. You can be a♥♥♥♥♥♥to people, but the core story doesn't have some ultimate evil badguy option, which was a bit dissapointing as my second playthru as a solo-thief/asssasin means I can't take over the world and make everyone my slave.

Divinity Original Sin 2 is one of the best games ever created. It is about creating your own story and crafting your own experience. Characters can die before you even have the chance to meet them, even off-screen, so 2 playthroughs will never be the same. You can take a lot of decisions, be it slaughter a town, make enemies or allies, betray people, steal stuff, mind control them, eat them, absorb their souls, save a dude only to realize he has one hell of a sword and that you want it or decide between killing a dragon, freeing the dragon or breaking his shackles to challenge him to a fair battle to the death and so much more.  The game also features total freedom. You can always respect your character starting from act 2 and there is no class system. Everyone can change their equipments and skills on the go. Mixing certain tree skills allows you to create devastating combos and you can really enjoy watching as your character grows from a nobody to someone that can be praised, hate or feared across the land.  Music is extremly good and you can choose from up to 4 different instruments, each making the battlefield give off a different vibe and enriching your experience. From a calming flute to a intense chello. Graphics are also pretty good for a game of this scale, most areas are detailed and the effect of skills and environments are breath-taking. When you cast a thunder, it sounds and looks realistic, it gives a feeling that it is really going to zap someone's life out of them. Creatures design is also decent, while you might find stuff you had already seen multiple times in other games, there are also some stuff that has never been seen before. Like flesh eating elves that are also plants.  The only faults I find in this game are that it can be pretty hard for newcomers or people who don't play strategic games often, that it could explain some of it's mechanics better or be more detailed in how certain things came to be. But these are all minor complaints for the most part. Do yourself a favor a buy/play this game becuase if you don't you are only missing out on some of the best stuff on Steam.   A tip I would give to everyone who plays this game is to take the "Pet Talk" talent. It allows you to speak with animals!( or for them to speak with you) and this gives you access to some of the most funny stuff in the game as well as dead threats, unique situations, some of the most interesting characters and even foretelling of dark lords coming to kill all life on the planet.  5/5.  Would love to hear more about insects dark lords, being roasted by a LV 3 guy with a fire dragon and fighting inmortal trolls that won't allow you to pass through a bridge unless you pay insanes amount of golds.

I've put some time into this game, and just writing this makes me want to do a 4th playthrough. Buy this game.

Playing Divinity Original Sin feels very much like playing a Dungeons And Dragons game, and it's also the game it takes most of its inspiration from. It's an easier to understand version of DnD, and I think it is perfectly possible to release a PnP version of the core rules of the game. While these rules aren't really explained in-game, they are very intuitive and it's easy to comprehend what is going on behind combat.  I like Divinity Original Sin 2. It's a little bit different from the first game, but still it feels very fresh and the problems addressed with the first game are now gone.  Differences from the first game One of the biggest differences are now the "two-type-of-armor-system". One is physical and the other one magical. Little bit similar as in the Starfinder Pen And Paper RPG, where you got AC for physical damage and EC for Energy Damage. Other differences are balancing of the skills, damage dealing and spells. Also the action points are fixed. Crafting is different too and is now easier. The rock-paper-scissor mini game for conversations is also gone.  Another big difference are two new races, which in the beginning I wasn't really convinced of, but if you play further they fit really well into the story.  The Story The story is also in my opinion better told than in the first one.  I'm not a fan of voice acting in general, but this game does it really well, especially since dialogue is mostly text-based and everything is also voice acted. It's very nicely done. So you don't have to listen to the voice actors to know what is coming. You can just read and respond to it faster.  What is good about this game is that the story allows for multiple solutions to certain problems. This can be from ignoring the quest and fight your way through to multiple civil solutions you can do by "roleplaying".  These solutions aren't always clear and not everything is handed out to you by map markers or highlighted characters. You have to find out most of the stuff yourself.  The first time I played the starter island, I dumbly fought my way out of the prison. But actually on my second try of the game, I already found 4 ways of getting out of the prison. Which made me wonder now... how much stuff I have missed or didn't see the first or even the second time I will play through this game.  Combat Combat is very similar as in DnD. It's turn-based, which is fun. But sometimes also so slow when facing many enemies at once. It can also become very difficult at times. It's not an easy game.  So when combat starts, just as in most turnbased RPG's everybody gets their initiative, based on their initiative score and something else I don't have found out... That determines who gets first in combat. Note that turns always alternate between player and opponent. Your initiative only determines the order of your own characters.  The other difference in divinity from other RPG's is that no matter what, you will almost always do damage. The percentage of missing an attack is very low. I think characters can dodge an attack if they have the appropriate talent or if the attacker simply just missed. When dealing damage, you first have to destroy their respective armor and then you can lower their HP. Which is pretty cool. So you don't have to roll to hit against an armor number, which makes it possible and more fun to attack a higher level enemy with multiple characters. It gives you the sense that your attacks actually do something instead of miss. There is also a chance you do critical damage with each weapon. That percentage is also determined by your wits. And the percentage damage it does extra is determined by the weapon stats itself.  Damage dealt is also more fun than in D&D. You always do minimal damage with certain weapons. So if you have sword and it does between 5-8 damage it would be in DND 1d4+4. There is no way you do only 1 damage, there is no way you can roll bad. Also the damage of weapons and spells increase with your attributes.  Character Creation The damage you do, they hp you have, etc... is based on your attributes. Which is very similar to abilities in D&D. The names are sometimes different, but they work in the same way. The only new one is "Wits", it effects your critical chance, initiative and perception.  Next to attributes are abilities. Which are called skills in DnD. These increase characters effectiveness with weapons or allow you to take more skills. There are two kinds of abilities in the game. Combat and Civil abilities. Some help with bartering or sneaking other with damage of certain weapon types.  Then there are skills, which are also are a little bit like skills in D&D. They determine the effectiveness of your spells and weapons. The huge difference is that you can always learn a new skill, thus getting the proficiency with everything related to that skill. So if you want to cast fire spells with a certain character, just give him the pyromania skill. These skills get their bonuses from their respected attributes and scale with level. The weapon related skills scale with the weapons you have.  The skills you can actually do are those you have learned from skill books, which act like the feats from pathfinder or DnD 3.5. You can find those books or buy them from vendors. These are plenty and easy to find and mostly bossfights will reward you with one. The number of skills you can remember are determined by character level.  And then at last you have the talents, which are also a little bit like feats or special abilities in DnD. The talents are passive and give you certain perks. Like talking with animals, or you heal more if you are alone, stuff like that.  Similarities with DnD What also came over from 3.5 DND is that the range and damage of your ranged attacks are higher when having the higher ground. That you can flank enemies and that you can have attacks of opportunity. The different kind of states the characters can be in are also the same: sleepy, diseased, slowed, poisoned and they are also healed in almost the same way. The different kinds of terrain also work the same and make the combat very entertaining because it's a huge part of the game. It's also one of the first basic tricks for every DM in a rpg to make combat interesting by having cool environments.  O, yeah, graphics and stuff... Furthermore, the graphics and sounds are very good. The user interface is very well done with many effects to make it enjoyable to use.  Actually I'm not really into graphics of games and while this game is obviously more demanding and detailed in its graphics and sound in comparison to the first game, I still prefer... the original - not even the definitive edition - of the first game. Because of the more cartoony look. If you know me, my favorite type of graphics are those of the computer games between the years 1998 and 2004. Those were good times.  Only <3 for this game!

So good it will make you question WTF everyone else is spending time and money on when they develop an RPG. It's the best turn-based RPG I've played in a very long time, and one where I actually feel like I'm playing a role. Which is especially good since you all know we can't count on Final Fantasy for that fix anymore.  The Good: Fully voiced campaign, including all NPC's! (Even big budget titles don't do this!) All playable characters are customizable, and able to be used as their own character, including recruited companions. Pick an origin story, or make up your own. Fun, tactical, and innovative combat system. Very Replayable. Moddable, with a custom campaign creator to boot. As if that wasn't enough, it has a D&D style Game Master mode.  The Bad: Persuasion is overpowered. Don't get me wrong, I like having a charming character who can talk their way out of some situations, but it seems like most things in this game have persuasion options, sometimes when it wouldn't even make sense for someone to be convinced otherwise. It requires little effort to make a character to fulfill the necessary requirements, as it's easy to pump your main character full of persuasion and let other characters handle other areas. Sometimes I consider this a great boon to the role-playing side of things, but it also makes for a weaker experience in gameplay. One of the weakest aspects of the game in fact, IMO.  While Larian did an excellent job desiging the areas and leveling, enemy level scaling still doesn't exist. I know some people like those moments where you revisit an earlier part of a level and you can just murder everything, but I prefer every combat encounter to have weight.  I enjoy little moments in games like Elder Scrolls, where NPC's act racist, especially toward non-human races, because it's realistic, helps immersion, and gives you an added cause, with characters and concepts to combat. You want to do your character's race justice, perhaps change opinions, or get vengence. It's good for role playing. But in this game TOO MANY characters are racist. I get that they want to add text that changes based on a character's race but, good land, does everyone hate the lizard-folk? It seems like they do! Even the *animals* slander my main character. It just takes a good, immersive idea too far, and just pushes it to the point of being expected and annoying.  Overall, however, the positives outweigh the negatives by far. This is now one of my favorite games of all time, and I could not recommend it more.

Once you're finished playing this game, you'll be fed up with the rest of the mediocre, money grabbing and trashy AAA title games on the market.  Thank you Larian Studios.

Awesome!  So me and 3 of my mates are playing the campaign together - Each of us for the first time so it's all fresh and fun!  Last night we were attacking a group on a balcony which drew aggro from 3 below - There were 2 stairways up to us, one directly and one that went ALL the way around the balcony.  Within a turn or two, two of the guys at the bottom start running up to us. On the close stairway I cast rain and lightning it, stunning the two. After the lightning effect wears off, I oiled a portion of the area and slowed them down. During this time, we finish of most of the enemies up high. The third guy however walked in circles at the bottom seemingly ignoring us...  After a turn or two more, the 2 guys on the stairs reached myself so I teleported one of them back to the bottom to give us some extra time. When I did this, the third guy STILL at the bottom decided to ATTACK his own TEAMMATE to heal himself!! He was on full health!! He just attacked poor Timothy for no reason hahaha!!  Sooooo, a few turns later, the second guy had run back up the stairs and we'd dealt with him and all the others. Just the third guy remaining... He, who obviously wanted no part in this fight, had decided to, for whatever reason, to go up the other stairs and ALLLLLLLL the way around...  So, we decided to set a plan of ambush - Because at this point we were all laughing and just mocking this particular guy anyway - So we all gathered on the balcony that the path led to just around a corner, except for our support guy who stood right at the back of the path.. I set a layer of ice, and some oil, and then we just skipped turns for him to run to us.  Finally, one turn away, JUST around this corner we could see him. I froze the poor guy, and someone else warmed him up just to toy with him. We were all laughing given how long it took for him to get there... HIS TURN!! FINALLY!! We figured we'd let him hit just one of us just because.. But no!! What's this?? He's run past me... And my friend... And another... And then past 2 minions... Where's he going?!?! hahahaha. He ran directly at the support guy but ran out of AP and just stood next to him thinking for a while, then passed his go! Hahahaha!! He'd just about made it around the entire balcony when we finally killed him..  God damn that was funny!! Cannot wait till we're all online tonight :D    Basically the same game as the first but with improvements in skills, choices, graphics, etc. Highly recommended!

TL;DR Buy this game! Best RPG game I've ever played and in my top 3 games of all time without a doubt. There are hundreds of hours of gameplay here. The gameplay is quality unlike games like Skyrim which pretty much relies on mods to be fun for extended play sessions, which this game also offers. Dialog and story is also some of the best you'll find in recent games with  every piece of dialog being voiced which is just a great thing for an Indie game to do.  Seriously 9.9/10 game.  This is honestly the best RPG I have ever played and one of the best games I've played in general. This is one of the few single-player games that I just can't stop playing.   Before I played this game me and my friends played a lot of D&D, but we couldn't find enough time to play as much as we'd like since we were in our final year of school. So for ages I looked for a game that could emulate that same expirence. Being able to do what I want, having funny moments as well as epic. When one of my friends showed me this I was hooked.   The mechanics are almost the exact same as old school table top games, so iif you're into that turn based combat you'll love this, but even someone like me that normally hates those kind of combat mechanics in games I just loved these just because of how polished they were. The combat suprisingly has a lot of depth to it. There's so many different spells and equipment and many of them interact with eachother in their own ways.  The story and dialog is also one of the best I've ever seen in a game. Most of the dialog has so much character and is of such high quality, only of the voices feel as they were acted poorly, but 10000x better than you'll see in any Bethesda game. The fact that all of the dialog in the game is voice acted is also just an amaznig thing. It makes it feel as you're living in a real world and it also helps with the consistancy where some lines would be voiced and some wouldn't. This wouldn't mean anything iff the story wasn't good, which thankfully it isn't. The story is so good. It pulls you emotionally in so many different directions and you have to make so many decisions that make or break relationships and have an effect on what happens for the rest of the game.  Character creation is also pretty good, different races and classes having different traits and abilities as per usual. This part is the only part that I find to be pretty hard on new characters since some races and classes are harder to play than others, which can make it difficult and punishing. This can become a non-issue early in the game since you have the choice to pretty much change everything about you if you're not happy about it.  The one thing that I wish could be different about the game is its modding cababilities. Sadly as of now there aren't any mods anywhere near as big as mods that you find in Bethesda games, but thankfully this isn't a Bethesda game so you don't need mods to make it interesting lmao. This game does have the ability to act as your own Dungeon Master and make a whole game for you, your friends and your fellow steam gamers. and you also have the ability to download other peoples campains which just extends the hundreds of hours in the base game.  This game is almost a perfect example of what a game should be. For the gamer by not constantly trying to ram microtransactions down every hole in your body, have hundreds of high quality content from launch. Constant interaction with the community, THESE GUYS MAKE VLOGS MAN!!! and last but not least they don't do what every triple-a developer is doing now and making all their content and just releasing it as expansions. These guys are just about to release a FREE expansion that adds hundreds of more hours of gameplay which I would be more than happy to pay for since it is actually worth it and it's made to add value to the game instead of be a stupid cash grab.     SO IN SUMMARY. Buy this game, its amazing how an indie studio made on of the best games of recent times from a kickstarter with a reasonably small studio compared to multi-billion dollar companies that make subpar games at best. These people really care about what they create and it shows in their final product. I recommend this game to everyone and I feel like a better person everytime I do so.

Great game, great engine, fun combat.   Not Quite as good as Pillars of Eternity though. I found myself comparing the 2 a lot during my 100 hour play through of the campaign to the end.  During that play through I spent half my time playing the game and half my time loading quick saves. It might just be how I deal with multiple outcomes in situations but it also came from making constant stupid mistakes. This game really shows you just how smart or dumb you are as a person, or at least makes you feel like a complete idiot so many times.    Part of the reason why Divinity 2 made me feel like a dummy was probably due to how much I had to rely on Google and Game Wiki's to get quests done or to get through situations or puzzles. Too often it felt like the game hadnt given me enough clues or any at all to progress through some situations, and that can be completely on me most the time for being thick in the head, but I found more than a few times that it happened turned out to be something that I would never have discovered no matter how switched on I was. For example theres a moment you have to put a specific framed picture onto a plaque on the ground to unlock a hatch you wouldnt even know was there to continue the story and there was no way of guessing you had to do that and the only clue it gave was so vague that I wouldnt have put 2 and 2 together in a million years. Moments like that made the game as frustrating as it was enjoyable.  Theres something about Pillars of Eternity's flow through the locations and storyline that was just so much more peacful, Immersive and enjoyable for me compared to Divinity 2, but when I compare these games together PoE only just comes out on top against Divinity for the reasons I mentioned above.  I recommend this game, but I must say, before you start, book a week off school or work and turn your phone off, because its all you're going to do until you finish it.

The game itself is great and a true continuation and development of all that was loved and praised about the first Original Sin; however, and it's a big however, the engine is buggy as hell.  There's an odd core usage issue which means that multi core cpus are not utilized and the game dumps everything onto a single core - notice the strange frame skip stutter when panning?  That's a core usage issue and nothing else.  It seems the devs either don't care to fix the issue or can't fix the issue, which means one has to set the processor affinity to a single core and then back to all cores in task manager every single time one plays the game.  Not cool.  So if they sort that out, it's a highly recommended game; if not, it's still recommended but be prepared to tune your system every playthrough.  Oh yes, also there are issues with overclocked CPUs and GPUs.  Come on Larian, get your technical issues as sorted out as you've gotten the combat in this game.

After beating the game on classic difficulty.  Pros: Fun tactical combat Largely voiced, either by the narrator or the NPCs. Good story and writing in general Smart enemy AI Animations satisfying to watch Sounds are well done Good music. Not as good as Nier: Automata. But still fairly good. A long game. First run took me ~130 hours, looking through every nook and cranny I could find, reading everything, using no walkthroughs. Tons of replayability. Many different choices, several different races and origin stories with different perspectives. Multiplayer (which I haven't touched yet) Mod support (which I haven't touched yet) Tons of flexibility as far as what your character can become. Many side quests which are well done, Several of which span across acts. Clearly defined "Point of no return" points.  Cons: Doesn't hold your hand as much as other games. (Which I personally like, but some people might not.) Balance issues between the classes (Debateable) Noticeable drop in quality in the final act. MIssing voiceovers. One notorious and buggy enemy encounter where weak enemies keep respawning, potentially for hours, with no xp gain. Quests more screwy. One NPC talked to a party member calling them someone else who has never been in the party. Needs patching. (My main complaint) The crafting system largely expects you to experiment. No materials are lost upon a failed combination. But I'm not going to bash things together all day until something works. At the end of the game I was still mostly unsure if most of the stuff I collected had any use. There are anvils and blacksmithing tools, but crafting armor/weapons/food dishes never seemed worth it and were a waste of space. Etc. Inventory system needs to be more user friendly. Like selecting multiple things at once. Or a search function. The storage box needs to be broken down into categories just like your inventory is.  Overall, tons of bang for your buck, which is what I'm all about. 9/10. Would be 10/10 if it wasn't for the issues in the final act.
